They still give you a divider even if you get two of the same broths, which is really convenient if you have dietary restrictions or if you're sick and you don't want to share broths!
The spicy miso broth was pretty good. I love spicy food and the spiciness level is pretty mild. I like that they use wagyu beef instead of the usual kobe beef. I thought the meat quality was good but it was a little too tough and chewy. It's also served with udon, tofu, 3 types of mushrooms, napa cabbage, spinach, and carrots. They gave a sesame sauce and ponzu sauce, and I typically only like to use the ponzu at any hot pot place. I thought the ponzu was pretty salty, but it was good when I dilute it with a little broth. I love the porridge at the end! They add rice, egg and green onions to one of the broths. They also top it with seaweed but I opt for no seaweed. The porridge is so good but we were really full and just brought the rest home!
There's no AYCE options. They definitely chose quality over quantity. The prices recently increased to $22 for regular and $26 for large! I think it's slightly more expensive than average but you pay for quality!
Also, one major downside is that it was so hot and stuffy in there when it was packed. The glass walls in the front even start fogging up! They have ventilation but it's not nearly strong enough.

excerpts: We ordered the spicy miso with our shabu shabu and it tasted pretty watered down.
The soy based dipping sauce had more flavor.
The tea needs to be served hot as well, instead of heating it on the same range as the hotpot.
Our main set came out pretty quickly after the tea so there was no time for it to even warm.
Portions of meat
we're just right, but the portions of veggies we're on the skimpy side.
shabu shabu.author: Andrea B.
shabu shabu.review:
Good service, like the ambience, though very loud and could use better spot lighting at night.

The ingredients are tasty and interesting, however the broth was bland.  We ordered the spicy miso with our shabu shabu and it tasted pretty watered down.  The soy based dipping sauce had more flavor.  The tea needs to be served hot as well, instead of heating it on the same range as the hotpot.  Our main set came out pretty quickly after the tea so there was no time for it to even warm. Portions of meat we're just right, but the portions of veggies we're on the skimpy side. Sake was delicious.

Overall pretty nice experience, albeit nosy and over priced.  One set,  small sake, tea, one starter,  two extra ingredients, and tax was more than $100

excerpts: Which in this case, is shabu shabu.
In this case, the boyfriend and I ordered a regular Sukiyaki and a regular shabu shabu.
($20 each).
It came with two sauces:
a soy sauce/ponzu flavored one and a sesame one.
Both were great but
the ponzu one could be stronger.
Good portions surprisingly.
We thought it wouldn't be enough, but ended up being very full!
The veggies were mostly identical in both sets.
shabu shabu.author: Lucy Z.
shabu shabu.review:
With the mostly unpredictable (and mostly chilly) weather, I'm always in the mood for soups and broths. The obvious answer is hot pot! Which in this case, is shabu shabu. Not that I'm an expert in the difference, but I think it's the sauces and portions of the two that differ.

In this case, the boyfriend and I ordered a regular Sukiyaki and a regular shabu shabu. ($20 each). It came with two sauces: a soy sauce/ponzu flavored one and a sesame one. Both were great but the ponzu one could be stronger. Good portions surprisingly. We thought it wouldn't be enough, but ended up being very full! The veggies were mostly identical in both sets. The beef was good as well.

Absolutely loved the end of the meal! This part is dinner only: If you ordered the sets, the server will make a rice soup with the rest of your broth. The broth is heated, then a bowl of Zosui rice is added. Stirred for a few mins, then a raw egg is cracked in the mixture. Stir some more, add green onions, and it's finished. Topped with seaweed! It's so freakin' good. I would have bowls of this just by itself. This isn't offered for lunch, so if you're curious, definitely come for dinner!

Shout-out to the service. Came by at 8:45 PM on a Sunday night and the place was packed. Two (or three) servers took care of the whole restaurant and were really friendly/attentive. We never felt rushed (they close at 10 PM) or neglected.

Space is limited so make a reservation just in case. Est. $50 for two people.

excerpts: One Sukiyaki pot and another Shabu Shabu plate.
The service was good, as our food came out fairly quickly.
We ordered pork and beef respectively for our meats.
shabu shabu.author: James D.
shabu shabu.review:
Came here last night with two other people and I was really impressed!

We ordered two large pots. One Sukiyaki pot and another Shabu Shabu plate. The service was good, as our food came out fairly quickly. We ordered pork and beef respectively for our meats. The pots both came with an assortments of vegetables. 

The meats tasted good and the broths were good as well! The entire Shabu experience was really good here!

Plus at the end of the meal they make this rice porridge for you which is amazing! We all split the billl and it came out to about $20 a person.

excerpts: We ordered the Kimchi Pork broth and Shabu Shabu, both turned out to be amazing.
We decided to use the kimchi broth for the porridge and that was probably the best part of the entire dinner.
We spent about $30 after tax and tip which is a little on the expensive side
but I think it's totally worth it for occasional enjoyments!
shabu shabu.author: Angel C.
shabu shabu.review: Nabe is one of my favorite restaurants in SF :) I especially love the porridge thing they would do at the end with your leftover broth. I went here with a friend at 6:30pm on a weekend. I strongly recommend you to call ahead and make a reservation. I called around 5:50 to snatch the 6:30 table, so don't need to call too early either unless you have a large party. Service was good and very attentive. We ordered the Kimchi Pork broth and Shabu Shabu, both turned out to be amazing. We decided to use the kimchi broth for the porridge and that was probably the best part of the entire dinner. We spent about $30 after tax and tip which is a little on the expensive side but I think it's totally worth it for occasional enjoyments!

excerpts: Enter Nabe, Inner Sunset's suave shabu shabu place.
shabu shabu.author: Edna C.
shabu shabu.review:
Floor-to-ceiling glass windows.
Pinterest-worthy wall decor of sake in wooden case dispensers.
Water served in pink and blue frosted sake bottles.
Sleek modern furniture.
Wooden utensils.
The classiness of not smelling like kBBQ.
Enter Nabe, Inner Sunset's suave shabu shabu place.

It's a cool ambiance with a general bouge feel, but overall I found it lacking flavor and more pricey for what it's worth. Yes it's locally sourced organic etc., which unfortunately doesn't translate to tasty. The broths were mediocre, and the portions were tiny (meat was sliced *paper-thin*!) I think we ordered a beef and a pork thing and added some noodles and mochi, but I don't remember exactly because it wasn't all too memorable. The redemption factor was the yummy rice broth at the end that everyone raves about. Overall though, $20 later, we were all still hungry :(

I think Nabe would be the best for a girl's night out (or maybe a date to impress a girl who really like ambiancey places). The food is nothing mind-blowing, but you feel so SF eating overpriced organic shabu and sitting in a pretty restaurant with a crowd outside waiting for your table.

excerpts: We ordered the Spicy Miso Shabu Shabu set ($20 regular/$24 large) and the Sukiyaki set ($20 regular/$24 large).
Each of those came with assorted vegetables and an order of Wagyu beef.
We ordered another two plates of Wagyu beef ($12 each regular) and Duck Breasts ($16 regular) as an add-on.
shabu shabu.author: Cindy Z.
shabu shabu.review:
Upon entering this quaint restaurant, the sweet aroma just fills you up. I already fell in love with the flavors of the restaurant just from its scent. The four of us were seated in about half an hour even after we called in over an hour earlier to put our name down. The wonderful thing about this place is that the pot is great for two with an additional order of meat as my friend recommended. We ordered the Spicy Miso Shabu Shabu set ($20 regular/$24 large) and the Sukiyaki set ($20 regular/$24 large). Each of those came with assorted vegetables and an order of Wagyu beef. We ordered another two plates of Wagyu beef ($12 each regular) and Duck Breasts ($16 regular) as an add-on. First of all, this place is pretty pricey, but the flavor and quality is absolutely worth the splurge.

Although I had the Spicy Miso pot, I also tried the Sukiyaki and absolutely fell in love with it. The sweet and salty flavor was unique and tasteful. I kept refilling my bowl with the soup to drink, yum. In the end, you also get to choose one of your soups to make into a porridge and of course we chose the Sukiyaki flavor. The porridge is mixed with rice, green onions, egg, and seaweed. I never knew it could taste so delicious! The food here is definitely something I'd be back for, but the service not so much. It took forever for us to be seated, forever to order, forever to get our checks so that's where they lose a star. Also, it's a very cramped and tiny restaurant, so not much moving room.

excerpts: We ordered the tako su octopus salad, the shabu shabu, and the seafood yosenabe.
The spicy miso broth for the shabu shabu was spicy/savory and the dashi broth for the seafood yosenabe was sweet/savory.
The wagyu beef that came with the set was not fatty at all (which we like) and of good quality and the seafood that came with the other set was of wide variety too!
We really enjoyed the porridge at the end of the meal as well.
Also, their service was great!
They were able to sit us super fast on a Friday night even after we were told that the wait would be about 30 minutes!
shabu shabu.author: Grace M.
shabu shabu.review: We ordered the tako su octopus salad, the shabu shabu, and the seafood yosenabe. The spicy miso broth for the shabu shabu was spicy/savory and the dashi broth for the seafood yosenabe was sweet/savory. The wagyu beef that came with the set was not fatty at all (which we like) and of good quality and the seafood that came with the other set was of wide variety too! We really enjoyed the porridge at the end of the meal as well. Also, their service was great! They were able to sit us super fast on a Friday night even after we were told that the wait would be about 30 minutes!

excerpts: We ordered a large shabu shabu and the Kinoko Nabe split.
It came with side of beef, veggies, spinach, and tofu.
shabu shabu.author: Brian L.
shabu shabu.review:
Came here on a weekday with two friends. We waited roughly 10-15 mins for a table to open up and the staff was kind. 

We ordered a large shabu shabu and the Kinoko Nabe split. It came with side of beef, veggies, spinach, and tofu. We also ordered a side of pork belly as well. 

Overall, service and food was good. For SF price ranges, it's pretty typical but for three people with 3 different sets our bill came out to $100 after tip. For the price, I didn't think the food was worth it. There are other AYCE hot pot places and even KBBQ places that are from the 24.99-29.99 price range, and thats AYCE!

The rice porridge at the end of the meal was nice, but I don't think I would come back. There are other places I rather go out on a nice dinner than here. You get full from eating the carbs (rice, noodles, udon) rather than the meat and veggies. There are better hot pot places for a better value else where.

excerpts: After a sunny afternoon stroll along Ocean Beach in San Francisco, sharing the shabu shabu with Waygu beef was delicious and satisfying!
Restaurant was cleanly designed, unpretentious, and the service was impeccable.
Would definitely return!
shabu shabu.author: Evelyn C.
shabu shabu.review: After a sunny afternoon stroll along Ocean Beach in San Francisco, sharing the shabu shabu with Waygu beef was delicious and satisfying!  Restaurant was cleanly designed, unpretentious, and the service was impeccable. Would definitely return!

excerpts: The real deal as far as Shabu Shabu is concerned.
shabu shabu.author: Ken M.
shabu shabu.review:
This place is great, and I am very grateful to have it in our neighborhood.
The real deal as far as Shabu Shabu is concerned.

excerpts: Yummy shabu shabu place!
I ordered extra toppings because I didn't know how much vegetables come with the basic sukiyaki pot.
They turned out to have plenty of mushrooms, tofu, and cabbage to begin with, so I recommend getting toppings after you see what comes with the pot.
Me and my girlfriend gobbled everything up.
The broth and the meat were so good.
And they have cool servers.
shabu shabu.author: Haein K.
shabu shabu.review:
Yummy shabu shabu place!
I ordered extra toppings because I didn't know how much vegetables come with the basic sukiyaki pot. They turned out to have plenty of mushrooms, tofu, and cabbage to begin with, so I recommend getting toppings after you see what comes with the pot. Me and my girlfriend gobbled everything up. The broth and the meat were so good. And they have cool servers.

excerpts: Clean , minimalist lines in the decor ,food features Shabu Shabu and Sukiyaki hot pots .
Gyoza is above average and a good prelude to the main courses.
Rice tends to be tough , possible arefact of sitting around too long in the rice cooker .
The broth is a bit sweet , possibly as a concession to most customers who like their food to be sweet .
The A5 beef is definitely worth a splurge , the Wagyu is wonderfully marbled and Flavorful especially when washed down with Ice cold Asahi  super dry.
The service is efficient and welcoming .
The wait out front even on a Monday night is a testimonial to the pleasing decor , good food and fine hospitality .
shabu shabu.author: Shariq Y.
shabu shabu.review:
Nabe on Lombard is one half of a two store chain run by a brother and sister team. Extremely popular with Millennials and Young families . Clean , minimalist lines in the decor ,food features Shabu Shabu and Sukiyaki hot pots . Gyoza is above average and a good prelude to the main courses. Rice tends to be tough , possible arefact of sitting around too long in the rice cooker .
The broth is a bit sweet , possibly as a concession to most customers who like their food to be sweet .
The A5 beef is definitely worth a splurge , the Wagyu is wonderfully marbled and Flavorful especially when washed down with Ice cold Asahi  super dry.  The service is efficient and welcoming .
The wait out front even on a Monday night is a testimonial to the pleasing decor , good food and fine hospitality .

excerpts: The shabu shabu broth is good too, very traditional.
And the spicy shabu is really spicy
so make sure you can handle it.
The veggies and sides that come with the sets are fresh (comes with napa cabbage, mushrooms, tofu, carrot slices, kabocha slices, and either udon or clear Soba noodles).
Rice provided upon request too.
As for meat portions, the large set is enough for me to finish on my own if I'm hungry (which is every time I come here) and the regular set is only a few pieces less.
shabu shabu.author: Audrey D.
shabu shabu.review:
Excellent service and a dark, intimate ambiance. Would be cute for a higher end hot pot date night! 

They do split pot on one stove per two people. 
I usually go with the sukiyaki with their wagyu beef. The sukiyaki broth is a little on the sweet side, but it makes for a delicious congee combo when they add rice to the leftover broth and reduce it to a tasty treat. It makes for AMAZING leftovers. The congee is their house special and included in the price for the shabu sets (why it's more expensive than other places). 
The shabu shabu broth is good too, very traditional. And the spicy shabu is really spicy so make sure you can handle it. 
The veggies and sides that come with the sets are fresh (comes with napa cabbage, mushrooms, tofu, carrot slices, kabocha slices, and either udon or clear Soba noodles). Rice provided upon request too. As for meat portions, the large set is enough for me to finish on my own if I'm hungry (which is every time I come here) and the regular set is only a few pieces less.

excerpts: It's a shabu shabu place rather than a noodle shop but either way it's nice to have a local option for hot Japanese soup.
shabu shabu.author: Alan S.
shabu shabu.review:
A really nice addition to the neighborhood, especially since Hotei is no longer in business.  It's a shabu shabu place rather than a noodle shop but either way it's nice to have a local option for hot Japanese soup.

This place gets pretty crowded but my wife and I were fortunate enough to get seated within 10 minutes of showing up.  They have a nice selection of different broths and food items to cook in it.  We got the mushroom platter which comes with miso broth... ordered a side of fish cake for extra protein.  I'll say that the miso was nice if not great...a bit on the bland side but I tend to like strong flavors so your mileage may vary.  It's not clear from the menu but there exists an option for "spicy miso broth" so if you want miso with a bit more kick be sure to tell your server, we had some of that and I found it much more to my liking, The mushrooms and other veggies themselves were very nice, especially the trumpet mushrooms.

I would be remiss if I did not comment on the specialty sake flight I had.  WOW!  Definitely a stand out.  I don't know how it compares to the similarly priced premium sake flight or the cheaper standard flight but the unfiltered and pearled sake on offer with this flight were top notch, definitely a nice experience for $20 and reasonably generous (albeit still small) pours for each.

excerpts: I would've to say that Nabe is the only Shabu Shabu restaurant that makes me want to come back over over and over again, I can have their hot pot 3 days in a row i would say, not only Nabe has the best authentic Japanese hot pot taste to me, but it also very creative in the way they use the left over broth to make rice porridge in no time (isn't it sound great!!).
shabu shabu.author: Kerry P.
shabu shabu.review:
I would've to say that Nabe is the only Shabu Shabu restaurant that makes me want to come back over over and over again, I can have their hot pot 3 days in a row i would say, not only Nabe has the best authentic Japanese hot pot taste to me, but it also very creative in the way they use the left over broth to make rice porridge in no time (isn't it sound great!!). Not to mention their special desserts, that no restaurants can imitate- green tea cheescake and the homemade mochi cake(served hot with ice cream, which is a must try). 
Also, the staffs are really really sweet, I love them all

excerpts: Had great quick service and bomb shabu shabu.
shabu shabu.author: Christian P.
shabu shabu.review: Came here right after visiting the California academy of sciences. Best timing since Nabe opens at 5 and the science center closes at 5. We were the first to arrive, first to leave. Was a good idea since it got packed 30 mins after it opened. Had great quick service and bomb shabu shabu.

excerpts: She drools over my shabu shabu pictures in LA
so she asked me to find a good shabu place in SF.
Nabe is new and came highly recommended
so we made reservations.
+ Shabu shabu (wagyu beef/kurobuta pork and udon in radition konbu, miso, or spicy miso)
- get this with wagyu beef and SPICY MISO.
I've had spicy miso at other locations and this one is by far the best spicy miso shabu I've ever had.
I HIGHLY recommend.
shabu shabu.author: Elysse P.
shabu shabu.review:
I was visiting SF for a week and I told my best friend to choose a place to eat for Christmas. She drools over my shabu shabu pictures in LA so she asked me to find a good shabu place in SF. Nabe is new and came highly recommended so we made reservations. MAKE RESERVATIONS, it's tiny!

Ambiance could be better... There's a loooooooooooong communal table in the middle and a few tables on the side. LUCKILY my bestie and I got our own table to the side. I would've hated to catch up in between a bunch of strangers. They use the space to the fullest extent... like there's barely any room for the waiters to move around AND it's a fucking sauna in there. It's so funny cuz the glass windows literally steam up and you can't see anything outside. Ok on the important part... the food.

You order a set of broth and meat and choose regular or large. The sets come with the items listed plus assorted veggies, noodles, and rice. You can also add veggies and more meat for an additional fee. I thought that the sets provided more than enough. For a party of 2, order these two sets to share... perfect combination!

+ Sukiyaki (wagyu beef and shirataki in warishita broth) - I liked their sukiyaki. Sometimes it can be TOO sweet or salty, but theirs is just right. Wagyu beef is super on point... really great quality. I highly recommend this set.

+ Shabu shabu (wagyu beef/kurobuta pork and udon in radition konbu, miso, or spicy miso) - get this with wagyu beef and SPICY MISO. I've had spicy miso at other locations and this one is by far the best spicy miso shabu I've ever had. I HIGHLY recommend. Again the wagyu beef is great and I don't think I'd ever stray from beef with shabu. 

+ porridge - What's different about Nabe that I really enjoyed was the porridge they make for you at the end of your meal. They simply ask you to choose a broth, add rice and condiments, and voila... delicious. 

Ask for their ponzu and goma sauce because I don't think they don't serve it automatically with your set. AND be sure to ask for garlic, green onions, daikon, and chili oil/powder (if you like spice) to add to each sauce. 

Nabe is missing one important ingredient - hot drops to add to the sauce. Every shabu spot in SoCal has this and it is a key component. LUCKILY we brought our own so the lack of it didn't kill our experience lol. Nabe, I suggest looking into it. 

I'm hoping they expand in the near future. This spot has so much potential.

excerpts: My friend & I came to Nabe to try their shabu shabu.
I ordered the regular sized ($19) shabu shabu with kurobuta pork with spicy miso broth.
The shabu shabu itself was average.
I have had much better shabu elsewhere.
However, after our meal, we were offered to have porridge with the leftover spicy miso broth and it was amazing.
The waitress put in two bowls of rice into the leftover broth, turned the heat up, let it cook for a couple minutes, and slowly started taking some of the broth out
so it wouldn't be soupy.
She also added a scrambled egg, green onions and seaweed.
My friend & I were pleasantly surprised at how amazingly delicious this was.
However, I would most likely not return to Nabe for shabu.
I'd return to try the sukiyaki and to have the porridge, but that's it.
shabu shabu.author: Victoria H.
shabu shabu.review:
My friend & I came to Nabe to try their shabu shabu. I ordered the regular sized ($19) shabu shabu with kurobuta pork with spicy miso broth. The order came with napa cabbage, spinach, pumpkin, shiitake mushrooms, tofu, udon, shimeji mushrooms, carrots, and a plate of kurobuta pork. The only difference between the regular and large size shabu is the amount of meat that is provided. 

The shabu shabu itself was average. I have had much better shabu elsewhere. However, after our meal, we were offered to have porridge with the leftover spicy miso broth and it was amazing. The waitress put in two bowls of rice into the leftover broth, turned the heat up, let it cook for a couple minutes, and slowly started taking some of the broth out so it wouldn't be soupy. She also added a scrambled egg, green onions and seaweed. My friend & I were pleasantly surprised at how amazingly delicious this was. However, I would most likely not return to Nabe for shabu. I'd return to try the sukiyaki and to have the porridge, but that's it.

excerpts: I like Duck and Shabu Shabu (beef), plenty of vegetables and the meat
are pretty fresh.
A bowl of rice comes with the pot.
The Zosui (they use one of the soup base you have in your party to make porridge with eggs, rice, nori (seaweed) and green onions) is my absolutely favorite!
I probably look forward to the zosui more than than the hotpot itself :3.

If you think sharing someone else's pot base is disgusting or not sanitizing, just remember to set up rules beforehand to use extra set of chopsticks or the end of the chopsticks when putting food in/out of the pot?
It is really delicious and you are missing out of not having it!!!
shabu shabu.author: Ya K.
shabu shabu.review:
Come early or make reservation (no need to be days ahead, maybe just when they open), it is a pretty small place, so it does fills up pretty quickly, and the wait is usually longer!

I like Duck and Shabu Shabu (beef), plenty of vegetables and the meat are pretty fresh. A bowl of rice comes with the pot. 
The Zosui (they use one of the soup base you have in your party to make porridge with eggs, rice, nori (seaweed) and green onions) is my absolutely favorite! I probably look forward to the zosui more than than the hotpot itself :3. If you think sharing someone else's pot base is disgusting or not sanitizing, just remember to set up rules beforehand to use extra set of chopsticks or the end of the chopsticks when putting food in/out of the pot? It is really delicious and you are missing out of not having it!!! If you just don't like porridge, nevermind then :p

Some people might think the portion is kind of small, but remember to save your stomach space for the Zosui in the end!!! Also good with big group (just reserve ahead).

excerpts: Very good and affordable shabu shabu.
Don't consume all your broth they will come at the end to make a preparation with an egg some rice and some spices!
It is delicious!
shabu shabu.author: Sara-Fleur S.
shabu shabu.review: Very good and affordable shabu shabu. Don't consume all your broth they will come at the end to make a preparation with an egg some rice and some spices! It is delicious!

excerpts: I've gotten the shabu shabu wagyu beef with miso broth-
so yummy dipped in the citrusy ponzu sauce.
The veggies are nice but the main attraction was certainly the beef.
My bf ordered the kombu broth once
but we felt it was not nearly flavorful enough to spend $25 on (though I suppose it's the more traditional option).
The service is also great, the women who work there are super helpful and friendly.
The restaurant is quite small and the glass doors get steamy from all the hot pots but that just gives it a nice intimate aesthetic.
You should expect long waits of 45 minutes (unless you call ahead) but there's a nice brewery across the street to help kill time.
One of my fav places in SF!
shabu shabu.author: Delaney B.
shabu shabu.review: Mmmmm- love this place, such a treat! Both of the times I've gone I've gotten the shabu shabu wagyu beef with miso broth- so yummy dipped in the citrusy ponzu sauce. The veggies are nice but the main attraction was certainly the beef. My bf ordered the kombu broth once but we felt it was not nearly flavorful enough to spend $25 on (though I suppose it's the more traditional option). The service is also great, the women who work there are super helpful and friendly. The restaurant is quite small and the glass doors get steamy from all the hot pots but that just gives it a nice intimate aesthetic. You should expect long waits of 45 minutes (unless you call ahead) but there's a nice brewery across the street to help kill time. One of my fav places in SF!

excerpts: The food was tasty, we went with the Nabe shabu shabu, and traditional kombu style.
The meat was sliced perfectly, vegetables were fresh.
The crowd is mostly College students, but not super rowdy, just very energetic.
Will be returning try another great dinner.
And looking forward to the opening of the marina location.
shabu shabu.author: Ari T.
shabu shabu.review:
Had such a great experience, went with my grandparents around 9:30 was able to get a reservation, while driving to the restaurant. The interior decoration was great, very japanese with an underlying  San Franciscan vibe. The location is great as well, the cool weather will always put you in a soup mood. The food was tasty, we went with the Nabe shabu shabu, and traditional kombu style. The meat was sliced perfectly, vegetables were fresh. The crowd is mostly College students, but not super rowdy, just very energetic. Will be returning try another great dinner.
And looking forward to the opening of the marina location.

excerpts: I tried the vegetarian shabu shabu, which was delicious.
They convert your leftovers into a porridge at the end too!
shabu shabu.author: Riccha T.
shabu shabu.review: Excellent service. I tried the vegetarian shabu shabu, which was delicious. They convert your leftovers into a porridge at the end too!

excerpts: Got the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU (miso) sets.
Great customer service and very sweet and knowledgeable servers.
Love the spicy drops that they have and the drops are NO joke.
Really, you only need one or two drops in your pot (it has ghost peppers)
shabu shabu.author: Karen C.
shabu shabu.review:
First time at Nabu ! 
Got the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU (miso) sets. Great customer service and very sweet and knowledgeable servers. Love the spicy drops that they have and the drops are NO joke. Really, you only need one or two drops in your pot (it has ghost peppers) and you're set! 

I especially love that they take your left over broth and make it into a rice porridge!

excerpts: I've tried the Sukiyaki and Shabu Shabu flavors,.
Both are good
but I prefer the Sukiyaki.
shabu shabu.author: Corinna T.
shabu shabu.review:
I've had my fair share of hotpot, and after coming here twice, Nabe would only hover near the middle of the list. While service is great, and the interior is classy, sophisticated, and beautiful, I always leave still feeling hungry. The first time I came, I shared a large pot with my friend, and the second time, I shared 2 pots with 3 friends. Next time, if I come back, I will get my own. 

I've tried the Sukiyaki and Shabu Shabu flavors,. Both are good but I prefer the Sukiyaki. At the end of the meal, they make a pretty good rice porridge with your leftover soup, adding egg, green onion, and rice.

Overall, good food, just pricey for the portion size.

excerpts: The meat was of high quality and the portion size for the veggies was generous for a Japanese shabu shabu place.
My side of the pot took quite some time to heat up since all of the veggies had already been dumped into the broth.
I think the Spicy Miso broth was better tasting the Sukiyaki broth.
I really enjoyed the rice porridge that was made using the leftover Spicy Miso broth at the end.
shabu shabu.author: Yi Z.
shabu shabu.review:
Checked out Nabe with my Babe (oh, never mind, I realized that doesn't rhyme and I don't think my friend likes it when I make advances on her).

It was Saturday night and we were hungry. I wasn't in the mood to go to an ultra trendy restaurant in the Mission or wherever they are these days. Who has the time to wait in line for 2 hours? Nabe seemed like great comfort food for a cool SF evening. 

We were able to score free street parking easily and were seated right away. We thought that the free filtered water was awesome and it was brought out in pretty frosted glass bottles (I know, it's a random observation).

Anyway, I ordered the Sukiyaki with beef and my date for the evening ordered the Spicy Miso broth with Kurobuta Pork. The meat was of high quality and the portion size for the veggies was generous for a Japanese shabu shabu place. My side of the pot took quite some time to heat up since all of the veggies had already been dumped into the broth. I think the Spicy Miso broth was better tasting the Sukiyaki broth. I really enjoyed the rice porridge that was made using the leftover Spicy Miso broth at the end. That was probably the best part of the entire meal.

I also really enjoyed eavesdropping on the people behind us who were on a first date. The girl giggled so much and the guy seemed to be having a good time. I wonder if they are going on a second date.

excerpts: Between two of us we shared a large shabu shabu ($16) and a cold tofu appetizer ($5).
The pork quality was good, and amount of veggies and noodles definitely filled us.
The soup was bland in the beginning but obviously cooking the meats and veggies kicked it up a notch.
The cold tofu was very refreshing but not a must-order.
shabu shabu.author: Maggie G.
shabu shabu.review:
Food: 3.5 stars
Service: 4 stars

The zosui at the end tipped my rating from 3.5 to 4 stars! The rice porridge is hot and soaked up all the flavor from our meat/spicy miso. Yum. We almost didn't try it but sooo glad we did because the nori (seaweed) they add on top make the zosui quite outstanding.

Between two of us we shared a large shabu shabu ($16) and a cold tofu appetizer ($5). The pork quality was good, and amount of veggies and noodles definitely filled us. The soup was bland in the beginning but obviously cooking the meats and veggies kicked it up a notch. The cold tofu was very refreshing but not a must-order. Overall, great place with cool decor, it's a reliable lunch/dinner place that won't disappoint!

First thing walking in we both took a step back at how stuffy and hot it was. But I asked the waiter for AC and she turned it on immediately. During the time we were there she was very responsive and friendly. Tipped her 20% and I usually don't do that :P

excerpts: The Sukiyaki comes with everything u would expect from shabu shabu, but with thinly sliced marbled pieces of beef.
They also supply you with an egg for dipping the meat in to make it more silky.
The Kinoko nabe comes with mushrooms and ramen.
Both broths were very flavorful.
shabu shabu.author: Victor L.
shabu shabu.review:
The GF and I came here on a Monday night.  I have passed by here before and seen it being very busy.  It was pretty late when we got here, which explains why there were only four other tables occupied.  We looked at the menu and decided to get the Sukiyaki and the Kinoko nabe.  The Sukiyaki comes with everything u would expect from shabu shabu, but with thinly sliced marbled pieces of beef.  They also supply you with an egg for dipping the meat in to make it more silky.  The Kinoko nabe comes with mushrooms and ramen.  Both broths were very flavorful.  I liked the Sukiyaki a little better though because it is more traditional.  

The vegetables and other ingredients are already placed in the pot.  This has its pros and cons.  For example, stuff that you do not like is automatically cooking inside the pot.  Although, one does not really have to worry about overcooking tofu or mushrooms, the vegetables may get soggy in this manner.  Pros are that you can get whatever you want at once because they will have all cooked at the same time!  

After you are done eating, they prepare a type of rice soup.  They ask you what type of broth you want the rice soup to be made in.  Then, they bring out green onions, egg, seaweed, and of course rice.  They add the rice into the broth.  Then they slowly drain the broth until the rice is clearly visible under the broth.  After that, the egg and green onions are stirred into the equation.  Then, this creation is put into bowls and topped with seaweed.  This was definitely my favorite part of the meal.  Dinner and a show?  Awesome.  

We were so full after the meal.  However, we had to make room for dessert.  Their special is the butter mochi, which is made in house.  I could definitely tell they were proud of it because they asked us what we thought of it.  It was really delicious.  Imagine a warm mochi that melts in your mouth.  It is served with ice cream of your choice.  The GF loves black sesame, and it paired great with the mochi.  NomZ.  

Service A 
Food A
Environment A (ventilation was very good)

excerpts: I love the shabu shabu here.
Its a step in quality and execution than the best AYCE shabu places in SF.
You get what you pay for and I think prices are fair.
They make a rice pourridge at the end of the meal which is very tasty.
The gyoza is excellent here too.
I have only positive things to say about this place
and I always enjoy coming here.
shabu shabu.author: Adam M.
shabu shabu.review: I love the shabu shabu here. Its a step in quality and execution than the best AYCE shabu places in SF. You get what you pay for and I think prices are fair. They make a rice pourridge at the end of the meal which is very tasty. The gyoza is excellent here too. I have only positive things to say about this place and I always enjoy coming here.

excerpts: A different take on Shabu Shabu.
Yes, its basically the same formula, thinly sliced pieces of high quality beef, served with a selection of vegetables, selection of noodles and selection of broth.
shabu shabu.author: Tony L.
shabu shabu.review:
A different take on Shabu Shabu. Yes, its basically the same formula, thinly sliced pieces of high quality beef, served with a selection of vegetables, selection of noodles and selection of broth. Yes, they have suggested sets, but you can really customize anything and everything. 

Their claim to fame is that they use organic and locally sourced ingredients. The service was attentive and efficient. The deco is trendy, but the dining area is small. There are only 3 or 4 private tables with two long communal style tables in the middle. 

Call and make a reservation if you want to eat at a decent hour for dinner.

excerpts:
JAPANESE SHABU SHABU
(4 stars)

Simple evening, nothing fancy, just a big ass boiling pot of goodness.
The sausages were appetizer size, very very tasty, and it's worth getting to eat while the Shabu Shabu is warming up.
Dip the raw Wagyu beef in the raw egg first, then the Shabu Shabu, then the fabulous dipping sauce...
So good!!!
Japanese people and their raw eggs rock my socks!!!
The sukiyaki is a savory and sweet broth, gives the beef a nice coating of both.
It was good but rather keep Shabu Shabu
shabu shabu.author: Jane A.
shabu shabu.review:
JAPANESE SHABU SHABU
(4 stars)

Simple evening, nothing fancy, just a big ass boiling pot of goodness. Start with an appetite, leave with a mini gut. 

-FOOD, very good 
-PRICES, decent
-SERVICE, good
-AMBIANCE, small and chic

Been wanting to come here for months. Had reservations for 2 at 7pm. Packed but thank god for reservations. Make reservations or you'll be sitting outside for awhile. THE WALL OF SAKE BOTTLES amaze me, it's like a Sake fountain... It's not decor. Place is small and steams up like a sauna and the glass walls steam up. We decided to do two broths at regular size to taste as much as we can. 

HEFER STATS. 

KUROBUTA SAUSAGE ($5) - with mustard aioli. Comes with four sausages. The sausages were appetizer size, very very tasty, and it's worth getting to eat while the Shabu Shabu is warming up.

SUKIYAKI ($19/reg) - Wagyu beef, shirataki with warishita broth. They give you a raw egg and this fabulous dipping sauce for the Wagyu. Dip the raw Wagyu beef in the raw egg first, then the Shabu Shabu, then the fabulous dipping sauce... So good!!! Japanese people and their raw eggs rock my socks!!! The sukiyaki is a savory and sweet broth, gives the beef a nice coating of both. The only thing I hate toward the end of the meal all the veggies become mushy cause of the hotpot cooking all that time. 

SEAFOOD YASENABE ($19) - shrimp, salmon, scallops, and clams. Harusami with dashi broth. We chose a seafood since we already had meats. This is perfect for seafood lovers. All the seafood boiling in the broth married each item and it tasted good. I am not much of a seafood broth person, I love seafood but when seafood mix together in soup the taste then becomes too seafoodish - I'm weird. It was good but rather keep Shabu Shabu all meats/pork if possible. 

SURPRISE!!! When you think you're full, they come out asking which broth you liked more and make a porridge out of the leftover broth (trust, you will have left over broth). We chose the Sukiyaki. They mix rice and green union in the pot and explain what they are doing, then pour it in a bowl for you and top it off with seaweed garnish. So good yet so filling. You can pack it up if you like.

BUTTER CAKE AND SESAME ICECREAM - they don't feature their desserts on the menu. They have a few items and an assortment of icecream. I must always end a good meal with dessert, that's just me. Full or not!!! I got to choose so I selected the butter cake and paired it with sesame icecream because the other choices would make it sweet on top of sweet. Two lite butter cakes were the consistency of light pound cake. Ice cream taste exactly as it sounds. 

Will I be back? Yup!

Until the next review.....

excerpts: Shabu shabu on a cold San Francisco night is the best.
We came on a Monday night and were seated promptly.
We ordered the wagyu beef shabu shabu with traditional broth and the seafood platter.
I ordered the large plate for an extra few ounces of beef.
shabu shabu.author: Calvin C.
shabu shabu.review: Shabu shabu on a cold San Francisco night is the best. We came on a Monday night and were seated promptly. We ordered the wagyu beef shabu shabu with traditional broth and the seafood platter.  I ordered the large plate for an extra few ounces of beef. With the vegetable plate and ramen (which we subbed for the udon), this was a huge amount of food. They have the electric stoves on the table and they were well taken care of as the broth almost immediately boiled once they brought the pots of soup to the table. Remember to keep some rice as they take the rice and make a porridge out of the leftover soup. Best part of the meal and it made a fantastic breakfast the next day as there was tons of porridge. Fantastic meal and I definitely want to come back

excerpts: Shabu shabu makes the world a better place.

SHABU SHABU
-We always go for the half pot Spicy Miso Broth (Shabu Shabu order) and half pot Warishita broth (Sukiyaki order)
-Meat
platters come in two sizes: Regular or Large.
The prices vary depending on which type of meat.
For this outing we ended up ordering a large Sukiyaki wagyu beef order and a regular Shabu Shabu kurabuta pork plate.
-TIP: After you finish your shabu shabu meal, there is actually a FINISHER!
The waiter will bring out rice and use your leftover broth to make a rice soup.
The spicy miso broth rice soup finisher is amazing.
They add an egg, green onions, and a little bit of seaweed.

PROS/TIPS
-Complimentary rice soup finisher after your Shabu Shabu meal!
It always hits the spot if you're still a little hungry after your Shabu Shabu!
-Ask for iced water
when you get in - most people ask for tea but after you get your Shabu Shabu... you'll want cold water.
-Keep your broth hot after you're done with your Shabu Shabu
and you're ready for the finisher - otherwise it'll take extra time to reheat the broth and make the finisher.
Overall delicious :) happy happy shabu shabu!
shabu shabu.author: Grace J.
shabu shabu.review:
Shabu shabu makes the world a better place. Especially if you are sick and it is cold outside. 

SETTING
-Nabe is in a busy part of Inner Sunset - right between Irving and Judah on 9th Ave.
-Glass doors and walls so you can look right into the restaurant, unless it's around dinner when the inside is so hot that the glass gets fogged up! 
-They have a few tables for parties of 4 or smaller, and then a long table that stretches in the middle of the restaurant for pairs or larger groups. 
-If it's a full house they do have a wait list you can put your name on. You can wait inside or wander about outside and they'll give you a call. 
-Service gets a little bit slow when things get crowded.

SHABU SHABU
-We always go for the half pot Spicy Miso Broth (Shabu Shabu order) and half pot Warishita broth (Sukiyaki order)
-Meat platters come in two sizes: Regular or Large. The prices vary depending on which type of meat. For this outing we ended up ordering a large Sukiyaki wagyu beef order and a regular Shabu Shabu kurabuta pork plate.
-Each order comes with a plate of assorted vegetables and other condiments: tofu, cabbage, enoki mushroom, carrot, udon noodles, shiitake mushroom, kabocha squash, etc. 
-TIP: After you finish your shabu shabu meal, there is actually a FINISHER! The waiter will bring out rice and use your leftover broth to make a rice soup. The spicy miso broth rice soup finisher is amazing. They add an egg, green onions, and a little bit of seaweed. It takes about 10 minutes to prepare if your broth is still hot. 

PROS/TIPS
-Complimentary rice soup finisher after your Shabu Shabu meal! It always hits the spot if you're still a little hungry after your Shabu Shabu!
-Ask for iced water when you get in - most people ask for tea but after you get your Shabu Shabu... you'll want cold water.
-Keep your broth hot after you're done with your Shabu Shabu and you're ready for the finisher - otherwise it'll take extra time to reheat the broth and make the finisher. Since it's time intensive you could end up waiting for awhile. 

Overall delicious :) happy happy shabu shabu!

excerpts: The menu is pretty straightforward, and we both chose the Shabu Shabu with spicy miso and Wagyu beef ($19 for the regular).
If your table chooses different soups, they'll give you a split pot.
The veggie plate gets bonus points from me because it had kabocha, a sort of pumpkin!
The beef was beautifully cut into squares and looked very pretty.
The soup was more spicy than miso, so eh.
The boyfriend and I were pretty disappointed with the ponzu sauce; they give it to you already mixed with Daikon and garlic, and it's just too...
Pickled tasting.
We both barely touched it.
Nabe is probably the closest to traditional shabu shabu I've had, but the spicy miso just didn't do it for me.
While I'd definitely come back purely for the zotsui (and maybe try the kimchi soup), I'm probably gunna stick with Shabu House, where I love the spicy miso and you get to mix up your own ponzu.
shabu shabu.author: Doris K.
shabu shabu.review:
The boyfriend and I swung by on a Tuesday night at 7:15-30 and were seated immediately. There were two other open tables, so I guess we came at a good time. We sat in the middle section of the long table, and though the restaurant is small, the way they have the tables set up doesn't make you feel cramped. But then again, there's only two of us. The atmosphere is very modern, with the sake bottle wall and the white tables contrasted with the grey wall paint. They also use wooden bowls and spoons, which gives the meal itself a more traditional feel I suppose. 

The menu is pretty straightforward, and we both chose the Shabu Shabu with spicy miso and Wagyu beef ($19 for the regular). If your table chooses different soups, they'll give you a split pot. The veggie plate gets bonus points from me because it had kabocha, a sort of pumpkin! The beef was beautifully cut into squares and looked very pretty. The soup was more spicy than miso, so eh. The boyfriend and I were pretty disappointed with the ponzu sauce; they give it to you already mixed with Daikon and garlic, and it's just too... Pickled tasting. We both barely touched it. They also don't offer chili oil, garlic, Daikin, or any of that at the table. 

The BEST part of the meal had to be the zotsui, rice porridge, at the end of the meal. The waitress takes your leftover soup, mixes in some rice and an egg, and let's it sit. Then she'll serve it with some green onions and seaweed. So. Damn. Good. And if you don't finish, you can take it home! Honestly, this was the main reason I wanted to come to Nabe. 

The servers were really great and friendly. When the place got packed, they slowed down a bit, but I can't blame them I guess. The waitress who made our zotsui for us explained every step, and asked to make sure it was okay to put in whatever ingredient was going next, which I think is great service. When the table next to us asked why one half of their pot wasn't boiling, she kindly told them it was because it had more stuff in it (duh). 

So what's my verdict? Nabe is probably the closest to traditional shabu shabu I've had, but the spicy miso just didn't do it for me. While I'd definitely come back purely for the zotsui (and maybe try the kimchi soup), I'm probably gunna stick with Shabu House, where I love the spicy miso and you get to mix up your own ponzu.

excerpts: My boyfriend got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef and spicy miso and I got the sukiyaki with wagyu beef.
Out of the two I personally liked the sukiyaki better.
The broth itself was sweet and tasted amazing after dipping your beef in it and then the raw egg they give you.
Portion wise they could have been more generous
but I understand since it's lunch time their portions are probably smaller than a dinner plate.
We both finished our meat in no time at all and had to order an additional plate of meat because we were still hungry.
shabu shabu.author: Linz C.
shabu shabu.review:
My boyfriend and I were craving shabu but with not very many shabu places opened for lunch yelp led us to Nabe.  I had heard a lot of good things about this place and always wanted to try it for their "after meal" where at the end they add rice and egg into your shabu broth and you get a rice porridge.  

We came about an hour before they closed and there was still quite a few people there.  My boyfriend got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef and spicy miso and I got the sukiyaki with wagyu beef.  Out of the two I personally liked the sukiyaki better. The broth itself was sweet and tasted amazing after dipping your beef in it and then the raw egg they give you. Portion wise they could have been more generous but I understand since it's lunch time their portions are probably smaller than a dinner plate.  We both finished our meat in no time at all and had to order an additional plate of meat because we were still hungry. The meat was good, soft and not frozen like many other places, and I loved the vegetable assortment, especially the variety if mushrooms and kabocha squash!

When we were all done the waitress have us the bill and I was thinking... "We don't get the rice and egg add ins?" So my boyfriend asked our waitress and she told us it was only during dinner that they do that.   Seeing the disappointment on my face the waitress was sooo kind and said she could bring us a bowl of rice and I could make it myself since my meal already came with a raw egg.  She ended up making the whole thing for us, adding the rice, taking out excess soup to make the rice to soup ratio even, stirring in the raw egg, and she went above and beyond and brought us the green onion and seaweed garnishes to put on top.  The customer service that we experienced was AMAZING and our waitress was really sweet.  And I'm glad we got to try the rice porridge because it was delicious!! 

I wouldn't mind coming back again but I prefer AYCE when doing hot pot or shabu.

excerpts: For our dinner set, we decided to share a large 50/50 pot ($24) of Sukiyaki and Shabu Shabu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#MhOerOo7cXe4vkZrU31rww).
The SUKIYAKI side came with a Warishita broth and a plate of Wagyu Beef.
Although it was a little light and sweeter than what I would normally go for, it balanced out the rest of the meal pretty well.
On the SHABU SHABU side, we went with the Spicy Miso broth over their traditional Kombu and opted for the Kurobuta Pork over getting more beef.
Between its more savory flavor and slight kick, I thought the Spicy Miso was the better of the two we had.
shabu shabu.author: Mike L.
shabu shabu.review:
Considering where it is (9th Ave), how long they've been open (it's been a while), the food (it's pretty good), and the fact that it's shabu (shabu!), I'm really surprised Nabe only has 109 reviews.  I mean, TPumps probably had that many after two weeks and they aren't nearly as good!  Granted, there's a slight difference in what they serve, but still!

Unlike other shabu joints, Nabe doesn't offer an AYCE option (which might be why they get less traffic).  However, the menu does offer several appetizers and Nabemono sets, which each include a plate of meat and vegetables (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#jAuLiyN-WUPGbLsAKTkbbA).  To start our meal, the three of us shared an order of the KUROBUTA GYOZA ($7).  The filling was pretty tasty and I liked the accompanying chili sauce, but I thought the skin could have used a harder crust (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#S79V2u3V_0n3JhZSB02q6A).

For our dinner set, we decided to share a large 50/50 pot ($24) of Sukiyaki and Shabu Shabu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#MhOerOo7cXe4vkZrU31rww).  The SUKIYAKI side came with a Warishita broth and a plate of Wagyu Beef.  Although it was a little light and sweeter than what I would normally go for, it balanced out the rest of the meal pretty well.  Not mind blowing, but solid.

On the SHABU SHABU side, we went with the Spicy Miso broth over their traditional Kombu and opted for the Kurobuta Pork over getting more beef.  Between its more savory flavor and slight kick, I thought the Spicy Miso was the better of the two we had.  Can't argue with the Kurobuta Pork either!  So good (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#J3qUCdFHz-k2gbf5qREluw).

To cap off the meal, we were served Nabe's signature Zosui rice soup (I don't know of any other place in SF that does it).  Utilizing the remainder of our Spicy Miso broth, our server mixed in an egg, rice, green onions, and nori to create a delicious jook-like soup.  Although it was a little salty, it was delicious!  Almost made us wish we had left more of the meat and veggies in the pot (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#Xy2B_bzJWTb2zn2AVA2bLw).

Despite the fact they won't replace Shabu House as my favorite spot for shabu in SF (or anywhere), Nabe is more than a sufficient alternative to mix things up a bit.  Not I hope Nabe doesn't get TOO busy in the future...

excerpts: I came to this location with my boyfriend as we were craving some shabu shabu.
Luckily there was parking right outside the restaurant
and it was a minute away from the location.
When we walked into the location it was very stuffy and there were a few tables occupied.
There were three servers that were very friendly and helpful.
We looked at the menu and ordered a set which included Wagyu beef.
We added a couple of additional items as we were sharing these the set together.
We got the spicy miso soup-
I suggest ordering the regular miso soup instead of the spicy as you can always add spicy and not the other way around.
shabu shabu.author: Amy Y.
shabu shabu.review: I came to this location with my boyfriend as we were craving some shabu shabu. Luckily there was parking right outside the restaurant and it was a minute away from the location. When we walked into the location it was very stuffy and there were a few tables occupied. There were three servers that were very friendly and helpful. We looked at the menu and ordered a set which included Wagyu beef. We added a couple of additional items as we were sharing these the set together. We got the spicy miso soup- I suggest ordering the regular miso soup instead of the spicy as you can always add spicy and not the other way around. The set comes with a vegetable plate that includes some udon, mushroom, spinach, squash etc. The service was okay, when we got there, the employees were eating their dinner too. They failed to tell us it was last call time, so we ended up not being able to order anything. Instead we just ordered this mochi cake with ice cream. The waitress suggest that we order the roasted black sesame ice cream. It was good to try but I wouldn't say that I crave their ice cream or shabu. I suggest trying this shabu place as the decor and utensils are fun, and it could be a nice fun first date, but I don't think this is my go to. The mochi cake was not very tasty, there was definitely a lack of sugar and butter. It needs to be softer, more moist, and definitely sweeter.

excerpts: Nabe is Japanese style shabu shabu, so don't come here if you're expecting Taiwanese hot pot.
I looooove shabu shabu
and I think Nabe does a pretty good job.
They offer nabemono sets that come with your choice of a broth and a predetermined set of veggies.
You can go ala carte too
but I think the sets are where it's at.
I got the sukiyaki broth and my friends got the miso.
I love sukiyaki and this was exactly what I was craving...
it's on the sweeter side.
Don't forget to dip your meat in the raw egg!
Their ponzu sauce and sesame sauce are also AMAZING.
I started to just eat then on their own with my rice.
The Wagyu beef it came with was thinly sliced, very good quality and it was accompanied with assorted veggies + shirataki (yam) noodles.
Our meal was ended with the zosui (rice porridge) made from the miso broth + green onions and nori (seaweed).
shabu shabu.author: Sara S.
shabu shabu.review:
Nabe is Japanese style shabu shabu, so don't come here if you're expecting Taiwanese hot pot. It's different! 

This is a pretty small and cozy joint so I would recommend making reservations like we did. The decor is cool with the sake bottles hanging on the walls. I looooove shabu shabu and I think Nabe does a pretty good job. They offer nabemono sets that come with your choice of a broth and a predetermined set of veggies. You can go ala carte too but I think the sets are where it's at. I got the sukiyaki broth and my friends got the miso. I love sukiyaki and this was exactly what I was craving... it's on the sweeter side. Don't forget to dip your meat in the raw egg! Their ponzu sauce and sesame sauce are also AMAZING. I started to just eat then on their own with my rice. The Wagyu beef it came with was thinly sliced, very good quality and it was accompanied with assorted veggies + shirataki (yam) noodles. Our meal was ended with the zosui (rice porridge) made from the miso broth + green onions and nori (seaweed). It was really flavorful because the broth was so concentrated at that point so it could've been overpowering to some, but I enjoyed it. 

It came out to around $20/person without tax or tip so it is a little more expensive. That was with each of us ordering our own regular order and that was more than enough for me. You could try to order a large and share with 2 people if you have a smaller appetite. I just think shabu is less salty than hot pot which I like, but if you want AYCE or more options, you should probably look elsewhere. 

 I really have no qualms about this place, so 5 stars it is!

excerpts: Amazing shabu shabu and love the interior as well!
Will come back for sure!
shabu shabu.author: Sarah B.
shabu shabu.review: Great service! Amazing shabu shabu and love the interior as well! Will come back for sure!

excerpts: Modern and clean for a shabu shabu restaurant, which is probably why it's slightly pricier than your usual AYCE hotpot joint in the city.
shabu shabu.author: Catherine C.
shabu shabu.review:
Modern and clean for a shabu shabu restaurant, which is probably why it's slightly pricier than your usual AYCE hotpot joint in the city.

My go-to: Wagu Beef with spicy miso soup.

excerpts: Of course there are "shabu shabu" places, but rarely do you get the genuinely authentic flavors as nabe is supposed to be in Japan.
shabu shabu.author: Sherry L.
shabu shabu.review:
I'll admit, I was a huge skeptic of this place until I actually ate here. Nabe is still a relatively new genre in Japanese cuisine in the US. Of course there are "shabu shabu" places, but rarely do you get the genuinely authentic flavors as nabe is supposed to be in Japan.

We got two large ones to share between 3 people, even though the waitress tried to convince us to get 3. Really, there's no need for that. There are plenty of add-ons for you to, well, add on, to your order. I think you should get as many individual nabe as you want to taste different flavors.

We got the sukiyaki and seafood yosenabe. Both had different broths. And then we got a bunch of add-ons: veggie plate, shiitake mushrooms, tofu, shungiku. You can also get additional meat and seafood, but I think veggies are essential to nabe, because they impart so much flavor to nabe.

So the way you're supposed to do this is let the nabe boil. Then start eating the meat. For sukiyaki, they give you a raw egg as a "wash" after you cook the meat in the nabe. Since the meat is cut so thinly, you only really need to put it in the boiling broth for a few seconds. And because it's so hot, you dip it in the egg wash and then eat. Let me tell you, the egg makes a world of difference - not only to calm the temperature down, but all add flavor and texture. The meat tastes so much better with the egg.

As you continue to eat, you might want to bring down the temperature of the heating pad a little if you're not eating meat. Add some veggies and wait for them to be ready. Eat the veggies and then eat more meat. Repeat until you don't have anything but broth.

Signal your server and she'll bring rice over to make zosui. This is an amazing end of the meal extra. Because you've added so much meat and veggies to the broth, the broth is rich with extra flavor that it didn't start with. When you add the rice, it becomes a heavenly porridge. No need to get noodles or other carbs as an add-on. The end of the meal zosui comes with your meal already. It's so much better than noodles because the rice absorbs the broth and all that good flavor.

Hot pots are one of my favorite food genres because it can be so flavorful... and FUN TO EAT! Definitely come to Nabe if you like hot pots. You'll be in for an adventure!

Notes

*They should play some music, Japanese jazz? Nujabes anyone?

*I wonder if modern places like this are going to start the next trend in Shabu?

shabu shabu.author: Priscilla W.
shabu shabu.review:
Nabe is the new, popular Japanese hot pot restaurant in the Inner Sunset. They have an inadequate ventilation system, so the front windows are usually covered with steam; it's no surprise if you overlook this restaurant while walking along 9th Avenue. However, the restaurant's name, displayed cleverly with a bold, blue neon lighting against the black exterior, is easily seen across the street, up to half a block away. It's like your calling to come in on a cold day for some yummy Japanese-style comfort food.

We tried Nabe a few Saturdays ago for an early dinner around 6PM. As newbies, the menu was a little confusing at first. But our server, Nhu, was very helpful explaining how everything worked. Basically, the nabemono sets are portioned per person. They come with the meat, noodles, and vegetables in the broth, all already in a large pot. That pot is brought to your table stove to cook. However, there is one shabu shabu set (beef or pork for choice of meat), which is the only nabemono set that doesn't have the ingredients already in the pot. In other words, you cook it yourself at the table.

We shared the beef and pork shabu shabu and opted for one regular miso broth and one spicy miso broth (traditional kombu (kelp) in water was the other option for shabu shabu broth). I definitely preferred the beef over the pork. Both meats were very fresh and delicious, but the beef was flavorful on its own that sauce wasn't necessary. Vegetables were fresh and abundant. You're given a generous helping of spinach, cabbage, shiitake and enoki mushrooms, carrots, tofu and kabocha squash. The miso broth was very mild, and the spicy miso definitely had some heat.

I love the idea of using leftover broth for rice porridge, so you're not wasting the broth. The waitress comes over to make it for you. That Saturday night we went, there were only three waitresses in the restaurant, so I give our server credit for doing so much, shuffling back and forth to other tables but still tending to ours. The broth is usually concentrated after your meal, so you can ask for them to dilute it. The rice porridge is a perfect compliment at the end of our meal, keeping us warm before we leave the restaurant and endure the cold night.

Nabe is a relatively small restaurant. There's two long communal tables and three smaller 4-person tables. Not a lot of walking room either. Without a reservation, come in by or before 6PM on weekends to guarantee no lines.

shabu shabu.author: Cherylynn N.
shabu shabu.review:
4.5 STARS

The Winter Blues.

For 60 hours, I didn't leave the house much less leave my bed (too bad it wasn't one of those "marathon" sessions). I don't/can't sleep so all I did was watch awesomely terrible Lifetime movies and eat Tyson buffalo wings and Kimchi ramen bowls.

Nothing was going to get me to leave the house. Nothing.

That was until I heard there was a new shabu joint that opened in The Sets.

*Furiously grabs baby wipes and sprays dry shampoo all over*

Hey, don't judge. 

My friends and I came to Nabe on Friday night with reservations. Thankfully, we made reservations because it was packed.

F O O D
Nabe offers Nabemono shabu set meals with additional a la carte meat and seafood options. No AYCE is available. All ingredients are organic and locally sourced. No MSG is used in any of the broths.

Each shabu set is paired with a specific broth that will best complement the type of meat. 

*Sukiyaki: Washugyu Beef with Warishita Broth
*Kinaka Nabe: Assorted Japanese Mushrooms in Miso Broth
*Kimchi & Kurobuta Pork Belly: Pork Belly with Kimchi Miso Broth
*Shabu Shabu with Traditional Konbu or Spicy Miso Broth
*Seafood Yosenabe: Shrimp, Salmon, Scallops, and Asari Clams in Dashi Broth

You have a choice of Regular ($18 for 8oz) or Large ($22 for 12oz); more for the seafood option. A veggie platter with udon noodles is included with each set.

Our group's Nabemono Sukiyaki & Shabu Shabu Sets: http://bit.ly/UEmCVg

My pick was the traditional konbu which is clear broth with seaweed (http://bit.ly/UEmQvI). There's not much flavoring to it but it allows you to enjoy the natural beefiness of the well-marbled washugyu beef (http://bit.ly/UEmZz3). The accompanying sesame paste with bonito and ponzu sauce were deliciously mouth-watering and full of umami flavors (http://bit.ly/UEn7yK).

However, when I got a taste of Mr. NSS' Warishita broth (Sukiyaki set), I was in shabu heaven (http://bit.ly/UEndGE). The delicious broth imparted a savory sweetness into the beef that was addicting that I abandoned my own pot. I loved the accompanying raw egg that added a layer of creaminess.

Saving the best for last is the Zosui. After your broth has been well-seasoned from the meat swishing, they add, rice, egg, nori and green onions to your broth to make a Japanese porridge (http://bit.ly/UEnh9o). The Zosui using the Warishita broth was so comforting and oh so good.

S E R V I C E
Friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable. Wendy, our waitress always had a smile on her face and did a good job explaining the Nabemono shabu concept to us thoroughly since it was new to us. I appreciated that they asked for feedback at the end of our meal. Always a good sign from new business owner(s). 

Service was a tad slow and it took awhile to get our broth pots but it was opening week and all.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
The swankiest shabu place in the city with minimalist black walls lined with wooden sake dispensers (http://bit.ly/UEnqcX). My only gripe is the place is small and tight (formerly Good Earth Cuisine) with just 2 communal tables and 3 small tables.

P A R K I N G
Good luck. Your best bet finding street parking is 2 blocks down on Lincoln near GG park.

With soul warmed and my tummy filled (ok, busting out from my spanx), I was glad I finally left the house to shabu my winter blues away!

excerpts: My PDC family ordered 2 regular sets: the SUKIYAKI (Washugyu beef with a sweet Warishita broth) and the SHABU SHABU (Washugyu beef or Kurobuta pork with either traditional konbu or spicy miso broth).

Our order came with 3 plates, one for each of the meats (15 slices of thinly sliced, beautifully marbled beef: http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZwBukC0KhMXJKbmaNfKPFw/l.jpg, forgot to take a picture of the pork, oops) and another for the combined vegetables and udon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oENOdFCIcUrOqzm1cSXdgg/l.jpg).
Since the sukiyaki set came with Washugyu beef, we opted for the Kurobota pork in spicy miso broth, per my big's recommendation.
When our pot came to our table, the vegetables were already swimming in it (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9Zp7qpP_MynVcMIw3wA0TQ/l.jpg).
This gave the scallions, mushrooms, tofu, cabbage, carrots, chrysanthemum leaves, and these spotted, slightly-crunchy, translucent noodles more time to cook.
Both the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU sets were fantastic, although I have a preference for the sukiyaki's broth and raw egg dip.
I liked both the beef and the pork, and the beef is exceptionally marbled.
And don't forget the Zosui rice porridge at the end!
shabu shabu.author: Adele F.
shabu shabu.review:
2 regular nabemono shabu sets shared among 3 people is more than enough, mostly due to the Zosui rice that they add to your broth after your hot-potting is done. It's like two meals in one!

A new hotpot restaurant in Inner Sunset that opened only 3 weeks ago? Hot damn! Cherylynn's review is so thorough that I don't need to bother with all the details. I just want to note that the nabemono sets include meat/seafood, noodles, and assorted vegetables paired with a broth. Your meal ends with a Zosui rice soup using the flavored broth from the cooking. Pricing is $18 per person for a regular portion, $22 per person for a large portion.

They also have a seasonal nabemono winter set called Kamonanban, which includes duck breast and Tokyo negi with Dashi broth, regular $23 and large $28.

Our group of 9 entered the restaurant around 5:30 PM without a reservation, and we were lucky to nab the long communal table in the back. The restaurant can only seat 32, so I would definitely recommend a reservation during normal dining hours. Service is good, with multiple waitresses running around checking on things, refilling water, and asking if the group is ready for the Zosui rice. However, the entire endeavor is a bit time-consuming given the ingredient preparation, table stove heating, and rice porridge finale. Our group was there for TWO HOURS. Crazy.

My PDC family ordered 2 regular sets: the SUKIYAKI (Washugyu beef with a sweet Warishita broth) and the SHABU SHABU (Washugyu beef or Kurobuta pork with either traditional konbu or spicy miso broth). Our order came with 3 plates, one for each of the meats (15 slices of thinly sliced, beautifully marbled beef: http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZwBukC0KhMXJKbmaNfKPFw/l.jpg, forgot to take a picture of the pork, oops) and another for the combined vegetables and udon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oENOdFCIcUrOqzm1cSXdgg/l.jpg). The vegetable/udon plate came with chopped cabbage, baby spinach leaves, a few slices of squash, two slabs of tofu, enoki mushrooms, a quartered shiitake mushroom, a few carrot pieces in cute shapes, and udon noodles. To be honest, I wish they gave more vegetables because spinach severely shrinks :(

Since the sukiyaki set came with Washugyu beef, we opted for the Kurobota pork in spicy miso broth, per my big's recommendation. When our pot came to our table, the vegetables were already swimming in it (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9Zp7qpP_MynVcMIw3wA0TQ/l.jpg). This gave the scallions, mushrooms, tofu, cabbage, carrots, chrysanthemum leaves, and these spotted, slightly-crunchy, translucent noodles more time to cook. We added the meats on par with our consumption; I enjoyed the beef and pork equally :)

Regarding the broths, I definitely preferred the sukiyaki's Warishita. The sweetened soy base adds subtle undertones to the hot pot ingredients, although the spicy miso adds that kick most people enjoy with their meat. The sukiyaki also comes with a raw egg that you crack into a bowl and dip your meat and vegetables in. So strange! I loved the added creaminess hehe. Screw Salmonella.

After all is eaten, a waitress scoops out some of your broth and adds in some rice to make this delicious porridge chock full of hot pot flavor. You can choose to split your rice between the two broths or have it half-half. We asked for half-half, and she let the rice sit for 5 or so minutes before returning to stir in the beaten egg, nori, and green onions. I definitely would vouch for the Warishita broth over the spicy miso broth because at the end of the stewing, the savoriness of the boiled ingredients blends harmoniously with the innate sweetness of the broth.

Max 4-way credit card split, and make sure to let them know before the ring things up. Also, they have one bathroom hidden behind a curtain. It has a weird sliding door...

All in all, I would recommend 2 regular nabemono sets to be shared among 3 people. Both the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU sets were fantastic, although I have a preference for the sukiyaki's broth and raw egg dip. I liked both the beef and the pork, and the beef is exceptionally marbled. And don't forget the Zosui rice porridge at the end! You're getting a real bang for your buck here ;)

Also, shout-out to the best family out there!

shabu shabu.author: Tara A.
shabu shabu.review:
I came to Nabe with reservations for my bff and I on a Saturday evening. We were a little late to our reservation at 6:30, but the waiter understood how terrible parking is around here (forrreal lol) and gave us the next available table. 

After yelping around I already knew I wanted the sukiyaki. I love sukiyaki broth because it's so sweet! My friend ended up going with miso broth shabu shabu (the waitress let us know they not only had spicy miso, but just miso as well). Our pot came and the sukiyaki vegetables and noodles were already in the soup pot that was being boiled. I didn't really mind, but it was definitely unconventional for me haha. The waitress came by and gave us our dipping sauce, and a raw egg for my sukiyaki. The dipping sauce (ponzu) here isn't really my taste.. It's too sour for me. My friend and I ended up asking for sesame/peanut sauce and thankfully, they had some! The only thing I didn't like about this place was that they don't give you a bowl of rice, and also I wish that the sukiyaki had the choice of the veggies already being in the pot, or given to you on a separate plate. The veggies were good though, they included lettuce, mushrooms, shirataki noodles, carrots, some greens I don't know the name of (looked like part of a spring mix lol) and pumpkin which I had never seen before at a shabu plate haha. 

The meat came out fairly quickly and it was very neat, cut into little squares. The meat portion is okay, but for $18 I would expect a little more. The meat was delicious though!!! Good quality and super tender. I've seen on different yelp reviews that you're supposed to dip the meat into the broth and cook it, then into the raw egg mix, and then into a dipping sauce of your choice. I did just that and o m g I fell in love!!! I've never had it like that before, but now I want to order a raw egg at every shabu/hot pot place i'm at haha. 

At the end of the meal we were told to pick one broth for the zosui, which is a "meal finisher" containing rice, egg, seaweed, and scallions. The waitress boiled our rice in the sukiyaki broth and took out some of the broth to even the ratio. Afterwards, she added in the scallions and poured the raw egg on top, and then finished it with the seaweed. My friend and I were really happy with the zosui!! Too bad we were so full that we couldn't finish it all.

I will definitely be back!! I'm not sure about dinner because of the hefty price tag, but lunch is very reasonable at $12/16 for regular/large! Although I know lunch doesn't include the zosui at the end. :(
