shabu shabu.author: Michelle Y.
shabu shabu.review:
My friend introduced me and now I can't stop going back. Nabe isn't an AYCE hot pot place but it does offer high quality meats and delicious soup bases for the same price. Unlike many of the Chinese hot pot restaurants in the area, Nabe serves Japanese-style shabu shabu. I love their spicy miso soup base and their wagyu beef is just amazing. I find their regular shabu shabu soup base a bit plain, but it could be just right for those who like a more clear broth with their hot pot. The porridge at the end is also quite awesome. They take the leftover soup and mix it with rice to give you a rice porridge. It tastes better with the more savory soup base so be sure to choose the soup of the friend with the more flavourful soup (it's one bowl per 2 people and the kimchi based soup base tastes best with the rice in my opinion). The only problem my friends and I have is that sometimes there's barely enough soup to mix with the rice cause we've used up so much of the soup to cook....

It does get quite cramped in the restaurant and you're relegated to waiting outside (even in the cold) for a table. The wait can be insane at times by the way,so be prepared.

Some might find this expensive compared to the AYCE hot pots in the area. However, for the food quality, I personally think that it's totally worth it and it's all based on your preference of volume or quality.

excerpts: but it's better with shabu shabu.
shabu shabu.author: Catherine C.
shabu shabu.review:
A friend brought me here for my birthday, and I've been back twice since then. The sukiyaki is my favorite and I would highly recommend their yam noodles. Their veggies are fresh and the meat looks relatively lean, and even though their portions don't look huge it's a lot of food. 

At the end of the hot pot there's a rice finisher that's really interesting. It involves slightly more than just dumping a bowl of rice into the left over soup. They let the rice simmer down into a porridge and then add some toppings. A little too salty with a sukiyaki base but it's better with shabu shabu. For dessert their most popular seems to be the mochi cake which is what it sounds like, a blend of mochi into a piece of cake. You can choose your own ice cream on the side. I've tried the green tea and black sesame and both were really good. 

Only downside to Nabe is that the service is a little slow. It was fine when we came for an early dinner but after 7pm it seems to fill up and it's difficult to catch the servers' attention. When you do have their attention though, you have their full attention and they are very pleasant. 

Overall Nabe is awesome for a cold SF day-- the food is really great and absolutely worth a try. Will definitely be back!

excerpts: The shabu shabu also comes with veggies such as napa cabbage, spinach, mushrooms, squash, and udon noodles.
shabu shabu.author: Denise C.
shabu shabu.review:
My bf and I came here on a rainy day, wanting some nice hot soup to warm us up. While Nabe did just that, it really was pretty average and honestly not making a special trip back.

First things first, Nabe is not AYCE shabu, which is why my bf and I came here in the first place. However, I'd say that going for AYCE shabu would probably be a better bet moneywise. All in all, after tax and tip, a large serving of shabu was at least $20. AYCE is not too much more than that, and you would get way more food.

That being said, the food was satisfying but nothing special. I was definitely disappointed with the serving size. My bf and I were ravenous, and I think without the bowl of rice and gyoza we ordered, we would have been hungry after. The meat itself looked like it was a good quality and the soup was tasty. The shabu shabu also comes with veggies such as napa cabbage, spinach, mushrooms, squash, and udon noodles.

Service was a little on the slow side considering how slow it was in the restaurant (we were one of two parties dining during lunch). However, there was only one waitress, so I guess I could understand. She was nice, but could have been a bit more attentive given the relative slowness of the time (she was in the back most of the time).

If you're from the city, you know how crazy parking can get around this area. Be prepared to round the block a few times and pull out a bunch of quarters.

Overall, not a bad place to eat, but not memorable either. I'd probably suggest an AYCE shabu place if a friend wanted to eat here.

shabu shabu.author: Abby C.
shabu shabu.review:
Overall: 4/5 
What can I say, I love my shabu shabu and this place really is delicious. The staff is attentive and friendly despite the fact of how busy it gets. What caught my eye is the special porridge that they make at the end with the leftovers from your broth. However, what wowed me was the sesame sauce that they had, it was perfection. I would definitely come back again, Nabe's porridge and sesame sauce has a place in my heart! 

I came here after I called in asking if there was a wait. Shabu house had over a hour wait and luckily, Nabe said they had a table for two! Unfortunately when we arrived, the table that they thought would leave was still sitting there and ordered another plate... So we had to wait for around 15 minutes before we could get seated. It wasn't the servers fault since we did only call in and of course no promises were made without an reservation. 

Once inside, the restaurant was TINY! There was a long table that ran down the middle of the restaurant with just a few tables on the side. I would've hated having to sit in the middle tables with a bunch of strangers all cramped up. Fortunately, my friend and I were seated in the tables on the side. But let's talk about the space (reason I took off a star)! There was barely any room for anyone to walk through and the servers had a hard time squeezing in between everyone as well. Also, I know the decor is simple and they want to keep it to a minimal given the size of the restaurant but I found it a by weird how no condiments were offered or set on the table.... 

I ordered the Shabu Shabu with the regular size Washugyu beef $19 (large $24.00) with traditional konbu (comes with a plate of veggies and udon). The traditional konbu is just water with seaweed so don't order it if you don't like a plain base! I like my broth plain so I could taste the real flavor of my beef and this was just right up my ally. But what came next was the sesame sauce and this was THE real game changer! I added this to my broth along with garlic and ahh, I was so in love!!! This sauce alone will make me come back and regarding the garlic, don't forget to ask for it or condiments because they don't have it set out nor do they mention it unless asked! 

Let's talk about that porridge though, so on point! Towards the end of the meal, a server will ask if you're ready for their porridge that is whipped up on the spot from one of your leftover broths. From there, the server will add a bowl of rice and set the heat to high. After a while, they will add some green onions, turn off the heat, and immediately mix it in with an egg. The end result is a nice, thick creamy consistency topped off with some shredded seaweed and voila, porridge is served! What an AMAZING and smart way to use up the remainder of the pot. Thank you Nabe for giving me such an amazing experience!

excerpts: My favorite dish is the Shabu Shabu spicy miso soup.
The Shabu Shabu option means the veggies come on the side, and the diner places the veggies in the broth when desired.
You can order extra meat or veggies

shabu shabu.author: S O.
shabu shabu.review:
The Nabe staff are the best. Yes, the food is delicious, the quality of the ingredients high, and the ambiance warm (sometimes literally - it gets steamy inside), but the service and care that the staff show make this place five star. They're usually very busy on weekend nights, but will try to accommodate walk-ins if they can. 

They have five (or six?) options for meals. You pick a type of broth, and then you pick the meat. The different broths come with pre-picked veggies. My favorite dish is the Shabu Shabu spicy miso soup. The Shabu Shabu option means the veggies come on the side, and the diner places the veggies in the broth when desired. You can order extra meat or veggies (I sometimes get extra mushrooms or udon noodles for my Shabu Shabu) for extra. 

Each diner will pay approximately $19-24 for their meal, however, you can choose to order one broth with one set of meat and it will come to $19-24 for the table. If you choose to order two different meals/broths - and remember each comes with their own meat/veggies, each diner is charged for the meal. They have big pots that the broths come in, and they can split a pot to accommodate two orders if needed. At the end, the servers have the table choose a broth; the server adds rice, one egg, and green onions to the broth, and serve it to each diner with a small amount of seaweed on top. Delicious, and very filling.

The sake menu is extensive, though I stick with the Asahi 33 ounce beer (more than enough for two people). They also have appetizers, but having Shabu Shabu with the finishing rice bowl is more than enough. Enjoy!

excerpts: Nabe is a healthier version of shabu shabu in San Francisco compared to other alternatives.

So if you're here with a group of friends you can choose to do both shabu shabu and sukiyaki, or some other combination.
shabu shabu.author: Annie Z.
shabu shabu.review:
Nabe is a healthier version of shabu shabu in San Francisco compared to other alternatives. Dinner prices are a few dollars higher than their lunch equivalent, but they have the option of doing a split pot. So if you're here with a group of friends you can choose to do both shabu shabu and sukiyaki, or some other combination. 

The meats were definitely not as fatty and therefore not as juicy and tender as the meat they serve at shabu house. But at the same time, this means they also have a lesser chance of giving you a heart attack later on in life. Their non-spicy soup is the traditional kombu soup. This soup is very very light. It is often mistaken for water with a piece of seaweed. Definitely a healthier, less-sodium alternative to the ginger chicken they have at Shabu house. At the end of the meal, the kombu soup will still taste amazing from all the beef you cooked in it. 

Nabe's shabu dinner is $3 more expensive than shabu house's and the portions are a bit smaller, but instead of the ice cream they will make your soup into a zosui rice porridge at the end by adding rice, egg, and scallions. Definitely another nice traditional touch at the end.

tip: Since the meats here are more lean, make sure you don't over cook it! You only need to dip the wagyu beef into the hot water for about 2 seconds. It's okay if parts of the meat are still slightly pink. Im sure most of you prefer your steaks medium rare-- it's a similar concept. if you cook it fully through it will definitely not taste as great. (you should do this at any shabu joint but it's especially important with leaner meats)

excerpts: One of the better shabu shabu places in the bay.
Got the ordinary shabu shabu with beef and the traditional broth and miso broth.
you can also choose from spicy miso broth as well.
shabu shabu.author: Heejin L.
shabu shabu.review:
One of the better shabu shabu places in the bay.
It's hard to find a shabu place that doesn't fuse with Chinese hot pot.

They don't have all you can eat.
Got the ordinary shabu shabu with beef and the traditional broth and miso broth. you can also choose from spicy miso broth as well.  The miso broth is like the miso soup you have at Japanese restaurants. 

I prefer the traditional water with konbu.  The vegetables seemed fresh and the meat quality wasn't the best but it was decent enough.

Service was attentive.
I like the option of the zosui at the end which is similar to porridge but more watery.  They make it out of the broth you used.  They put egg and garnish with green onions and seaweed.

Place is small and looks modern.

excerpts: Kurobata pork belly and shabu shabu sets.
shabu shabu.author: Lily L.
shabu shabu.review:
What's really unique about this place is that you can mix and match various styles of asian hot pot which makes complete sense because it's usually made in the same kind of pot. Most other hot pot restaurants only serve one style of hot pot (just sukiyaki etc).

Parking around the area can be hard some times. There's usually a wait if you go around dinner hours and they don't really have waiting space so you kind of have to stand outside or just wander around the area. They will call you if you leave your number on the wait list.

This is really my go-to place if I crave generic hot-pot. I get a nabemono set every time I go. I'm a fan of their Kimchi  Kurobata pork belly and shabu shabu sets. I'm not a huge fan of their seafood yosenabe mostly because everything just ends up tasting fishy in it...

When you're done with your hot pot, they'll bring a bowl of rice and eggs to mix into your left over soup and make zosui rice which is really tasty. This will definitely fill you up if you're still hungry.

meat was a lot better quality than the other shabu shabu/hot places I have been to and the broth was very

service was one of the best, very polite and professional. We were also able to make a reservation with no trouble, thumbs up for that! 

Food did not seem to be authentic shabu shabu, but good quality and taste! meat was a lot better quality than the other shabu shabu/hot places I have been to and the broth was very flavorful(we got the sukiyaki and the kimchi). 

Perfect for a rainy day and ask for different sauces(no extra charge)

excerpts: Very impressed with this unique take on shabu shabu!
shabu shabu.author: Helen L.
shabu shabu.review:
Very impressed with this unique take on shabu shabu! I love how their sets come with different ingredients, switching up the vegetables and starches to complement the broth of your choosing. 

The sukiyaki broth is unique for shabu but Nabe does it well! I'm always skeptical of sukiyaki because often times it can be too sweet. Nabe achieved the perfect balance of sweet and savory. Ingredients were very fresh - the mushrooms, sliced tofu were my favorite and love that they give you an egg to crack into the soup. Despite all of the ingredients in the broth upon serving, nothing was overcooked as the servers were attentive and made sure to turn the heat down several times for us throughout the meal. We also had the spicy miso shabu at our table and were very pleased with that as well. 

As for meat quality, the wagyu beef was not as good as I've had at other shabu places (a little lacking in the fatty marbling) but the pork belly was delicious. 

Make sure to save room for the Zosui finisher where they create a porridge-like soup for you at the table using one of your leftover broths! The server brought out rice, egg, and nori and we chose to have it mixed into our sukiyaki broth. Yum! 

We also tried the wagyu and kimchi dumplings but they were nothing to write home about. We'll just stick to the shabu sets next time we come as it is more than enough to fill you up.

Service was very attentive and the waiter made helpful beer recommendations. The menu stated maximum of 2 credit cards to split bill per table but our waiter told us we could split the bill as many ways as as wanted before we even had to ask! Awesome service, food, and decore. Will be back!

excerpts: My dad got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef with miso (not spicy) broth
shabu shabu.author: Jennifer J.
shabu shabu.review:
Came here recently with my dad since we've been trying to try out all the hot pot places in the city. After looking through the pictures of the place on Yelp, we decided to make a reservation which turned out to be a good idea because right when we got to the place there was already a table waiting for us. The staff were very friendly and nice and answered all our questions regarding the menu.

The food was really good in my opinion. My dad got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef with miso (not spicy) broth and I got the kimchi hot pot with kurobuta pork belly and mochi. We also got a side of rice (one split between the two of us), harusame noodles, tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and duck (the side order of duck which was $16 isn't listed on the menu). They also have the sesame dipping sauce, which we also asked for as well as it isn't automatically given to you. The ponzu sauce was more tart than other places I've been too but I thought it was great. I really liked the flavors of both broths and the pork and the beef portions were pretty decently sized. Though neither of us thought the side order of duck was worth it, it was an interesting try. 

The best part of the meal for me was the zosui rice soup. They take rice, a beaten egg, and green onions and throw it into your broth that you cooked all your food in (in this case we had a choice between miso and kimchi, and we chose miso). They serve it in your individual bowls and top it with nori strips. I didn't really know what to expect but it ended up being very flavorful (even though it was the miso broth and not the kimchi broth) and I ate the whole bowl even though I was pretty full from the main meal. When you get the soup it is BLAZING HOT so take your time eating it... and don't worry if you don't finish everything in the pot! They'll give you the rest in a take-out container.

The atmosphere of the place is what's bringing down the rating to 4 stars. It's a small place and everyone is having hot pot, so of course it was hot and a bit stuffy. When we walked in my dad mentioned that his glasses fogged up, and maybe it's better right when they open, but I thought it smelled kind of sweaty. It was great that we made a reservation because we had a table for two in the corner of the restaurant (I'm not a fan of sharing my space and sitting next to strangers).

Their bathroom is pretty nice inside. The door is a sliding door which even though I thought was pretty cool, was pretty embarrassing when I was standing outside the bathroom door for longer than 15 seconds trying to figure to whether there was someone in there or not.

Overall our meals ended up being pretty pricey (no thanks to the side of duck) but I'd come back again.

excerpts: (I think my general rule for shabu shabu restaurants is that you get there earlier for the better cuts of meat.)
In comparison with lots of other shabu shabu restaurants, I'd say Nabe easily gets to be in my top 3 favorite.
shabu shabu.author: So C.
shabu shabu.review:
I've been here multiple times and Nabe doesn't fail to disappoint. Their meat quality is stellar for the most part. (I think my general rule for shabu shabu restaurants is that you get there earlier for the better cuts of meat.) In comparison with lots of other shabu shabu restaurants, I'd say Nabe easily gets to be in my top 3 favorite.
Looking forward to trying their other soups, as I've only tried two kinds!

Pro-tips:
1. My most favorite thing about Nabe is the Japanese porridge. I almost always get the sukiyaki broth only for the porridge!
2. For most dinner nights, they get pretty crowded where the wait turns out to be fairly long. It's helpful to call them ahead of time, tell them you'd be there within 15-20 minutes, and Uberpool your way to the restaurant right away.

excerpts: To them, shabu shabu particularly the all you can eat bonanza's (which I affectionately term SHA BOO)
, Da Been Lo, kuo guo, Little Sheep, etc etc
are either all the same to them,
and/
or they find shabu shabu bland as hell, and thus require spicy miso broths in their ramen...and now shabu shabu.
And of course what hotpot is complete without a sucka MC remix your own jive ass sauce experience.
In a world where subtle natural flavors = no flavor, variety is their spice of life, at the expense of what it should really be.

The essence of something like shabu shabu, should be an emphasis on the season, the seasonality of ingredients (as well as their quality and original taste)...plus having a cast iron hot pot of homey comforting food, to be shared with family or friends, is not just fun, but warms your heart.
Spicy miso broth would in essence destroy that essence of original flavor.
Didn't get a chance to try the other pots yet, but I very much enjoyed the shabu shabu experience here, even though many are recommending the sukiyaki.
Here's what you can expect with a Shabu Shabu here:
shabu shabu in soymilk broth, using organic ingredients (local if still retaining original flavor), this place would be unstoppable.
As long as they don't offer ramen burgers, I will continue to come back.
shabu shabu.author: Ken K.
shabu shabu.review:
Cherylynn N's 4.5 star rating for Nabe (NAH-BEH) is very spot on and I agree with 100%. Hi Cherylynn! I trust your reviews more than MBauer!

Speaking of Bauer...thanks a lot buddy for outing what was supposed to be a "secret" good spot in your blog today. And now that restaurant thanks you too for so much exposure. The unintended consequence is that now they will get a lot of "know it all's", the hipsters who got charged after watching Jiro Dreams of Sushi, will now become Hipster dreams of Douchey, bringing their Tila Tequila type Asian girlfriends to show off more sushi knowledge. If you cringed when Carrie's boyfriend in Sex and the City said "Sake to Me baby" when she ordered sake, there's more BS in the works. Bauer, why don't you all do us a favor and go to Sawa Sushi instead and stay there :-*( ? 

Anyways, I'm just going to throw it out there that maybe 85+% of Chinese and Asian Americans don't understand traditional Japanese hot pot category of food (nabemono). To them, shabu shabu particularly the all you can eat bonanza's (which I affectionately term SHA BOO), Da Been Lo, kuo guo, Little Sheep, etc etc are either all the same to them, and/ or they find shabu shabu bland as hell, and thus require spicy miso broths in their ramen...and now shabu shabu. And of course what hotpot is complete without a sucka MC remix your own jive ass sauce experience. In a world where subtle natural flavors = no flavor, variety is their spice of life, at the expense of what it should really be. Thus crap becomes the norm.

The essence of something like shabu shabu, should be an emphasis on the season, the seasonality of ingredients (as well as their quality and original taste)...plus having a cast iron hot pot of homey comforting food, to be shared with family or friends, is not just fun, but warms your heart. Spicy miso broth would in essence destroy that essence of original flavor. This is where premium quality beef, boiled in konbu broth, dipped in ponzu with scallions, momiji oroshi or ginger, is sufficient and elegant.

But not the SHA BOO BS.

So for Nabe to come in and pretty much do things right, and still give it a unique Japanese feel, right here in a city of wrong (and wrong food), is commendable. 

The interior is certainly interesting....swanky, yet very Japanese. Love the various bottles of sake plastered on the walls, and even the logo "Nabe" has that Orenchi-esque vibe to it.

But us FOB types are really here for the food.

Didn't get a chance to try the other pots yet, but I very much enjoyed the shabu shabu experience here, even though many are recommending the sukiyaki.

Here's what you can expect with a Shabu Shabu here:

If you are a traditionalist, the kelp/konbu broth is more than just "traditional water". There are humongous pieces of konbu in here. Way more than what the competition provides. Or if you have seen the version at Zabu in San Mateo, they throw in a few pieces of seaweed and call it a day, not kelp.

The plate of mixed veggies you get is of pretty good quality, but if you have more in your party you want to upgrade to extra veggies (combo platter include abura age/tofu pouches, which soaks up the broth), shimeji mushrooms (and king oyster). Ingredients are organic where possible, and this makes a huge difference in the overall experience. 

For pork there are choices of belly or shoulder.... while belly is the popular obvious choice, the shoulder cut is actually quite excellent in its own right. The beef quality here is better than Shabuway (which is better than those SHA BOO house of worship and AYCE AYCDrink excess, like a Roman orgy or Yelp Elite event from 2005).

The dip sauces have some thought put into it. The ponzu has a strong citrus accent than other places, and default one comes with momiji oroshi (minced grated daikon that has a slight spicy kick) and finely chopped scallions. Still very Japanesey. Didn't try the sesame dip, but it looked good.

Even a bowl of rice in here, tastes like a good Japanese restaurant's prep.

While I have yet to try Yosenabe, Sukiyaki, I have no doubt those will be done quite nicely too. Polite, adequate, and good solid service.

Make a reservation before coming, especially on the weekends.

If this place could do regional Japanese hotpots....ishikari nabe (Hokkaido) or even winter season kanburi (winter yellowtail) shabu shabu in soymilk broth, using organic ingredients (local if still retaining original flavor), this place would be unstoppable. As long as they don't offer ramen burgers, I will continue to come back.

excerpts: Good quality shabu shabu/hot pot with a variety of soup bases that should satisfy most people in your party.
shabu shabu.author: Jennifer W.
shabu shabu.review:
Good quality shabu shabu/hot pot with a variety of soup bases that should satisfy most people in your party. 

Each person can choose a different "set" since they have split pots available. I've tried the sukiyaki, kimchi pork belly, and regular kombu pots, and enjoyed all of them. They also provide a ponzu dipping sauce with green onions and garlic. 

At the end of your meal, they'll cook a congee with the remaining soup with egg, green onions, and seaweed. You'll likely be full at this point, but it's still really tasty and great to take home as leftovers. 

Service is friendly and attentive, and very accommodating. FYI - They let me charge my iPhone 6 in the back while I was eating.

One downside is that they're a bit stingy on the sides/vegetables. I got the harusume noodles, which is basically fen si/green bean vermicelli noodle, and I felt like after only a few bites there was none left. It's also on the pricier side, expect to spend at least $25 pp here for dinner.

excerpts: My go to sets are the Kamonanban (duck) and the Shabu Shabu (w/ the Wagyu beef or the Kurobuta pork belly).
But you really can't go wrong with any of them!
shabu shabu.author: My L.
shabu shabu.review:
Oh Nabe...how I love all your wonderful nabemono combinations! My go to sets are the Kamonanban (duck) and the Shabu Shabu (w/ the Wagyu beef or the Kurobuta pork belly). But you really can't go wrong with any of them! All the meats and veggies are great quality and really fresh! 

Another must is the Kurobuta Sausage starter. Great texture, nice bite of the casing and just super savory yumminess. Beware as you take your first bite as I've some across come squirters! *giggles*

And the Zosui rice finisher is a thoughtful way to end your meal. It's crazy comfort food and a wonderful way to not waste the delicious broth!

Lastly, the staff and owner round out all the reasons why this is one of favorite restaurants in SF. Courteous and attentive, while not being overbearing. 

I love introducing my friends to Nabe when they are craving shabu and are looking for something different from the usual. And everyone always walks out loving it as well!

Love you Nabe! I feel a shabu craving coming on so I will be seeing you guys soon!

excerpts: We decided to split between Shabu Shabu and Seafood Yosenabe with an extra order of ramen and udon on the side.
I enjoyed eating the seafood yosenabe because it has  plentiful amounts of seafood and shellfish.
One thing to note is that unlike other shabu places, you do not have rice on your side until the end when they mix it in the broth.
By the time we finished both pots, I was pretty full and content
shabu shabu.author: Jennifer W.
shabu shabu.review:
This score is based upon the average of the two visits here at Nabe.

Ever since it's opening, I've been excited to try this place because of its high reviews and the different styles of hot pot (shabu, sukiyaki, kimchi broth with pork belly, Seafood Yosenabe and Kamonanban!) that comes with Zosui at the end of the meal.
On the first visit, knowing that the place was going to be packed on a Friday night, my friend scheduled a reservation for 7:30pm for the two of us. 
Contrary to the pictures you see on the website, the restaurant looks a lot smaller and can probably fit 20 people at most. 
When we arrived for our reservation, the waitresses apologized and told us we essentially had 30 minutes to eat before a larger party of 10 came in or that we can come back in another hour.

Uh. what?

I don't think there is any possible way for anyone to leisurely finish within 30 minutes at a hot pot restaurant. 

If we had just casually walked into the restaurant and was told this, I would've thought, "Oh it's okay then. We can wait" But NO! We made a freaking reservation! It makes absolutely NO sense for us to wait another hour. 
I was pretty upset about this and seeing that we were both hungry, decided to go down the block to Ebi Sushi for dinner. :| 

A couple of weeks after, I decided to go again with a couple of my other friends, with some amount of reservation. It was a Saturday evening and was surprisingly empty. 
We decided to split between Shabu Shabu and Seafood Yosenabe with an extra order of ramen and udon on the side.  I enjoyed eating the seafood yosenabe because it has  plentiful amounts of seafood and shellfish.  One thing to note is that unlike other shabu places, you do not have rice on your side until the end when they mix it in the broth. 
By the time we finished both pots, I was pretty full and content The waitress was very nice and even offered to help take a picture of us. 

I wouldn't mind coming back again for lunch to try their other pots and hopefully, those next visits will help make me forget about that first visit...

excerpts: We got half Sukiyaki and half Vegetarian Shabu Shabu.
We liked both but
because we're such meat lovers, we loved the Sukiyaki best!
shabu shabu.author: Mandi W.
shabu shabu.review:
Nom Nom Nom, best hot pot I've had in the city so far!
I reserved a table on Open Table and it was ready and waiting for me when I walked in. :)

That place was PACKED!

We got half Sukiyaki and half Vegetarian Shabu Shabu. We liked both but because we're such meat lovers, we loved the Sukiyaki best! Go carnivores!

Anyways, food was good, service was good, and I'll definitely make a trip back.

excerpts: shabu shabu places you can find a dozen in the richmond district.
Keep in mind, they don't offer AYCE but a set of nabe or shabu shabu is more than enough for my tummy, and trust me, I have a big appetite for a girl!
I typically love to cook my udon in the soup and have that as the last bite of my shabu shabu.
But after I discovered zosui, I could care less about the udon!
I absolutely love zosui!
The raw egg makes the soup a little creamier for the taste
and you get a bowl of heaven(for me at least)!
shabu shabu.author: Mindy C.
shabu shabu.review:
Oh how I love shabu...

My love for shabu is unconditional. I want it all day everyday, rain or shine, day or night... No, seriously!
Nabe is not the usual shabu shabu places you can find a dozen in the richmond district. Nabe offers the authentic nabemono shabu sets that's carefully chosen and prepared based on the soup base and the flavor of the meat.

Appetizer
Edamame with sea salt and garlic sauce - get your appetite going!
Gyoza - pan-fried dumplings with ponzu sauce
Kurobuta sausages with mustard aioli - sweet and delicious! 

Kimchi kurobuta pork belly with kimchi miso broth - if you like a spicy kick in your soup, go for it! pork belly is thin-sliced, easy to cook and very tender!
Sukiyaki with wagyu beef and warishita broth - it's a much lighter and sweeter soup with a variety of vegetables. Absolutely refreshing! 

Keep in mind, they don't offer AYCE but a set of nabe or shabu shabu is more than enough for my tummy, and trust me, I have a big appetite for a girl! (And I'm not ashamed of it!)

Don't order rice with your shabu set because at the end of your meal you will regret it! After you are finished with your meat and vegetable set, Nabe offers the zosui - they put a bowl of rice, an raw egg, nori, green onions into the flavorful soup to make rice porridge. I'm a person who loves to drink a bowl of the soup which contains all the nutrition and flavor from the vegetables and meat. I typically love to cook my udon in the soup and have that as the last bite of my shabu shabu. But after I discovered zosui, I could care less about the udon! I absolutely love zosui! The raw egg makes the soup a little creamier for the taste and you get a bowl of heaven(for me at least)! That is my favorite part of the meal! 

Never disappoint! Ok, I'm hungry now thinking about the wagyu beef, the pork belly and the zosui! Maybe I'll have that for dinner tonight! 

The service at Nabe is great! The waitresses there are attentive and friendly. :) Thanks Nabe!
Parking is tough - street parking or you can try the parking lot right across the street. It is Irving st, just be patient. Make a reservation, it'll definitely be easier!

Enjoy! xoxo

excerpts: Shabu Shabu order didn't have the best beef quality.
Even with 5-7 seconds of quick dip, it was a little hard to bite into.
Not to mention, zero marble in the meat.
As far the pork belly
shabu shabu.author: Eric Y.
shabu shabu.review:
Located on the cross street of 9th and Irving is a hole in the wall shabu place. I totally didn't see this place until i pulled up google maps trying to look for the address. 

The exterior design of the place looks like a warehouse with 2 overly fogged windows. You literally cannot see inside from the outside if the temps outside is around 50F. Also the signs aren't that noticeable if you don't pay attention to the fusion Japanese style fonts. 

Interior is nicely done but very small. The walls are decored with sake/alcohol bottles. Seating is very straightforward and crowded. Feels like I didn't have enough room and the plates were all over the place. The seating next to us has their meat plate right next to mine (it's like, i should eat over). 

Meat quality was okay. Shabu Shabu order didn't have the best beef quality. Even with 5-7 seconds of quick dip, it was a little hard to bite into. Not to mention, zero marble in the meat. As far the pork belly, that was a little better, but I believe that pork slices should be a tad thicker since it can give you a little more taste (personal preference).  

As far as soup quality, nothing too special here. Kimchi bowl just had kimchi and some tofu + spices. Nothing you can't pull off at home. Miso side was just miso, bland and maybe even a little boring. 

Best part of the whole dinner was the last bowl of rice. The waitress introduced something called the zosui (but in chinese terms, it's congee). Basically they put a bowl of rice into any side of the soup you prefer. Add an egg and then sprinkle chopped green onions and some seaweed. Let it cook for a few minutes and you have a rich bowl of zosui. Super high cholesterol, but what gives... 

- too crowded, no waiting area except outside. hard to find parking as well. 
- air quality has miso smell all over. stuffy and hard to breath since there's no air condition or fans. maybe this is why the windows were all fogged up. 
+ service was excellent

excerpts: We shared a large Shabu Shabu set with spicy miso broth and wagyu beef ($24).
Each set comes with a complimentary bowl of rice, and assorted vegetable platters vary
but you're free to order extra items a la carte, which we did.
The broth was very good and not too spicy.
shabu shabu.author: Christina F.
shabu shabu.review:
My boyfriend and I admittedly came here for dinner when our original dinner plans fell through but we're glad things worked out the way they did. It was a cool enough evening for us to enjoy a little hot pot. The layout of the small restaurant is very minimalist and stylish with wooden boxes holding different bottles of sake all along the black walls. Only 2 servers were working the Tues evening we were here (though I can't see them being able to fit more), and we were promptly seated after arriving.

Our server was patient in explaining how the menu and service worked. We shared a large Shabu Shabu set with spicy miso broth and wagyu beef ($24). Each set comes with a complimentary bowl of rice, and assorted vegetable platters vary but you're free to order extra items a la carte, which we did. The broth was very good and not too spicy. If you're new to hot pot, a lot the meat and vegetables are cut in a way that don't require them to cook for very long so remember not to let them sit in there until they turn into leather or mush.

I was worried the 1 set wasn't going to be enough food but that plus the porridge they make at the end by mixing rice and egg in the remaining broth and topping it off with nori was plenty. The server warns you to leave room for it, and you should. Overall, Nabe was a great find.

excerpts: Spicy miso shabu shabu is sooo good!!
And the porridge dish after main course is especially excellent with spicy miso!
Highly recommend Nabe if you love hot pot.
shabu shabu.author: Ihsuan Y.
shabu shabu.review: Spicy miso shabu shabu is sooo good!! And the porridge dish after main course is especially excellent with spicy miso! Highly recommend Nabe if you love hot pot.

excerpts: We ordered seafood Yosenabe and Shabu Shabu with wagu beef.

excerpts: After numerous mediocre experiences with Shabu Shabu in San Francisco, we were excited to finally try Nabe.
The steamed glass walls and crowded, vibrant atmosphere indicated that we had made the right decision - it did not disappoint.
We ordered the Sukiyaki Shabu Shabu with a side of vegetables and fried tofu skins.
It came with a raw egg dip, which I've never had before, it was delicious!
Everything was really fresh and the broth was tasty, wished it would have been spicier.
shabu shabu.author: Elisa P.
shabu shabu.review:
After numerous mediocre experiences with Shabu Shabu in San Francisco, we were excited to finally try Nabe. The steamed glass walls and crowded, vibrant atmosphere indicated that we had made the right decision - it did not disappoint. The service was slow at the beginning though it got better throughout the night.

We ordered the Sukiyaki Shabu Shabu with a side of vegetables and fried tofu skins. It came with a raw egg dip, which I've never had before, it was delicious! Everything was really fresh and the broth was tasty, wished it would have been spicier.The meat looked Will definitely try the kimchi and the spicy miso broth next time.

A quality sake selection made the meal even more enjoyable. And, the complimentary zosui, rice porridge, made with the leftover, condensed broth, topped with seaweed, was fantastic! Perfect way to end a meal; guaranteed that you will not leave hungry.

excerpts: All of us ordered the shabu shabu; it comes with your choice of spicy miso, regular miso, or kombu broth.
I opted for the kombu; they give a good amount of kombu whereas other places I've been will only give a tiny square to flavor the broth.
The shabu shabu is $14 for lunch and $20 for dinner.
I think for an authentic shabu shabu joint, at least a couple leaves of shungiku should be automatic.
Anyways, the meat was pretty high quality, tender, and cooks very quickly.
The ponzu sauce was really delicious, the sesame sauce
just so-so.
I like the bottled goma-shabu I can buy at the supermarket better to be honest.
However, the rice finisher at the end is really a nice touch and a perfect end to the meal.
However, I would definitely come back for some quality shabu shabu.
shabu shabu.author: Elaine W.
shabu shabu.review:
Nabe is aptly named, as it lives up to its name in serving high quality Japanese style hotpot. It is very very cosy and a good place for a laidback dinner with a couple of friends. I wouldn't recommend coming with more than a group of four because this place is tiny. We waited about 40 minutes and there were only one or two groups ahead of us.

All of us ordered the shabu shabu; it comes with your choice of spicy miso, regular miso, or kombu broth. I opted for the kombu; they give a good amount of kombu whereas other places I've been will only give a tiny square to flavor the broth. The shabu shabu is $14 for lunch and $20 for dinner. It comes with your choice of wagyu beef or Kurobuta pork, udon, and an assortment of veggies, all nicely cut and of good quality. My only gripes would be that you have to ask for rice instead of it being given automatically, and that they charge for shungiku. I think for an authentic shabu shabu joint, at least a couple leaves of shungiku should be automatic. Anyways, the meat was pretty high quality, tender, and cooks very quickly. The ponzu sauce was really delicious, the sesame sauce just so-so. I like the bottled goma-shabu I can buy at the supermarket better to be honest. However, the rice finisher at the end is really a nice touch and a perfect end to the meal. The 33 oz Asahi is a perfect pairing with all of this too.

All in all I had a very good meal. I took one star off because of the above issues, and because of the lack of waiting area; the entrance door pushes inwards so it's easy to hit people who are waiting indoors. Also, the ventilation is really poor so it's just really stuffy and humid in the restaurant. However, I would definitely come back for some quality shabu shabu.

excerpts: We tried the sukiyaki & the shabu shabu with wagyu beef & spicy miso broth.
Personally, I liked the warishita broth that came with the sukiyaki a lot more than the spicy miso broth.
However, the porridge that they made using the spicy miso broth at the end of our meal was pretty great.

Personally, I liked the warishita broth that came with the sukiyaki a lot more than the spicy miso broth. excerpts: We ordered the Shabu Shabu w/ Waygu and the Kim Chi w/ Pork Belly.
All I got to say was this place is good!!!
shabu shabu.author: Teejay C.
shabu shabu.review:
Had zero issues with finding a seat for two.  We ordered the Shabu Shabu w/ Waygu and the Kim Chi w/ Pork Belly.  All I got to say was this place is good!!!  My Kim Chi soup was perfect and had the right amount of spice.  

Place is small with a great customer service.  We put garlic in our soup and the aroma seas blasting in our faces...lol.  

Definitely coming back.

excerpts: This is a good place to go for Shabu Shabu.
It's small, modern and semi-classy.
The meat was tasty, produce was fresh & seafood broth was good.
What I loved most about this place is the free Japanese-style rice porridge service they provide.
They use the broth that's left in the hot pot to: mix one bowl of steamed white rice, seafood and a raw egg.
shabu shabu.author: Content O.
shabu shabu.review:
Ate here while vacationing in the Bay Area with my big brother last Fall of 2014.  It was in the month of September, to be exact!  This is a good place to go for Shabu Shabu.  It's small, modern and semi-classy.  The meat was tasty, produce was fresh & seafood broth was good.  What I loved most about this place is the free Japanese-style rice porridge service they provide.  They use the broth that's left in the hot pot to: mix one bowl of steamed white rice, seafood and a raw egg.  It's yummy & one of the highlights of the hot pot experience...

I also dig their in-house green tea mochi cake.  It's not too sweet and perfect to share with your date, friend or anyone else you came with... :)))

excerpts: Nabe is a new trendy Japanese Shabu Shabu restaurant that recently opened in the Inner Sunset.
It's a bit out of place, but it works - "diversity".
The interior of the restaurant is simple, yet modern.
It also puts the small amount of space into good use as you basically share one long table with other customers.
It's like an average Shabu Shabu place.
I didn't find the meat to be extremely fresh, but definitely up to par with other places.
The beef is nicely marbleized.
The soup bases were decent, but nothing to rave about.
Though the sukiyaki broth was too overpoweringly sweet, The spicy miso was not spicy at all.
The Shabu set also comes with some veggies and noodles.
I would have liked more noodles and veggies, but whatever.
The porridge at the end of the meal is a nice and innovative touch.
They basically bring out a bowl of rice and put it in the soup base of your choice (already at your table).
One of the waitress will cook the porridge for you and add toppings such as green onions and seaweed.
shabu shabu.author: Michelle L.
shabu shabu.review:
3.5 stars!

Nabe is a new trendy Japanese Shabu Shabu restaurant that recently opened in the Inner Sunset. It's a bit out of place, but it works - "diversity". The interior of the restaurant is simple, yet modern. It also puts the small amount of space into good use as you basically share one long table with other customers. Good for people who enjoy others' company, bad for people who like a more intimate environment.

The service is excellent. The waitresses are friendly and personable. They are also very knowledgable in the menu (though not many options). They would explain in details what is in the soup base and the idea behind it, and etc. 

The food is okay. It's like an average Shabu Shabu place. I didn't find the meat to be extremely fresh, but definitely up to par with other places. The beef is nicely marbleized. The soup bases were decent, but nothing to rave about. Though the sukiyaki broth was too overpoweringly sweet, The spicy miso was not spicy at all. The Shabu set also comes with some veggies and noodles. I would have liked more noodles and veggies, but whatever. The porridge at the end of the meal is a nice and innovative touch. They basically bring out a bowl of rice and put it in the soup base of your choice (already at your table). One of the waitress will cook the porridge for you and add toppings such as green onions and seaweed. It was quite delicious, probably my favorite part of the meal!

It is reasonably priced, but the portions are not that big. I'm usually not a big eater, but I felt that the regular portion was just almost right. It got you to a somewhat satisfied state, but not too full. But you could probably snack on a couple more things before you're full. I didn't see much of a difference between the large and regular portion, I would have liked more meat..

excerpts: Nabe is a higher end shabu shabu shop in Inner Sunset.
They also serve sukiyaki.
Everything is kept pretty simple.
The meat quality and vegetable quality is key.
shabu shabu.author: Jay C.
shabu shabu.review:
Modern and minimalist, Nabe and its steamy storefront intrigue passerbys. Contributing to Nabe's Japanese zen vibe, sake bottles line the walls, along with its chic vibe, dark walls, and hipster customers.

Nabe is a higher end shabu shabu shop in Inner Sunset. They also serve sukiyaki. Everything is kept pretty simple. The meat quality and vegetable quality is key. Spicy miso broth cannot be found here; rather it's a focus on simple kombu broth, nice quality marbled beef, simple sauce choices, locally sourced vegetables (pumpkin!), and more.

The meal concludes with a tasty rice porridge - a bit too tasty, with too much salt. All in all, a great experience, though I would have preferred to see more variety.

excerpts: Order: I had to get the beef shabu shabu with spicy miso broth (to compare with all other shabu places, you know?).
My bf got the duck shabu in soy sauce broth.
My beef was sliced very thin and was very nicely marbled, but without any gross chewy fat.
It came with a plate full of veggies and noodles.
The spicy broth was a medium spicy, something that I could handle but that my bf also felt had some kick to it.
To my surprise, the duck was also amazing.
It came with everything already in the pot
and I was worried that the duck was going to overcook before we could eat it all, but the last bite was just as tender as the first.
Plus, all the veggies in there were soaked with so much flavor by the end, especially the tofu!
Save some room though because when you think you're done with the meal, they bring out the rice, egg, and scallions and make an amazing porridge out of your favorite broth.
We chose the spicy miso and did not regret it!
shabu shabu.author: Janet Z.
shabu shabu.review:
Ok this is my new favorite place for shabu if you want quality and a little something special (the porridge meal at the end)! 

Situation: Date night last Friday night with the bf. We had a reservation and got there a bit late due the craziness of parking in the area. I walked in and BOOM my glasses immediately fogged up! It was like a hot sauna in there because there are no windows and so much hot-potting going on!  This was a terrible day to wear my glasses - I should've just gone with contacts!  Anyway, moving on - Our table wasn't ready yet, but it's such a small space, I can understand that it's hard to predict customer flow. After about 15 minutes, we were seated. By that time, my glasses had gotten accustomed to the temperature inside, so I could actually SEE across the table at my food and my date now. 

Order: I had to get the beef shabu shabu with spicy miso broth (to compare with all other shabu places, you know?).  My bf got the duck shabu in soy sauce broth.  My beef was sliced very thin and was very nicely marbled, but without any gross chewy fat. It came with a plate full of veggies and noodles.  The spicy broth was a medium spicy, something that I could handle but that my bf also felt had some kick to it.  To my surprise, the duck was also amazing. It came with everything already in the pot and I was worried that the duck was going to overcook before we could eat it all, but the last bite was just as tender as the first.  Plus, all the veggies in there were soaked with so much flavor by the end, especially the tofu! Save some room though because when you think you're done with the meal, they bring out the rice, egg, and scallions and make an amazing porridge out of your favorite broth. We chose the spicy miso and did not regret it!  I will be making this porridge at home...

Service: The staff here was super communicative during our wait, and friendly and attentive during our meal.  It was also very nice of them to make the porridge for us. 

Pro tips: Save some room for the porridge at the end!  Parking here can also be crazy so try to get here a little early. There is a small lot right across the street, but it gets filled pretty quickly.

The kimchi set was my fav

shabu shabu.author: Krisna T.
shabu shabu.review:
The bae and I decided to check this place out after yelping a few hotpot/shabu spots in the sunset. I suggested that we try some place new--and so we both agreed on Nabe. 

When we arrived, we were greeted by one of the servers and he allowed us to choose our table since the restaurant wasn't too packed. After being seated, another server came by and kindly explained the menu thoroughly to us. Apparently, the restaurant serves nabemonos(aka nabe) and not your basic shabu. On their menu, there was a list of different nabe sets and our server explained that all sets but the shabu shabu set(yes, it's still an option here!) come with a pot of broth that already contains most of the paired items inside of the pot--whereas for the shabu shabu set, the meat, noodles, and veggies are all given separately. I wanted shabu at the start because I wanted to cook my own food yakno, so we ordered the shabu shabu set with beef and miso broth and the kimchi with pork belly set. Now let's break it down:

Food-Super yummy! The shabu shabu set was like other shabu I've had--but still good. The kimchi set was my fav *o* The bae also agreed that the kimchi was also his fav, hehe. The level of spiciness of the broth was perfect. I love eating spicy food even though I can't handle it well LOL, but it was still bearable. Pork belly of course was good, obvi. Best part about the kimchi set was that it came with little mochi cubes instead of noodles!! When we cooked it in the broth, it became squishy and just amazingggg. 

Best part of the meal had to be the rice finisher. When we were done eating, our server asked if we were ready for the rice finisher and I was like "Okay!", but then bae and I looked at each other like huh?? She came back with rice, egg, seaweed and green onions and explained to us that the rice finisher(zosui?) is served at the end of each meal. We chose to have it prepared in the kimchi broth and omg, it was so good. It is basically rice soup/porridge/jook/chao/whatever you wanna call it--but better. You can say that we both left with with a food baby.


Environment- The restaurant layout is really cute and compact. Not many tables and the aisles were quite small, but still walkable. Everything looks clean and simple. Although the restaurant was sort of empty when we got there, by the end of our meal, the restaurant was SUPER packed and it got pretty humid inside of the restaurant. 



Service-EXCELLENT! Although there were only 2 servers and there was a full house, both were very attentive and were super friendly. Our cups of tea were never empty and they checked up on us here and there.



Overall, I'd say my first visit to Nabe was enjoyable and will most def return!

excerpts:
My boyfriend decided to split half half so we could try more things and went with the large beef shabu shabu with spicy miso soup and another half of the pork belly with kimchi broth.
With the shabu shabu you add everything into the soup yourself.
I liked the kimchi broth, the soup was very flavorful and I loved how it was filled with a lot of vegetables.

shabu shabu.author: Jenny Y.
shabu shabu.review:
Call in before you get there so they can put your party on the wait list!
I called in about 20-30 minutes before I got there and a waitress called me back when we were up and our table was free.
We eventually found parking in the lot across the street but that area in general is just a pain in the ass to deal with.
We arrived with the windows all fogged up and were seated shortly after.
Waitresses are very nice and attentive and let you take your time to order and will gladly explain what everything is.

Nabe's hot pot is a bit different from all the other hot pot/shabu places that you go to and that's what caught my taste buds attention.
You order a set which comes with the listed ingredients/soup flavor.
My boyfriend decided to split half half so we could try more things and went with the large beef shabu shabu with spicy miso soup and another half of the pork belly with kimchi broth.
When our pot came the kimchi broth already had all the ingredients in the pot, with a large plate of pork on the side and mochi.
With the shabu shabu you add everything into the soup yourself.
I liked the kimchi broth, the soup was very flavorful and I loved how it was filled with a lot of vegetables. The marbling on the beef for the shabu was also very nice, the meat was tender.
Their sesame sauce is also good, it's more on the watery side which I like.

We were too full to try the zosui rice at the end but will be back.
Sucks that they run out of Sprite. Who runs out of Sprite?!

My table ordered:

shabu shabu.author: Jay K.
shabu shabu.review:
A pretty shabu shabu place that would be good for a date or group outing. The way food is served is suited to westernized sensibilities in that each person gets their own individual portion of meat/veggies according to whatever they order as their set. Broth can also be individualized. 

My table ordered: 
- The pork belly and kimchi set
- Shabu shabu beef set with both the regular seaweed broth and spicy miso broth

The kimchi set didn't come with noodles, but we ordered ramen noodles on the side, which went well with the spicy broth. The shabu shabu set was paired with udon noodles. 

At the end, the soup is used to make rice porridge, reminiscent of the way Korean restaurants will often make porridge at the end of their hotpot meal (different kinds of jungol). Add in a little spring onion, seaweed, and egg (I think sesame oil as well), and you've got a good end to the meal. I found the porridge a little too watery and salty but my dining companions enjoyed it. 

There were people lingering around the entrance, waiting for tables, by the time we were done. 

The place had good food and nice decor. I'm not sure what suggestions I would give to improve the experience or the food at the moment; I found it to be a solid choice but not an impressive one.

Rating would probably be a little over a 3.

excerpts: When she finally came back we ordered 4 shabu shabu dinners.
She asked if we wanted rice, and I asked if we could have udon instead.
(Shabu House lets us do this all the time.)
She shortly answered no and left us.
shabu shabu.author: Taylor W.
shabu shabu.review:
Now let me start by saying I absolutely love Nabe and I think it's a great addition to the sunset neighborhood! One of the nice things they do is they allow neighbors (or I suppose anyone) call ahead and put their name down on the waiting list. Normally when my family and I do this, we only have to wait a few minutes for our table but this recent experience was not like that. I called and spoke to the hostess who told me that it would be no problem for a group of 4, at most we would wait 20 minutes. My grandma and I headed over to the restaurant only to find out that the restaurant had two reservations for 4 booked and therefore would be seated ahead of us. This would have been great to know before leaving the house... We would have happily come later if we had know about these reservations... So instead, my 85 year old grandmother and I waited outside in 50 degree weather for over an hour... The hostess kept telling me it would only be a bit longer... Just a bit longer... If I knew it was going to be an hour, I would have gone elsewhere!! 

When we finally got seated, the hostess dumped our menus on the table and rushed away... After waiting so long, I was just ready to order! When she finally came back we ordered 4 shabu shabu dinners. She asked if we wanted rice, and I asked if we could have udon instead. (Shabu House lets us do this all the time.) She shortly answered no and left us. When I mentioned that we had been waiting over an hour for our table, she wasn't apologetic at all. 

The only thing that turned this night around was the waitress who took over our table. Nancy is the best!! She has been my server before and is always so nice! If it weren't for her, this review would have been more like 2 stars for the horrendous service by the hostess. Nancy was so great! She promptly brought our food and was very attentive. Most Shabu places will dump your food and won't check in with you until the end of your meal. I want to personally thank Nancy for going above and beyond! You really turned our night around! Thank you! And we will be back soon!

excerpts: We ordered the Shabu Shabu and split it between the both of us because we were still digesting our lunch and didn't think we had the room in our stomachs to order our own sets.
Being a first-timer, I didn't have anything to compare it to, so I'd say that I was satisfied and enjoyed the meal!
shabu shabu.author: Peter L.
shabu shabu.review:
I'm half a year late on this review, so let me reach into the deepest depths of my ass and pull out what I can remember. First time trying shabu and it was amazing!

Found this spot on Yelp some time ago while building my list of hotspots to check out in the city and dragged a friend to eat here with me so I'm not one of those sad people that consciously eat alone. We came in right when they opened for dinner time, so there wasn't anybody else other than just the two of us.

We ordered the Shabu Shabu and split it between the both of us because we were still digesting our lunch and didn't think we had the room in our stomachs to order our own sets. Being a first-timer, I didn't have anything to compare it to, so I'd say that I was satisfied and enjoyed the meal! I wasn't particularly pleased with the portions of the noodle add-ons, but you get a lot of other things to compensate for it.

Whatever soup is left they use to make the rice porridge, which I wasn't a big fan of because I didn't feel too comfortable eating the soup that we just dipped a bunch of crap in and who knows what's stewing in alla that. It's like putting rice into the leftover soup from a packet of ramen, it just didn't click with me. The server said it was her favorite part of the meal, but if baby food was her forte, then I guess.

excerpts: Both times, we ordered the same, half kimchi broth w/kurobuta pork and Shabu Shabu with Wagyu Beef, both of which were excellent.
The kimchi broth already comes with all the veggies within the broth whereas the Shabu Shabu provided you a platter of veggies for you to cook at your own pace.
shabu shabu.author: Rich L.
shabu shabu.review:
I came here two times as the first time was for lunch and little did I know that they do not offer the post-shabu porridge(Zosui Finisher) during lunch and only for dinner.

Both times, we ordered the same, half kimchi broth w/kurobuta pork and Shabu Shabu with Wagyu Beef, both of which were excellent. The kimchi broth already comes with all the veggies within the broth whereas the Shabu Shabu provided you a platter of veggies for you to cook at your own pace. We also ordered a side of clams in case the food was not enough.

The portions were just right for 2 people and I enjoyed being able to try two different broths and two different styles of cooking but ultimately, we enjoyed the kimchi broth the most so when it came time for the Zosui Finisher, we chose the kimchi broth.

I wish all shabu places in the city provided a Zosui Finisher as it is the ultimate way to have a flavorful porridge in case you were still hungry. I will definitely be back here for more especially with their cool decor of empty customer sake bottles hung all over the walls.

Food Highlight: Zosui Finisher with the KimChi Broth

P.S. - The bathroom is hidden behind curtains in the middle of the room along the wall so make sure to ask before walking towards/into the kitchen lol

excerpts: I'm normally more of a hot pot (Chinese style) fan than shabu shabu
shabu shabu.author: Kate M.
shabu shabu.review:
I adore this place. I'm normally more of a hot pot (Chinese style) fan than shabu shabu (Japanese) as the options for broth and everything that goes into it is far more varied in hot pot, but Nabe is something special.

It is a little on the pricey side but the quality of meat, noodles, and vegetables are all high quality. I've tried most of the broth and my favorite would have to be the spicy miso. Konbu is a little bland while the kimchi one is a little sour for my tastes. I always get the medium spicy miso broth for size and order extra meat and noodles if there are more people. The udon noodles are fresh and delicious while the pork has just the right amount of marbling.

If it hasn't been raved about already, the best part of the meal is the zosui rice, aka THE FINISHER. I can never go back to other shabu places as most places do not do the zosui. After you've finished your meal and the broth is wonderfully flavored with the meat and vegetable, they take a little bit of rice and egg and let it simmer to a wonderful jook, congee, rice soup, whatever you would like to call it. Top it off with scallions and nori and it is a PERFECT cup of the most flavorful rice soup/stew you could possibly taste. I love it so much that I wish they would just sell this part. 

If you have room for dessert at this point they have a delicious housemade mochi cake with green tea that I highly recommend.

The wait during weekdays is minimal to none but on the weekends I would recommend calling ahead to be seated. The service is great, they're attentive and make the rice soup on the spot for you.

excerpts: We shared the seafood broth and shabu shabu broth with konbu.
The ingredients didn't seem to come in large portions, but you can tell they are high quality stuff.
shabu shabu.author: Candice B.
shabu shabu.review:
Nabe has a very tastefully decorated interior.  I like the sake bottles on the wall, and even the fogged up wall/door as diners steam up the place with their hot pots.  It looks chic and yet cozy. 

We shared the seafood broth and shabu shabu broth with konbu.  The ingredients didn't seem to come in large portions, but you can tell they are high quality stuff. And by the time we were ready for the porridge, we were actually really full.  

Like many reviews have mentioned, the porridge is almost the best part.  It's full of umami from the broth.  A great way to end a great meal.

excerpts: The best soup base was the shabu shabu spicy miso.
The sukiyaki base was a bit too sweet.
At the very end they take your left over soup base and make a porridge with it.
This does take time so if you are in a rush to leave you should probably skip this.
It takes time to cook the rice and soup together.
We got spicy miso and sukiyaki base and the spicy miso base was the best!
The sukiyaki was even more sweet than before.
We were lucky the waiter allowed us to get both because he said normally they only do one soup base.
Overall this place is just ok.
Slightly different than any other shabu place I have been too.
Oh I forgot to mention, that the meat comes on the side.
Once the meat is cooked, it shrinks up and looks like a brain!
Please refer to the picture I posted!
The meat looks really gross and creeps me out!
shabu shabu.author: Shauna f.
shabu shabu.review:
This place is just ok. It is very different than any other shabu places I have been to in SF.
First off the waiter, explained the different types of soup bases. Which was nice because there are about 6 different choices to choose from. Once we ordered we waited for our food to arrive. The pots took awhile to come out. When the pots finally came, all the veggies were already inside the pot which was different than any other shabu places. I didn't really like the fact that they put the veggies in the pot for you because you can't control what you want to eat first. It also sucks when you order the seafood option because the seafood is already in the pot when it arrives. The seafood is all done at the same time and you feel like you have to rush to eat the seafood.
The best soup base was the shabu shabu spicy miso. The sukiyaki base was a bit too sweet.
At the very end they take your left over soup base and make a porridge with it. This does take time so if you are in a rush to leave you should probably skip this. It takes time to cook the rice and soup together. We got spicy miso and sukiyaki base and the spicy miso base was the best! The sukiyaki was even more sweet than before. We were lucky the waiter allowed us to get both because he said normally they only do one soup base. 
Overall this place is just ok. Slightly different than any other shabu place I have been too.
Oh I forgot to mention, that the meat comes on the side. Once the meat is cooked, it shrinks up and looks like a brain! Please refer to the picture I posted! The meat looks really gross and creeps me out!

excerpts: I've tried the Shabu Shabu set in the past but the veggies and noodles come on the side.
Meat is always tender and marbled.
At the end of your meal, you choose one broth to turn into a rice soup.
Super yummy as it holds all the flavor of your cooked ingredients.
shabu shabu.author: Cray C.
shabu shabu.review:
You get what you pay for when it comes to quality. Everyone who is complaining about the quantity should remember this isn't Shabu way / shabu club. This is nabe, a whole different type of hot pot. 

Ingredients come already laid out in the pot waiting to be cooked. Sukiyaki and Kimchi's presentation are on point! I've tried the Shabu Shabu set in the past but the veggies and noodles come on the side. Meat is always tender and marbled. At the end of your meal, you choose one broth to turn into a rice soup. Super yummy as it holds all the flavor of your cooked ingredients. NOT for the germaphobes!! 

The price is worth it for the quality of the ingredients and the atmosphere. Will definitely be back.

excerpts: My friend and I tried the sukiyaki and the shabu shabu with spicy miso.
We weren't too crazy for the broth that came with the sukiyaki.
It was really sweet with a hint of tartness.
The spicy miso was great.
All of the sets come with assorted veggies.
The beef and pork was very flavorful and tender.
And at the end of the dinner they make porridge out of the leftover broth.
I thought it was pretty interesting
shabu shabu.author: Tina D.
shabu shabu.review:
I made reservations for Wednesday night and arrived 30 mins early. Luckily it was a weekday so it wasn't too busy. We were seated right away. 

The restaurant is extremely small and narrow.  I didn't even realize I was sitting in front of the restroom. The restroom was covered with a drape so it wasn't uncomfortable.  The restroom has a sliding door which makes sense because the restaurant is so small. 

My friend and I tried the sukiyaki and the shabu shabu with spicy miso.  We weren't too crazy for the broth that came with the sukiyaki. It was really sweet with a hint of tartness.  The spicy miso was great. All of the sets come with assorted veggies. The beef and pork was very flavorful and tender.  And at the end of the dinner they make porridge out of the leftover broth.  I thought it was pretty interesting but i wasn't too crazy for it either. 

The service was attentive. The only problem was that the servers came to us at least three times and ask us the same thing twice. I think that they should find a way to communicate with each other so that they don't ask the customers the same thing twice. 

Overall, it was a good experience.  I will definitely come back to try the kimchi base instead of the sukiyaki.

This is definitely one of those spots.
I had a friend from LA come in last week, so my and my buddy though hey lets

shabu shabu.review:
You are always typically going to pay more for Shabu Shabu in the city, so why not go some place awesome. This is definitely one of those spots. I had a friend from LA come in last week, so my and my buddy though hey lets bring him here.

We called in for a wait time, but even then we still had to wait another 30. A testament to how popular this place can get. It not so bad though as a bar is right next door.

We had really nice and cute server (Nicole i think) and she was really friendly. We had the kimchi broth with pork and the miso broth with beef. Both excellent recommendations. At the end the congee stew to finish off pretty much put us over the top.

I would definitely come back here again.

excerpts: Okay okay, so I'm a shabu shabu snob.
I don't think it's the best shabushabu, as the beef was sliced excessively-thin and wasn't greatly marbled.
I think Shabuway still wins for the meat quality.
Also, this is another one of those places that seems to use watered-down gomadare (sesame sauce) for some reason.
Other than that, though, the meal was great.
Service was surprisingly VERY good, and I like how they will make you porridge at the end of the meal -- something that I haven't found at any other Bay Area shabu places.
I'll definitely be coming back..
but I hope they step up their meat quality game!

excerpts: Since having shabu shabu in Japan, I have been craving it!
shabu shabu.author: Seymour G.
shabu shabu.review:
YES YES YES. 
Extraordinary quality food and very tasty too!! Service was exceptional, very friendly and eager to answer any questions. 

Since having shabu shabu in Japan, I have been craving it! This place filled that void in a big way. 

Come here. Frequently.

excerpts: If I ever have a shabu shabu craving, I would come here.
shabu shabu.author: Janey H.
shabu shabu.review:
I've been to this place twice & can say that it's very good. The portions are good sizes, the prices are reasonable, & the service is very good. All the servers I've interacted with there knows everything about every dish which is excellent. Every one is very friendly & polite which everyone looks for in servers at a restaurant.
The food comes out promptly so there is never a long wait for anything. I've had the kimchee nabe, sukiyaki, & I've tried the duck. All three of those are very flavorful & tasty. I've also ordered the garlic soy edamame, which I would definitely recommend trying. 
For those green tea lovers, the green tea cheesecake is amazing here. Its not super thick cheesecake so it's easy to eat & you can taste the green tea flavor, mmm. The other choice of dessert is butter mochi which is also very good. 
 If I ever have a shabu shabu craving, I would come here.

excerpts: Shabu shabu at its best, good pricing and delicious food.
($18 med broth and $22 for large broth)
This is the hottest spot in town everyone, don't miss out!
shabu shabu.author: Sandra L.
shabu shabu.review:
SO yummy!! 

its a VERY small place but try to call in and reserve a table! I didn't think this tiny place accepted reservations but they do! (I saw there was a table reserved) 

My friend and I just tried the Sukiyaki broth. It's traditionally a cold soup so it'll take awhile to heat up.
It was VERY tasty, a deep flavor..it smells like typical udon soup but it taste very sweet (not in the candy way) and very savory at the same time. SO YUMMY!! It comes with an egg and thats it. But I've seen other people around me where they had ramen come with their order! The beef, no doubt, was very tasty. 

And like everyone else has said, the service is impeccable. The three waitresses rotationally came by every 3 mins or so .. I guess some people might not like it because they really came too often (probably because the restaurant is so small) but nevertheless, they were very attentive and patient in explaining their menu!

My favorite part was the RICE/porridge at the end! If you're not that hungry and you just want to try this place between you and your date, getting a large will fill you guys up. The rice at the end, where they put in another egg, seaweed bits and green onions is so good and filling. I think this broth was a PERFECT pairing with the rice at the end. ..and if you run out of broth, they'll gladly add more water for you and it won't dilute the flavor! 

Shabu shabu at its best, good pricing and delicious food. ($18 med broth and $22 for large broth) This is the hottest spot in town everyone, don't miss out!

excerpts: I won't be driving to San Mateo anymore for shabu shabu.
shabu shabu.author: Sterling P.
shabu shabu.review:
Nabe is beautiful inside and out. Authentic flavors and presentation. 

It's very difficult to find authentic Japanese food in San Francisco. Nabe makes the grade.

We ate the kimchi and kurobuta pork nabemono. Best I've had in the city. I won't be driving to San Mateo anymore for shabu shabu. Sake selection was unique and diverse.

Masa was our server, he was exceptionally attentive and caring during our meal. He made sure our glasses were always full and plates were removed.

Excellent Food, Service and Atmosphere. I'll certainly be back!

excerpts: if you love sukiyaki or shabu shabu or yosenabe or any Japanese stew dish then you'd love nabe!
shabu shabu.author: claudia y.
shabu shabu.review:
if you love sukiyaki or shabu shabu or yosenabe or any Japanese stew dish then you'd love nabe!

my only gripe is that I stink afterwards.  I think the ventilation in there needs some help.

the service is attentive and friendly

the place is cute and clean

the food!  we went straight for half sukiyaki and half duck nabe and both were delicious.  the meat and veggies were super fresh and nicely presented.  afterwards they make a zosui or rice soup with the remaining broth at the table.  it was a tad salty but I could imagine it being really comforting.  because they take the broth after all the boiling, its super concentrated and flavorful, but salty.  I think the zosui from the yosenabe would be yummy.  or they should do a crab hot pot!  yum

excerpts: Nabe's take on Shabu Shabu is refreshing and fun.
shabu shabu.author: Philip K.
shabu shabu.review:
We were actually on our way to Naan N Curry and found Nabe by accident. We stumbled upon a well lit, glass paned and modern looking Japanese Hot Pot restaurant.

Nabe's take on Shabu Shabu is refreshing and fun. With a very trendy decor, comfortable seating and an excellent ventilation system, Nabe provided us a perfect evening for a date night hot pot! 

The Wagyu Beef is super fresh, as is the vegetables that come with our hot pot. Good tasting broth as well. Very clean and great service. Huge selection of Sake for the drinkers out there! Best part of the meal comes at the very end when you are done with your hot pot. The server comes with a bowl of rice and simmers it in the remaining soup broth adding an egg, green onions and dried seaweed turning your leftover soup broth into a delicious porridge!

excerpts: Overall we had an enjoyable shabu shabu experience, one of the best of his kind in San Francisco.

Pros:
- Very good slices of Waygu beef and Kurobuta pork belly
- Good green tea cheesecake and black bean ice cream
- Attentive and friendly service 
- Good sake selection
- Unique touch with the rice porridge cooked at the table at the end of the meal (dinner only)
- Strong ventilation system which we wish other shabu shabu and hot pot restaurants had in place

Cons:
- Despite the strong ventilation, our clothes ended up smelling after the meal
- A few details missing: no chopstick holder, no place to put my cracked egg, paper napkins (simple cloth would fit better with the decor)
- The broths are quite intense (perhaps too much so:
shabu shabu.author: Claudio B.
shabu shabu.review:
Overall we had an enjoyable shabu shabu experience, one of the best of his kind in San Francisco. We will likely come back for more.

Pros:
- Very good slices of Waygu beef and Kurobuta pork belly
- Good green tea cheesecake and black bean ice cream
- Attentive and friendly service 
- Good sake selection
- Unique touch with the rice porridge cooked at the table at the end of the meal (dinner only)
- Strong ventilation system which we wish other shabu shabu and hot pot restaurants had in place

Cons:
- Despite the strong ventilation, our clothes ended up smelling after the meal

- The broths are quite intense (perhaps too much so: the miso that came with the pork was very spicy, the sukiyaki that came with the waygu was very sweet)
- The butter mochi and the red been ice cream are bland and not reccomended

excerpts:
my hands down favorite shabu shabu in san francisco. 
it's more elegant than the other shabu spots in the city. 
i love this as a date or double date night. 
don't forget to ask for the rice dish they create with the extra sauce, meat and veggies at the end of the night. 
i love that as breakfast the next day.
