excerpts: This restaurant has been my first "shabu shabu" experience, and I still don't even know what that means.
The defining difference between this and standard hot pot, to me, is that they make a "porridge" at the end, using rice to soak up your remaining broth and ingredients.
I think I ordered the "shabu shabu" dish both times, and I still felt a bit hungry and gassy until the porridge.
Not the biggest fan of raw egg.
But that's my own bias.
It's obviously top drawer in quality and taste, if this is what you're into.
shabu shabu.author: David S.
shabu shabu.review:
Hot pot tends to leave me hungry, gassy, and broke by the end of the meal. I don't know why I'm such a fan.

Nabe, at least, doesn't leave me hungry. This restaurant has been my first "shabu shabu" experience, and I still don't even know what that means. The defining difference between this and standard hot pot, to me, is that they make a "porridge" at the end, using rice to soak up your remaining broth and ingredients. It's something I could do at home with a $2 bag of rice and a chicken bouillon cube, but I don't mind paying $30 for this restaurant to do it for me.

That's because this place has a sleek, minimalist ambiance, made even better because it's infrequently busy. I can come in here on a weeknight and actually enjoy talking to someone I brought. The servers, bless them, always note my fresh-off-the-boat expression and give my table lots of attention and pointers.

The food has not exactly been my preference on both my trips. I think I ordered the "shabu shabu" dish both times, and I still felt a bit hungry and gassy until the porridge. Not the biggest fan of raw egg. But that's my own bias. It's obviously top drawer in quality and taste, if this is what you're into.

excerpts: So if you plan to come here anytime soon and it's your first time, remember to not get super full from the shabu shabu itself!
- Shabu Shabu with Wagyu beef in spicy miso broth - my bf
and I love anything spicy.
So we had to do a spicy option with something beefy.
This was the perfect combination of the two.
This one is always our go-to broth.
- Seafood Yosenabe - Seafood lover's pick.
shabu shabu.author: Gelene V.
shabu shabu.review:
I've always brought different people here for dinner and they always ask me "When's the next time we're going to Nabe? It's so good!" 

I guess the thing that sets it apart is the end course where they take your leftover broth, put rice, and then add other ingredients to make it into a delicious porridge. So if you plan to come here anytime soon and it's your first time, remember to not get super full from the shabu shabu itself!

Some of my favorite broths include
- Kimchi + Kurobuta Pork Belly - I love how the kimchi spice isn't overpowering all the other flavors in the pot. Plus, I also love the included mochis. Don't put them in the pot for too long, or else it becomes a blob that is so mushy you won't be able to pick it up with any of the provided utensils. 
- Shabu Shabu with Wagyu beef in spicy miso broth - my bf and I love anything spicy. So we had to do a spicy option with something beefy. This was the perfect combination of the two. This one is always our go-to broth.
- Seafood Yosenabe - Seafood lover's pick. Not my favorite since I'd probably choose the above two over seafood, but not a bad choice - especially if you love seafood! 

You can pick additional items to add onto your original broth, so don't feel too limited on a certain choice just because it includes something you like. My advice? Pick your favorite broth, then add the items you like!

This place can get a little pricy since it's more expensive than your traditional hotpot, but trust me.. you'll never leave Nabe still feeling hungry.

excerpts: - Washugyu beef shabu shabu.
Amazing how quickly it cooked in the boiling water.
- Forgetting our shabu shabu accompaniments until we asked.
shabu shabu.author: Jason B.
shabu shabu.review:
Boiling over.

The good.

-  Cool design. Small space with a minimalist Japanese design highlight by upside down sake bottle taps on the wall.

- Washugyu beef shabu shabu. Amazing how quickly it cooked in the boiling water. You were left with a succulent strip of meat that was a joy to consume.

The OK.

- Shrimp, scallops and clam medley in a dashi broth. Wished there was more of the former than the takes effort latter. Pleasantly light overall. Yam noodles were so so.

- Porridge made with leftover broth at the end was different and unique. Too sweet for my tastes by at least it helped justify the $19 - $29 dish price.

The underwhelming.

- Forgetting our shabu shabu accompaniments until we asked.

- Forgetting our check until we asked.

- Forgetting to put a reasonable amount of noodles in each dish. Or perhaps it was the proper quantity. Disappointing either way. Didn't ask.

Much promise but the misses left me boiling like the food. Too many service mistakes to overcome a not very impressive meal. Friendly and trying. But missing.

Walls were the highlight. Walls should never be the highlight.

excerpts: You would expect them to be serving nabe here, but it's actually more like hot pot/shabu shabu.
There's no clay or iron pot in the middle
and it's a split half half metal pot that you find in shabu shabu places.
The place has one long community table, a six person table, and some four people tables.
The community table is large enough to fit a party of 12-14.
One problem with this place is it's not big enough to support all the demand it's getting.
The wait time for this place around dinner can be over an hour long.
Shabu Shabu set was good.
The pork was pretty tasty.
shabu shabu.author: Steven B.
shabu shabu.review:
Nabe is a pretty interesting place with the most misleading name. You would expect them to be serving nabe here, but it's actually more like hot pot/shabu shabu. There's no clay or iron pot in the middle and it's a split half half metal pot that you find in shabu shabu places. The place has one long community table, a six person table, and some four people tables. The community table is large enough to fit a party of 12-14. One problem with this place is it's not big enough to support all the demand it's getting. The wait time for this place around dinner can be over an hour long. Pop in before dinner time and there may be a table free.

== Food ==

Shabu Shabu set was good. The pork was pretty tasty. The broth for this one was kind of sweet which made it pretty nice.

Sukiyaki set was also good. The beef were really tasty, soft, and tender. The spicy miso broth was pretty spicy.

Good amount of veggies that come with the dishes. I like the beef more than the pork due to the texture. The pork was a bit chewy compared to the beef.

The rice finisher is amazing. They put rice into one of the soups and create a porridge from it. The soup soaked in all the beef and veggie flavor so it's pretty amazing. One thing you probably want to do is forget how fatty the soup is.

== Service ==

Service was great here. The waitress, Michelle (name escapes me), was really nice and helpful. Water was refilled once in a while. She came around to explain things and to ask if everything was good.

== Overall ==

4.5 Stars. Great place to go. Long wait times make it hard to grab a table here. The food is expensive, but it is good and the experience is amazing. Definitely a place worth going to, but it seems like a gamble since you might not get a table.

I think.

excerpts: We ordered the traditional shabu shabu and the duck.
The problem was that the duck was raw and came already in the pot with a divider for the shabu shabu on the other side.
You need to keep the temperature up so that you can have your shabu shabu, but within 5 minutes the duck was severely overcooked.
shabu shabu.author: Aly A.
shabu shabu.review:
This spot is really close to my house and I had been dying to see if it was any good.  Unfortunately they made ONE KEY mistake that makes them just a mehhhhh ok place.

We ordered the traditional shabu shabu and the duck.  The problem was that the duck was raw and came already in the pot with a divider for the shabu shabu on the other side.  You need to keep the temperature up so that you can have your shabu shabu, but within 5 minutes the duck was severely overcooked.

The waitress came over and apologized but did nothing.  I dont' see why they didn't give us two pots or give us the raw duck on a place like the other meat.

Anyway, at the end they make some type of rice soup thing which I enjoyed.  Probably would not come back.

excerpts: Pretty good and modern place to get shabu shabu.
The lunch prices are more reasonable than the dinner prices.

With that said, I've tired the beef shabu and sukiyaki here and both are good.

In the sukiyaki order, the vegetables are already in the soup and you cook your beef in the broth as you do for shabu.

shabu shabu.review: Fun experience, a bit pricey, but good for dates and lingering over a shared meal. This is an interactive meal and you will be doing the cooking. Your gratuity will be a flavorful broth, and a great bowl of okayu/porridge at meal's end. I had the sukiyaki - a bit too sweet, wifey had the shabu shabu, and that was great, and what we made the porridge from, per the waitress' reco. The environs are upscale and chic minimal. excerpts: We ended up getting the large "Shabu Shabu" (beef) with an extra side portion of pork belly.
They definitely tried to upsell us to two entrees, but it was a good enough portion of food for two.
I finished the meat and veggies feeling comfortably full but not entirely satisfied.
shabu shabu.author: Jackie L.
shabu shabu.review:
This place is tiny. However, the decor is great (despite the lack of ventilation) and the service is fantastic.

The shabu itself, though, was mediocre and seemed somewhat expensive. We ended up getting the large "Shabu Shabu" (beef) with an extra side portion of pork belly. They definitely tried to upsell us to two entrees, but it was a good enough portion of food for two. I finished the meat and veggies feeling comfortably full but not entirely satisfied. As they started clearing the table, I had a twinge of regret - for just a normal dinner, maybe we should have just gone to Marnee Thai, or San Tung, for cheaper.

BUT THEN. Then, they came and made the Zosui rice soup. It's a rice porridge that's included with your meal, and is made from the leftovers of your hot pot. It took quite a long time (a bit of an art, it seems), and we had a nice conversation with our waitress as she stirred. She finally handed us two heaping bowls and I took a tentative bite... then downed the rest of the bowl in record time. It was AMAZING. We ended up with 3-4 extra servings for leftovers, too -- which makes the aforementioned high price suddenly reasonable.

And that, my friend, is why I will be back to Nabe. Because I need to try all the other flavors of porridge. I'm serious. It's only been a week and I already crave it.

excerpts: i typically go to shabu shabu, which is a type of hot pot (i learned recently).
we had to wait an hour and a half on a chilly, super foggy sunday evening.
shabu shabu.author: Ashleigh R.
shabu shabu.review:
i'm a huge fan of soupy foods. pho, ramen, shabu, thai noodle soup, cioppino. i loves it all. no surprise that i was very interested in this new-ish hot pot place. 

i typically go to shabu shabu, which is a type of hot pot (i learned recently). we had to wait an hour and a half on a chilly, super foggy sunday evening. the staff was sweet though, and called us when our table was ready. 

our server gave us a nice breakdown of the menu, explaining that some items come with everything in the broth, only vegetables in the broth and meat on the side, or everything on the side. very helpful. 

for appetizers, we got the edamame as well as the korobuta sausage with mustard aioli. the edamame was yummy, and had a slightly smoky flavor that we liked. the sausage was delicious and the mustard aioli was a perfect creamy complement to the saltiness of the pork. 

for entrees, my roommate got sukiyaki and i got the kimchi + korobuta pork shoulder. the pork belly would have been a nice option, but i didn't feel like having such a fatty meat that night. our food came quickly, which is good because we were huuungry! i liked the sukiyaki broth much better than mine. the flavor was perfect and complex. also, the raw egg used as a dipping sauce after the meat was cooked, really kicks it up a notch. the kimchi broth wasn't salty enough for me, but after i cooked my pork slices, i dipped them in the accompanying ponzu sauce, which was delicious. ponzu saved the day. i also felt that the meat portion for the regular size was a bit small, considering the price. hmph.

i realized halfway through my meal that i didn't get my savory mochi. the server quickly grabbed it for me and apologized for forgetting. i forgot to mention that earlier, they brought me pork belly instead of shoulder. two small mistakes, but i understand they were really busy. didn't let that ruin my experience.

the end of the meal was, of course, finished off my preparing the rice porridge with the leftover broth. they actually ran out of rice, so he used udon noodles with the sukiyaki broth. heavennnn. by the time we finished, they had prepared more rice, and he made us the proper porridge out of the kimchi broth, too. i liked the kimchi broth a lot more after it had boiled down and became more salty. oh well. 

all in all, i had a great time and yummy food. nabe won't be my regular go-to, as the price point is a bit higher than my usual spot, but i'll be back for that sukiyaki broth!

excerpts: We tried the seasonal duck, spicy miso shabu shabu, kimchi/pork belly, and the Sukiyaki.
shabu shabu.author: Whitney W.
shabu shabu.review:
Went here around 5:30pm on a Monday and it was not busy at all. By the time we finished around 7 there is still plenty of seats available. 

The menu can be slightly confusing so ask the waitress how it works if it's your first time there. Basically you can choose 2 broth in one pot (you pay for each broth; ex. if you have one pot with 2 broth you pay for the 2 broths separately) and you can choose size large or small. The size refers to the amount of meat they give you rather than the pot size.  Since the store is relatively new, most of the staff seem to still be in training so our ordering process was kind of chaotic because we had some difficulty figuring out how to order and the pricing. 

We had 5 girls sharing 4 broths (2 pots, each pot with 2 kinds of broth) and it was a good amount. We each ended up paying $22 dollars (including tax/tip).  We tried the seasonal duck, spicy miso shabu shabu, kimchi/pork belly, and the Sukiyaki. 

1. Spicy Miso- a little spicier than I'd like, came with udon noodles and veggies/meat.Broth is very flavorful.
 
2. Duck- broth tasted like sukiyaki, came with soba noodles and mochi chunks. The duck is very soft and tasty even after boiling for 20 minutes.

3. Kimchi/pork belly: not too spicy or salty, pork belly meat was really good and thinly sliced

4. Sukiyaki- sweat/salty broth, goes well with beef and has jelly noodles in it. 

Quality of the meats are pretty good. Overall broth are pretty heavily flavored.

In the end the staff will add rice/egg, green onion and roasted seaweed to one broth per pot of your choice. They make a congee out of the left over broth. If they ask you how the broth taste, ask them to dilute your broth if you feel like it was on the salty side. We did not know this so we told them broth tasted fine and our congee turned out to be super salty and inedible with the sukiyaki broth. The congee with the kimchi broth was delicious however.

I think there are definitely room for improvement, but given the quality of the food and considering the fact that they just opened, I think they can (and hopefully will)  get better with time.

excerpts: Even though the meat quality isn't as good, Shabu Shabu is not that filling
so I need much more than the servings they give us.
Also, I like eating more veggies and making my own sauce.
For the price I paid, I don't think I would've been very happy if I had come here on a completely empty stomach.
shabu shabu.author: Tiara T.
shabu shabu.review:
3.5 STARS My parents and I were brought here today by my aunt and uncle who are both locals of the bay area. We had originally been planning on going to Mum's across the street from our hotel in Japantown. But, after hearing where we were planning on eating, my uncle insisted we try here because it's just a million times better than Mum's. 

Walked in and first thing we noticed was that the decor is super nice. Very sleek and classy looking (and apparently the guy who designed the place is the same guy who designed my aunt's lounge/club). Waitress is really nice and was very attentive. Probably helped that we got there pretty early for dinner, around 5:30, and the place was still empty. 

Menu: Smaller selection, but they do have different broths including a spicy miso broth, plain seaweed broth, and other soy based broths. We went with the traditional broth, just because we prefer getting the flavor from the ponzu sauce, garlic and green onions. No all you can eat, which is kind of a bummer but the food was still pretty on point.

Food: the quality of the meat was obviously way better than Mum's all-you-can-eat. The Wagyu beef was mouth wateringly tender and the selection of seafood was great (coming with salmon, clams, shrimp, etc.) Veggie were pretty standard: 3 different types of mushrooms, napa cabbage, carrots, tofu, spinach, and udon and clear noodles. One interesting thing was the squash. Never tried that, but it was really good as well. They give you the 2 standard sauces, but one thing I didn't like was that they give you the ponzu sauce already made. I like adding as much garlic, radish, and green onions as I like to my sauce. Also, the portions are not that big. I ordered a regular, and still ate half my mom's plate of beef as well as all the veggies on my plate (I also had just come from an oyster happy hour that included 6 dozen oysters, 2 dungeness crab cocktails, and many cocktails between the 5 of us). For the price, I wasn't about to order more. At the end, they make a porridge out of the broth. Isn't really anything special as much as my uncle tries to hype it up. Just rice, egg, and seaweed, made in the broth from our meat. Was pretty plain, so I mixed the ponzu sauce into it to make it taste better. 

Overall, I still prefer Mum's all-you-can-eat. Even though the meat quality isn't as good, Shabu Shabu is not that filling so I need much more than the servings they give us. Also, I like eating more veggies and making my own sauce. For the price I paid, I don't think I would've been very happy if I had come here on a completely empty stomach.

excerpts: If I were to come here again, I would definitely get shabu shabu.
Kombu, cabbage + beef make a much tastier porridge than sukiyaki.
shabu shabu.author: Margaret S.
shabu shabu.review:
We got kimichee kurobuta bacon and sukiyaki. The sukiyaki was infinitely better. Cooked meat dipped in raw egg=holy moly. 

The rice porridge at the end was too salty and sweet even after our waitress offered to dilute it. BTW, I appreciate the side table service a lot. 

I could really taste the sugar and the mirin from the sukiyaki. I didn't really enjoy it. Bummer~ 

If I were to come here again, I would definitely get shabu shabu. Kombu, cabbage + beef make a much tastier porridge than sukiyaki.

excerpts: The broths have a wide variety of flavors, though I gravitate mostly to the spicy shabu shabu and the sukiyaki.
The zosui rice finish is AWESOME.
shabu shabu.author: Pete H.
shabu shabu.review:
This place is pretty much a weekly stop for me now, and I always bring friends and family from out of town here because of the whole experience. I like a place that keeps things basic and doing everything well, and that's what you get here. I've had every broth on the menu and virtually every side item listed. I'm particularly fond of the duck -- I actually find myself craving it. The broths have a wide variety of flavors, though I gravitate mostly to the spicy shabu shabu and the sukiyaki. The zosui rice finish is AWESOME. A real highlight and fills you up just right. 

Excellent sake menu. Try the one that looks like it's in an oil can. Seriously. I don't remember what it's called. Probably because I barely remember that night. Powerful stuff! 

I'm also a big fan of the staff. Friendly and attentive. My Mum and Dad loved this place -- remarkable considering this definitely isn't their style of food. That puts this place over the top for me. Go and enjoy.

excerpts: because my friend was eating from the sukiyaki/kimchi kurobuta set and our other friends' set which was shabu shabu and seafood).
It was extremely filling and tasted amazing.
Both sukiyaki and kimchi broths were full of flavor and plentiful in assorted veggies (the mushrooms in the sukiyaki broth absorbed all the flavors in the broth which made it even tastier).
The ponzu dipping sauce for the beef made the beef taste even better.
At the end of the meal, the servers make a rice porridge from the broth of your choice (we chose the shabu  shabu broth which was a miso broth).
shabu shabu.author: J L.
shabu shabu.review:
I ate here once with a group of friends, and it was one of the best dinners I have ever eaten. The food here is absolutely amazing.

My friend and I had the sukiyaki and kimchi kurobuta pork belly sets (both in regular), and it was enough to feed 2.5 people (I say .5 because my friend was eating from the sukiyaki/kimchi kurobuta set and our other friends' set which was shabu shabu and seafood). It was extremely filling and tasted amazing. Both sukiyaki and kimchi broths were full of flavor and plentiful in assorted veggies (the mushrooms in the sukiyaki broth absorbed all the flavors in the broth which made it even tastier). The ponzu dipping sauce for the beef made the beef taste even better. At the end of the meal, the servers make a rice porridge from the broth of your choice (we chose the shabu  shabu broth which was a miso broth). I usually don't like rice porridge but this was super delicious porridge, probably because the miso broth was so flavorful.

I most definitely recommend this place and will be coming back soon. So worth every penny.

excerpts: It's great to have a shabu shabu place in the Inner Sunset.
I was stuffed by the time they made the rice porridge.
shabu shabu.author: Jang K.
shabu shabu.review:
The kimchi pork belly shabu was delicious. It's great to have a shabu shabu place in the Inner Sunset. I was stuffed by the time they made the rice porridge. However, it made for an excellent lunch the next day!

It's a little bit on the expensive side. It's also weird that the front windows get all fogged up.

excerpts: lol we always get the shabu shabu with beef and
it's soooooo good!
It's hilarious how someone said that it was "too hot", um hello

It's like me going to a club and complaining about how loud the music is.

shabu shabu.review: I LOVE this place!!!!! Me and my bf love coming here we've basically become regulars lol we always get the shabu shabu with beef and it's soooooo good! It's hilarious how someone said that it was "too hot", um hello how else are you supposed to cook your meat??? It's like me going to a club and complaining about how loud the music is. And yes this isn't the type of restaurant where your done in 30 minutes, were usually here for about an hour which is fine with me.

excerpts: I usually get the shabu shabu with spicy miso brother and wagyu beef.
Don't forget to ask for the sesame sauce to compliment the meat.
One order doesn't look like a lot of food compared to all those all the you can shabu places out there
but with the rice finisher, it gets quite filling.
The rice finisher is like a porridge.
Rice is added to broth to thicken.
An egg is added to the concoction when the stove is turned off.
It is then garnished with green onions and seaweed.
shabu shabu.author: Foodi C.
shabu shabu.review:
One of my favorite Shabu places in SF. At one point, I literally came here 3 times a week! So let's break down what makes this place so successful:

1. The food -- flavorful broth, organic vegetables, grass fed beef
2. The service -- attentive, gives great recommendations, graceful
3. The ambiance -- love the glass wall facing the street. When the place is full and the steam fogs up the glass, the cozy feeling of having eating in front of a simmering pot of goodness is priceless

I usually get the shabu shabu with spicy miso brother and wagyu beef. Don't forget to ask for the sesame sauce to compliment the meat. One order doesn't look like a lot of food compared to all those all the you can shabu places out there but with the rice finisher, it gets quite filling. The rice finisher is like a porridge. Rice is added to broth to thicken. An egg is added to the concoction when the stove is turned off. It is then garnished with green onions and seaweed. If you can't finish it there, it makes a great breakfast for the next day.  

I've also tried the sukiyaki. The broth is slightly sweeter and it comes with the calorie free shirataki noodles. This is a slightly healthier option and equally as delicious.

excerpts: The spicy Kim chee and Shabu Shabu is the way to go!
shabu shabu.author: Sandra T.
shabu shabu.review: Great place! pretty modern a bit small. Came here for a party of 12 they were very accommodating. Service was attentive. The bathroom has a sliding door.. i was confused for a bit! The meat quality in key for me. I'm very picky with my meat.. One amazing treat at the end is the rice porridge, they don't waste your broth with the flavorful meat you put in there! The spicy Kim chee and Shabu Shabu is the way to go!

excerpts: I ordered the Shabu Shabu - with beef and spicy miso broth.
I've had a few different spicy miso at other shabu places but this was probably the most flavorful!
Unlike other shabu places, the spices such as chili oil, garlic, radish, and pepper flakes weren't laid out on the table as condiments -but
you had to ask for it yourself.
Im guessing it's because the place is so small they didn't want to add more clutter.
Also, the sesame goma sauce did not come as a standard so you had to ask for it to get it.
I like adding extra garlic to my sauces and to my broth as well.
I was a little disappointed when I asked for the hot drop and was told that they didn't offer it here.
I looove hot drops -
I feel like it gives my sauce a little kick and makes everything that much more delicious.
Oh well, the meal goes on.
I got a regular and it came with about 12 slices of beef.
The slices are pretty thin but it will fill you up.
Veggie platter consists of the usual: napa cabbage, spinach, enoki and shitaki mushrooms, carrots, tofu, and udon noodles.
Overall everything tasted great.
The broth was delicious, fresh veggies and the meat was tender!
I had a chance to dip some of my meat in my friend's sukiyaki broth and it was good as well!
I don't know if I'm the sweet type to be able to have a whole meal of it -
but if I was sharing with someone I wouldn't mind having both sauces at my mercy.
After the meal you can ask the servers to prepare a porridge for you!
They basically just pour a bowl of rice into your broth, add an egg and green onions, mix it around and throw some seaweed on top ...
but it's delicious!
So simple but tasty
I feel like adopting this tradition at other shabu places!
I'd just have to save my rice to mix into the broth at the end.
I've been to places where they offer to make you udon/noodles at the end of the meal
but I guess this is a little reversed.
Either way, it was a great experience.
The servers are attentive and especially nice.
Definitely a place I would recommend.
shabu shabu.author: Ngan T.
shabu shabu.review:
After hearing many things about Nabe through my friend, I was excited to try it last night for my friend's birthday. Luckily we had a small dinner party because this place was probably one of the tiniest dine-in restaurant I've ever been to!! A long communal table that stretched from the front to the back was placed in the midde, and there were about 3 or 4 separate tables of four to the side. When I first got there I felt like I was walking into the steam room. All the steam from everybody's broth was circulating the air and there seemed to be no ventilation - the only way I felt that air was escaping was through the open front door. The thought of my face/makeup melting off was a little worrying but that wasn't going to keep me from dipping my meats into any pots!

I ordered the Shabu Shabu - with beef and spicy miso broth. I've had a few different spicy miso at other shabu places but this was probably the most flavorful! Unlike other shabu places, the spices such as chili oil, garlic, radish, and pepper flakes weren't laid out on the table as condiments -but you had to ask for it yourself. Im guessing it's because the place is so small they didn't want to add more clutter. Also, the sesame goma sauce did not come as a standard so you had to ask for it to get it. I like adding extra garlic to my sauces and to my broth as well. I was a little disappointed when I asked for the hot drop and was told that they didn't offer it here. I looove hot drops - I feel like it gives my sauce a little kick and makes everything that much more delicious. Oh well, the meal goes on. I got a regular and it came with about 12 slices of beef. The slices are pretty thin but it will fill you up. Veggie platter consists of the usual: napa cabbage, spinach, enoki and shitaki mushrooms, carrots, tofu, and udon noodles. Overall everything tasted great. The broth was delicious, fresh veggies and the meat was tender! I had a chance to dip some of my meat in my friend's sukiyaki broth and it was good as well! I don't know if I'm the sweet type to be able to have a whole meal of it - but if I was sharing with someone I wouldn't mind having both sauces at my mercy. After the meal you can ask the servers to prepare a porridge for you! They basically just pour a bowl of rice into your broth, add an egg and green onions, mix it around and throw some seaweed on top ... but it's delicious! So simple but tasty :) I feel like adopting this tradition at other shabu places! I'd just have to save my rice to mix into the broth at the end. I've been to places where they offer to make you udon/noodles at the end of the meal but I guess this is a little reversed. Either way, it was a great experience. The servers are attentive and especially nice. Definitely a place I would recommend.

excerpts: I order the large Spicy Miso Shabu Shabu with Wagyu Beef.
The spicy miso had very little flavor.
I had to request more spice in order to get it taste like any thing.
The portion of meat was not a lot for a large but it was okay.
The meal came with a brown sauce with onions and maybe garlic.
This was my saving grace to  make a bland meal taste like anything.
I will say that my friend, who order the duck, tasted much better.
Well at least the duck did, I was not a fan of her soup base.
On to The Service - We had reservation, so we were seated right away.
However, the reservation was not needed since the place was pretty empty.
The serve the soup and meat right away.
The meal we order was a set, which also comes with rice and the normal shabu vegetables.
Yet, this was not served right away.
We had to ask twice for the rice.
The first time we ask for the rice, they bring out the vegetables.
After waiting a few minutes we asked again for the rice.
I found this a little weird since the place wasn't busy and I would think bringing the rice and vegetable would be standard practice.
The staff was pleasant enough, but not a lot of interaction (I am fine with this).
Lastly The Price - This place is expensive for what you get.
You could go to an all you can eat Shabu House for the same price and better food.
I would not recommend this place at all.
shabu shabu.author: Yaya H.
shabu shabu.review: I was really excited to try this place, since I love hot pot. However, it was not very good overall. The Food - I order the large Spicy Miso Shabu Shabu with Wagyu Beef. The meal came with a brown sauce with onions and maybe garlic. This was my saving grace to  make a bland meal taste like anything. I will say that my friend, who order the duck, tasted much better. Well at least the duck did, I was not a fan of her soup base. On to The Service - We had reservation, so we were seated right away. However, the reservation was not needed since the place was pretty empty. The serve the soup and meat right away. excerpts: This is my second time trying shabu (first time at Shabu Shabu on Geary) and this place was also very good, but pretty different.
Nabe looks super modern and cool, and has great service.
I got the Beef plate and it was big and the spicy miso broth was delicious.
I liked that
at Shabu House they gave some like kimchi and stuff on the side, but they didn't give anything other than the meat and vegetables here.
But the food was fresh and fantastic.
The best part, which I have never seen before, is the rice porridge they made at the end ( rice, spicy miso broth, raw egg, and onion); it was so good and creamy,
something very new to me.
shabu shabu.author: Nikita K.
shabu shabu.review: This is my second time trying shabu (first time at Shabu Shabu on Geary) and this place was also very good, but pretty different. Nabe looks super modern and cool, and has great service. I got the Beef plate and it was big and the spicy miso broth was delicious. I liked that at Shabu House they gave some like kimchi and stuff on the side, but they didn't give anything other than the meat and vegetables here. But the food was fresh and fantastic. The best part, which I have never seen before, is the rice porridge they made at the end ( rice, spicy miso broth, raw egg, and onion); it was so good and creamy, something very new to me. The only thing I was disappointed with was the dessert, all these reviews said how good the mochi and sesame ice cream is, and I just was not impressed what-so-ever. But regardless, I will be coming back here for sure! Try it out!

excerpts: I will definitely come back here again to try their shabu shabu next!
shabu shabu.author: Stephanie G.
shabu shabu.review: Yay another hot pot place I like besides Shabu House. I came here on a super cold day in SF, so it was perfect for hot pot! This restaurant is pretty small (probably fits around 50 people or less?). The owner who was also our server said it gets pretty packed on the weekends, but you can call ahead of time to put your name on the waiting list. She was super friendly btw! I love restaurants with good service. Anyway, we decided to order the sukiyaki with beef and pork. I wasn't a huge fan of their pork (still good though, just not my fav), but their beef was delicious. Especially dipped in the raw egg, yumm. Also, all the veggies and tofu were already in our soup. We weren't super full by the time we finished our meat and veggies, but when you're finished with your meal they come and serve "The Finisher". Basically, they add rice to your remaining soup to make a porridge out of it! So awesome. They also had scallions and seaweed for the finishing touch. The server will ask you if you want to dilute it and I advise you to do so because heating the soup up again makes it too sweet! At least with the sukiyaki. I will definitely come back here again to try their shabu shabu next!

excerpts: Great for shabu shabu.
I also took my parents here to celebrate their bdays and the employees were great at surprising them with dessert and making the evening very special.
Very great staff and delicious food too.
Keep it up, Nabe!!
shabu shabu.author: Louise C.
shabu shabu.review: The rice porridge at the end was delicious! It's what I look forward to the most when I come here. When I first discovered Nabe, I ate at the restaurant 3x in under 2 weeks. It's SO good! Great for shabu shabu. I also took my parents here to celebrate their bdays and the employees were great at surprising them with dessert and making the evening very special. Very great staff and delicious food too. Keep it up, Nabe!!

excerpts: We had the sukiyaki, shabu shabu, and kamonanban.
The food was excellent; the broths were extremely flavorful and the meat/veggies were super fresh.
Service was fantastic; my water was constantly being refilled.
Cozy, intimate atmosphere.
Food is easy to share; the 3 different dishes fed four of us.
The rice porridge at the end of dinner is really yummy and flavorful as well.
It gets a little steamy in the restaurant, so dress accordingly!
shabu shabu.author: Ashlee C.
shabu shabu.review: We had the sukiyaki, shabu shabu, and kamonanban. The food was excellent; the broths were extremely flavorful and the meat/veggies were super fresh. Service was fantastic; my water was constantly being refilled. Cozy, intimate atmosphere. Food is easy to share; the 3 different dishes fed four of us. The rice porridge at the end of dinner is really yummy and flavorful as well. It gets a little steamy in the restaurant, so dress accordingly!

excerpts: This is our go to place for shabu shabu in the city.
The wifey
and I frequently make the trip from Nob Hill over to Sunset for this place.
You can't go wrong ordering the shabu shabu with waygu beef and spicy miso.
Their sake selection is solid as well.
Enjoy!
shabu shabu.author: Dave H.
shabu shabu.review: This is our go to place for shabu shabu in the city.  The wifey and I frequently make the trip from Nob Hill over to Sunset for this place.  You can't go wrong ordering the shabu shabu with waygu beef and spicy miso.  Their sake selection is solid as well.  Enjoy!

excerpts: My friend brought me here to try shabu shabu.
This is fantastic!
I don't really have anything to compare it to
but I was impressed!
The services is fantastic, its right off of muni and its reasonably priced.
The best part was the massive amount of leftovers that were only better when I ate them for lunch the next day.
shabu shabu.author: Amber M.
shabu shabu.review: My friend brought me here to try shabu shabu. This is fantastic! I don't really have anything to compare it to but I was impressed! The services is fantastic, its right off of muni and its reasonably priced. The best part was the massive amount of leftovers that were only better when I ate them for lunch the next day.

excerpts: It's great shabu shabu.
The staff is very helpful though may be short staffed.
We had two large pots for 3 people and it was plenty.
We tried the Shabu Shabu spicy miso and the Sukiyaki.
Both with Waygu beef which was the best beef for shabu shabu I have had.
I have been to the Henry the VIII, Shabuzen and Shabuway and this ranks as the best.
The prices are pretty good and we loved the porridge at the end.
It was definitely a neat and tasty experience!
shabu shabu.author: Amy C.
shabu shabu.review: It's great shabu shabu. The staff is very helpful though may be short staffed.  We had two large pots for 3 people and it was plenty.  We tried the Shabu Shabu spicy miso and the Sukiyaki.  Both with Waygu beef which was the best beef for shabu shabu I have had.  I have been to the Henry the VIII, Shabuzen and Shabuway and this ranks as the best.  The prices are pretty good and we loved the porridge at the end.  It was definitely a neat and tasty experience!

excerpts: As for the shabu shabu, we ordered the pork belly in kimchi broth and the Washugyu beef in traditional konbu broth.

Apparently these are traditional Japanese pairings but it seemed weird to me that they don't let you choose meats and broths separately because when it comes out you can cook the meat in whichever broth you want.
This was key because even though they told us upfront that the konbu is just water and seaweed, I soon realized that it makes your meat and veges taste exactly like...water and seaweed.
So very quickly I was pretty much cooking everything in the kimchi broth, which I must say was amazingly delicious.
Spicy but flavorful-spicy not just spicy-for-the-sake-of-burning-your-tastebuds.
shabu shabu.author: Aaron G.
shabu shabu.review:
Some friends who live in the Sunset recommended this place so me and my cuz decided to try it out. Got here around 5:30P on a Friday night and we were lucky enough to get a table but the place got crowded quickly. I should really say a part of the table because the center of the restaurant is essentially one really long table with hot pot burners inset .

We started off with the edamame appetizers and they give you a ton a edamame (perfect for me)! As for the shabu shabu, we ordered the pork belly in kimchi broth and the Washugyu beef in traditional konbu broth. Apparently these are traditional Japanese pairings but it seemed weird to me that they don't let you choose meats and broths separately because when it comes out you can cook the meat in whichever broth you want. This was key because even though they told us upfront that the konbu is just water and seaweed, I soon realized that it makes your meat and veges taste exactly like...water and seaweed. So very quickly I was pretty much cooking everything in the kimchi broth, which I must say was amazingly delicious. Spicy but flavorful-spicy not just spicy-for-the-sake-of-burning-your-tastebuds. Meat quality was excellent as well and veges were fresh.

Definitely a nice place to eat on a cold night. Prices are on the higher end but not unreasonable. Missed out on the Zozui rice porridge when we went so guess we'll have to come back!

excerpts: My husband had the shabu shabu with miso broth in a large and was fully satisfied.
(he's a big guy--6'1)
There is only one restroom in the restaurant which is unisex.
The one waitress was VERY busy waiting the tables and she never refilled our waters until we asked.
I wish she refilled the water more
so I deducted a star.
I left the restaurant feeling thirsty...
For my first time having shabu shabu this restaurant is amazing!
I would recommend this restaurant to a friend!
There is a small metered parking lot across from the restaurant which was very convenient.
I should add that I did not have to wait at all to be seated and didn't have a reservation.
shabu shabu.author: Susie L.
shabu shabu.review: I came here to meet with a friend and catch up during lunch (12:30). I went with my husband and daughter as well. My daughter is 3 months so she's in a stroller, and we only have a jogging stroller which is pretty big. Luckily we arrived when there weren't many people so we were seated immediately and were able to snag a seat where the stroller could go next to us. (I don't recommend going here if you have a baby in a stroller as there just isn't much room.) when the place started getting busy and packed (15 mins later), I felt as if the stroller was a nuisance to other customers. I ordered the kimchi broth and it was amazing! If I didn't have a stroller and lived closer to San Fran I would go here again! My husband had the shabu shabu with miso broth in a large and was fully satisfied. (he's a big guy--6'1) There is only one restroom in the restaurant which is unisex. The one waitress was VERY busy waiting the tables and she never refilled our waters until we asked. I wish she refilled the water more so I deducted a star. I left the restaurant feeling thirsty... For my first time having shabu shabu this restaurant is amazing! I would recommend this restaurant to a friend! There is a small metered parking lot across from the restaurant which was very convenient. I should add that I did not have to wait at all to be seated and didn't have a reservation.

excerpts: The decor and ambiance, 5 stars, service-one of the waitress had to come back 4 times to ask additional questions to confirm our simple orders of Shabu Shabu, however, she was cute and personable; therefore, the service was 3 stars, and the food quality was very good but the portion is small,even for the large order.
for $29, I would expect more.
The soup was average.
3 stars-- average 3.5 stars.
shabu shabu.author: SJ L.
shabu shabu.review: The decor and ambiance, 5 stars, service-one of the waitress had to come back 4 times to ask additional questions to confirm our simple orders of Shabu Shabu, however, she was cute and personable; therefore, the service was 3 stars, and the food quality was very good but the portion is small,even for the large order. for $29, I would expect more. The soup was average. 3 stars-- average 3.5 stars.

excerpts: This Hotpot/Shabu Shabu restaurant was offering a huge variety of broths and flavor combinations, but I've mostly stuck to the traditional fare of spicy miso and beef.
Their ingredients are very fresh, the hotpot burners are convenient, and they can even split flavors in a single pot.
I'd really recommend it as a place to go and catch up with friends-
The variety of sides offered with your generic shabu shabu is generous and one of their selling points (tofu, enoki, noodles, pumpkin, spinach, cabbage, carrot).
but it comes with the second portion of rice porridge and more sides than your usual shabu shabu course.
shabu shabu.author: Viva W.
shabu shabu.review:
This Hotpot/Shabu Shabu restaurant was offering a huge variety of broths and flavor combinations, but I've mostly stuck to the traditional fare of spicy miso and beef. Their ingredients are very fresh, the hotpot burners are convenient, and they can even split flavors in a single pot. I'd really recommend it as a place to go and catch up with friends- there's a lot of potential for communal sharing and its easy to chat over the food. 

The variety of sides offered with your generic shabu shabu is generous and one of their selling points (tofu, enoki, noodles, pumpkin, spinach, cabbage, carrot). Their meat is a nice quality and stays buttery soft. 

But lets talk about the best thing- the rice porridge that is made after the meal with the rich broth leftover, egg, and rice. Whipped until its milky- I almost always take home this portion and have it for breakfast. 

The food is a little high-priced for my usual budget- but it comes with the second portion of rice porridge and more sides than your usual shabu shabu course. 

The staff is usually very attentive and informative, very lovely. Sometimes it seems as though they may need one extra person on hand to just help with getting water and helping patrons get their check in a timely manner.

excerpts: I was hooked with their shabu shabu set
but it was their duck set that was life changing.
This stuff is like crack.
The skin is seared nicely and the breast is cut into perfect slices.
It's cooked in a dashi broth (savory soy based) and it simply taste like heaven.
And when things can possibly get better, they make you a rice porridge with your left over broth that'll blow your mind all over again.
Save room for desert though!
shabu shabu.author: Anna Z.
shabu shabu.review: This is a long overdue review. When I first tried this place, I was immediately impressed with their beef quality. If you shabu a lot like me, you'll remember that other places have beef that seemed to fall apart when cooked or turned into a weird gray color. But nabe beef is amazing. It's tender, juicy, and never falls apart even after over cooking. I was hooked with their shabu shabu set but it was their duck set that was life changing. This stuff is like crack. The skin is seared nicely and the breast is cut into perfect slices. It's cooked in a dashi broth (savory soy based) and it simply taste like heaven. And when things can possibly get better, they make you a rice porridge with your left over broth that'll blow your mind all over again. Save room for desert though! The new panna cotta is super creamy and their mochi cake which is served warm with ice cream is delicious. I usually get the duck breast and my BF gets the spicy miso shabu. I think it's one of the best combos ever. Best part is, they take rsvp despite party size! Super plus. Give nabe a try, you won't regret it!

excerpts: Nabe is the best Shabu Shabu place I have been to in the entire bay area.
Their service is amazing, and their food is even better.
I definitely recommend it if you are craving good Shabu Shabu.
shabu shabu.author: Gerardo A.
shabu shabu.review: Nabe is the best Shabu Shabu place I have been to in the entire bay area. Their service is amazing, and their food is even better. I definitely recommend it if you are craving good Shabu Shabu.

excerpts: Got the sukiyaki and shabu shabu.
More upscale ambiance than some of the other hot pot places, but I thought it was pricier and not as tasty as some of the other hot pot/shabu shabu places.
I'd go to hot pot garden over this place.
shabu shabu.author: Caroline D.
shabu shabu.review: Got the sukiyaki and shabu shabu. More upscale ambiance than some of the other hot pot places, but I thought it was pricier and not as tasty as some of the other hot pot/shabu shabu places. I'd go to hot pot garden over this place.

excerpts: I ordered a Large Shabu Shabu for $16.
She said the different between small and large ($13 vs. $16) was 5 oz or 7 oz of meat.
No.
Freaking.
Way was it 7 oz.
I got 8 paper thin slices of beef that shredded every time I tried to pick it up with my chopsticks.
I know they're supposed to be thin, but I doubt it was weighed before giving to us.
The cold tofu w/ kim chee was good, but didn't arrive until half the table was already eating their shabu and
my end of the table hadn't gotten anything (I ordered first, and don't want to sound like a diva but somehow got my food
last when we all ordered the same thing).
We were all still hungry afterward
so we went to Sheng Kee around the corner.

washugyu beef.author: Cherylynn N.
washugyu beef.review:
4.5 STARS

The Winter Blues.

For 60 hours, I didn't leave the house much less leave my bed (too bad it wasn't one of those "marathon" sessions). I don't/can't sleep so all I did was watch awesomely terrible Lifetime movies and eat Tyson buffalo wings and Kimchi ramen bowls.

Nothing was going to get me to leave the house. Nothing.

That was until I heard there was a new shabu joint that opened in The Sets.

*Furiously grabs baby wipes and sprays dry shampoo all over*

Hey, don't judge. 

My friends and I came to Nabe on Friday night with reservations. Thankfully, we made reservations because it was packed.

F O O D
Nabe offers Nabemono shabu set meals with additional a la carte meat and seafood options. No AYCE is available. All ingredients are organic and locally sourced. No MSG is used in any of the broths.

Each shabu set is paired with a specific broth that will best complement the type of meat. 

*Sukiyaki: Washugyu Beef with Warishita Broth
*Kinaka Nabe: Assorted Japanese Mushrooms in Miso Broth
*Kimchi & Kurobuta Pork Belly: Pork Belly with Kimchi Miso Broth
*Shabu Shabu with Traditional Konbu or Spicy Miso Broth
*Seafood Yosenabe: Shrimp, Salmon, Scallops, and Asari Clams in Dashi Broth

You have a choice of Regular ($18 for 8oz) or Large ($22 for 12oz); more for the seafood option. A veggie platter with udon noodles is included with each set.

Our group's Nabemono Sukiyaki & Shabu Shabu Sets: http://bit.ly/UEmCVg

My pick was the traditional konbu which is clear broth with seaweed (http://bit.ly/UEmQvI). There's not much flavoring to it but it allows you to enjoy the natural beefiness of the well-marbled washugyu beef (http://bit.ly/UEmZz3). The accompanying sesame paste with bonito and ponzu sauce were deliciously mouth-watering and full of umami flavors (http://bit.ly/UEn7yK).

However, when I got a taste of Mr. NSS' Warishita broth (Sukiyaki set), I was in shabu heaven (http://bit.ly/UEndGE). The delicious broth imparted a savory sweetness into the beef that was addicting that I abandoned my own pot. I loved the accompanying raw egg that added a layer of creaminess.

Saving the best for last is the Zosui. After your broth has been well-seasoned from the meat swishing, they add, rice, egg, nori and green onions to your broth to make a Japanese porridge (http://bit.ly/UEnh9o). The Zosui using the Warishita broth was so comforting and oh so good.

S E R V I C E
Friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable. Wendy, our waitress always had a smile on her face and did a good job explaining the Nabemono shabu concept to us thoroughly since it was new to us. I appreciated that they asked for feedback at the end of our meal. Always a good sign from new business owner(s). 

Service was a tad slow and it took awhile to get our broth pots but it was opening week and all.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
The swankiest shabu place in the city with minimalist black walls lined with wooden sake dispensers (http://bit.ly/UEnqcX). My only gripe is the place is small and tight (formerly Good Earth Cuisine) with just 2 communal tables and 3 small tables.

P A R K I N G
Good luck. Your best bet finding street parking is 2 blocks down on Lincoln near GG park.

With soul warmed and my tummy filled (ok, busting out from my spanx), I was glad I finally left the house to shabu my winter blues away!

excerpts: My PDC family ordered 2 regular sets: the SUKIYAKI (Washugyu beef with a sweet Warishita broth) and the SHABU SHABU (Washugyu beef or Kurobuta pork with either traditional konbu or spicy miso broth).

Our order came with 3 plates, one for each of the meats (15 slices of thinly sliced, beautifully marbled beef: http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZwBukC0KhMXJKbmaNfKPFw/l.jpg, forgot to take a picture of the pork, oops) and another for the combined vegetables and udon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oENOdFCIcUrOqzm1cSXdgg/l.jpg).
Since the sukiyaki set came with Washugyu beef, we opted for the Kurobota pork in spicy miso broth, per my big's recommendation.
When our pot came to our table, the vegetables were already swimming in it (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9Zp7qpP_MynVcMIw3wA0TQ/l.jpg).
This gave the scallions, mushrooms, tofu, cabbage, carrots, chrysanthemum leaves, and these spotted, slightly-crunchy, translucent noodles more time to cook.

washugyu beef.author: Adele F.
washugyu beef.review:
2 regular nabemono shabu sets shared among 3 people is more than enough, mostly due to the Zosui rice that they add to your broth after your hot-potting is done. It's like two meals in one!

A new hotpot restaurant in Inner Sunset that opened only 3 weeks ago? Hot damn! Cherylynn's review is so thorough that I don't need to bother with all the details. I just want to note that the nabemono sets include meat/seafood, noodles, and assorted vegetables paired with a broth. Your meal ends with a Zosui rice soup using the flavored broth from the cooking. Pricing is $18 per person for a regular portion, $22 per person for a large portion.

They also have a seasonal nabemono winter set called Kamonanban, which includes duck breast and Tokyo negi with Dashi broth, regular $23 and large $28.

Our group of 9 entered the restaurant around 5:30 PM without a reservation, and we were lucky to nab the long communal table in the back. The restaurant can only seat 32, so I would definitely recommend a reservation during normal dining hours. Service is good, with multiple waitresses running around checking on things, refilling water, and asking if the group is ready for the Zosui rice. However, the entire endeavor is a bit time-consuming given the ingredient preparation, table stove heating, and rice porridge finale. Our group was there for TWO HOURS. Crazy.

My PDC family ordered 2 regular sets: the SUKIYAKI (Washugyu beef with a sweet Warishita broth) and the SHABU SHABU (Washugyu beef or Kurobuta pork with either traditional konbu or spicy miso broth). Our order came with 3 plates, one for each of the meats (15 slices of thinly sliced, beautifully marbled beef: http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZwBukC0KhMXJKbmaNfKPFw/l.jpg, forgot to take a picture of the pork, oops) and another for the combined vegetables and udon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oENOdFCIcUrOqzm1cSXdgg/l.jpg). The vegetable/udon plate came with chopped cabbage, baby spinach leaves, a few slices of squash, two slabs of tofu, enoki mushrooms, a quartered shiitake mushroom, a few carrot pieces in cute shapes, and udon noodles. To be honest, I wish they gave more vegetables because spinach severely shrinks :(

Since the sukiyaki set came with Washugyu beef, we opted for the Kurobota pork in spicy miso broth, per my big's recommendation. When our pot came to our table, the vegetables were already swimming in it (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9Zp7qpP_MynVcMIw3wA0TQ/l.jpg). This gave the scallions, mushrooms, tofu, cabbage, carrots, chrysanthemum leaves, and these spotted, slightly-crunchy, translucent noodles more time to cook. We added the meats on par with our consumption; I enjoyed the beef and pork equally :)

Regarding the broths, I definitely preferred the sukiyaki's Warishita. The sweetened soy base adds subtle undertones to the hot pot ingredients, although the spicy miso adds that kick most people enjoy with their meat. The sukiyaki also comes with a raw egg that you crack into a bowl and dip your meat and vegetables in. So strange! I loved the added creaminess hehe. Screw Salmonella.

After all is eaten, a waitress scoops out some of your broth and adds in some rice to make this delicious porridge chock full of hot pot flavor. You can choose to split your rice between the two broths or have it half-half. We asked for half-half, and she let the rice sit for 5 or so minutes before returning to stir in the beaten egg, nori, and green onions. I definitely would vouch for the Warishita broth over the spicy miso broth because at the end of the stewing, the savoriness of the boiled ingredients blends harmoniously with the innate sweetness of the broth.

Max 4-way credit card split, and make sure to let them know before the ring things up. Also, they have one bathroom hidden behind a curtain. It has a weird sliding door...

All in all, I would recommend 2 regular nabemono sets to be shared among 3 people. Both the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU sets were fantastic, although I have a preference for the sukiyaki's broth and raw egg dip. I liked both the beef and the pork, and the beef is exceptionally marbled. And don't forget the Zosui rice porridge at the end! You're getting a real bang for your buck here ;)

Also, shout-out to the best family out there!

washugyu beef.review:
Overall: 4/5 
What can I say, I love my shabu shabu and this place really is delicious. The staff is attentive and friendly despite the fact of how busy it gets. What caught my eye is the special porridge that they make at the end with the leftovers from your broth. However, what wowed me was the sesame sauce that they had, it was perfection. I would definitely come back again, Nabe's porridge and sesame sauce has a place in my heart! 

I came here after I called in asking if there was a wait. Shabu house had over a hour wait and luckily, Nabe said they had a table for two! Unfortunately when we arrived, the table that they thought would leave was still sitting there and ordered another plate... So we had to wait for around 15 minutes before we could get seated. It wasn't the servers fault since we did only call in and of course no promises were made without an reservation. 

Once inside, the restaurant was TINY! There was a long table that ran down the middle of the restaurant with just a few tables on the side. I would've hated having to sit in the middle tables with a bunch of strangers all cramped up. Fortunately, my friend and I were seated in the tables on the side. But let's talk about the space (reason I took off a star)! There was barely any room for anyone to walk through and the servers had a hard time squeezing in between everyone as well. Also, I know the decor is simple and they want to keep it to a minimal given the size of the restaurant but I found it a by weird how no condiments were offered or set on the table.... 

I ordered the Shabu Shabu with the regular size Washugyu beef $19 (large $24.00) with traditional konbu (comes with a plate of veggies and udon). The traditional konbu is just water with seaweed so don't order it if you don't like a plain base! I like my broth plain so I could taste the real flavor of my beef and this was just right up my ally. But what came next was the sesame sauce and this was THE real game changer! I added this to my broth along with garlic and ahh, I was so in love!!! This sauce alone will make me come back and regarding the garlic, don't forget to ask for it or condiments because they don't have it set out nor do they mention it unless asked! 

Let's talk about that porridge though, so on point! Towards the end of the meal, a server will ask if you're ready for their porridge that is whipped up on the spot from one of your leftover broths. From there, the server will add a bowl of rice and set the heat to high. After a while, they will add some green onions, turn off the heat, and immediately mix it in with an egg. The end result is a nice, thick creamy consistency topped off with some shredded seaweed and voila, porridge is served! What an AMAZING and smart way to use up the remainder of the pot. Thank you Nabe for giving me such an amazing experience!

Nabe, Inner Sunset's new Japanese hot-pot restaurant opened on Friday 12/21/12. Nabe is a nabemono hot-pot restaurant with a clean modern decor. They have surely drawn a crowd with their wonderful choices of broth and high quality organic, locally sourced produce.

While Nabe is a bit small on size (32 seats), it's big on "high quality" flavors. It's a must try!

- Kimchi + Kurobuta Pork Belly - Berkshire pork belly with Kimchi Aka Miso broth
* Traditional Nabe pairings, includes meat/seafood, broth, accompanied by noodles and assorted vegetables, finished with Zosui rice soup. [Reg 18., Lrg 22]

Be sure to save room for the Zosui rice soup at the end; it comes with an egg, seaweed, green onions, and your choose of which soup to put it in. - For parties of 6 or more, call in for reservations.

The Good: Savory flavored soups, delicious food, and Zosui rice soup!

The Bad: Waiting 1 hour on a Friday night while watching everyone sitting at the tables eating and salivating away.

washugyu beef.review:
Boiling over.

The good.

-  Cool design. Small space with a minimalist Japanese design highlight by upside down sake bottle taps on the wall.

- Washugyu beef shabu shabu. Amazing how quickly it cooked in the boiling water. You were left with a succulent strip of meat that was a joy to consume.

The OK.

- Shrimp, scallops and clam medley in a dashi broth. Wished there was more of the former than the takes effort latter. Pleasantly light overall. Yam noodles were so so.

- Porridge made with leftover broth at the end was different and unique. Too sweet for my tastes by at least it helped justify the $19 - $29 dish price.

The underwhelming.

- Forgetting our shabu shabu accompaniments until we asked.

- Forgetting our check until we asked.

- Forgetting to put a reasonable amount of noodles in each dish. Or perhaps it was the proper quantity. Disappointing either way. Didn't ask.

Much promise but the misses left me boiling like the food. Too many service mistakes to overcome a not very impressive meal. Friendly and trying. But missing.

Walls were the highlight. Walls should never be the highlight.

excerpts: The food was excellent, the thinly sliced washugyu beef was very tender and flavorful.
We also had an order of the seafood mix which had a great variety of seafood options which included salmon, clams, shrimp and scallops.
The seasonal special was a duck breast which was very good but be sure not to cook the duck too long, the water can boil quick and the duck can get over cooked.
It comes crusted on the skin side but the rest of the duck is rare until they turn on the electric burner on.
The broth is came with was very good, wasn't too salty.
It also came with a small dish of cold soba noodles which compliment the salt form the broth and duck very nicely.
My favorite was the kimchee pork belly, the pork belly was cut very thin and had great flavor and tenderness.
The kimchee wasn't overpowering and added a nice flavor and seasoning to the vegetables and meat.
washugyu beef.author: Darren W.
washugyu beef.review:
Nabe has a very small menu, but they focus on high quality ingredients.  They do shabu a bit different here, they call it Nabemono but its practically the same thing.  Most shabu restaurants I've been to usually bring out the soup and the uncooked ingredients on a plate.  At Nabe they already put everything in the pot, with the flavored broth.  They do have one dish, called Shabu, where you do put the ingredients in yourself.  The food was excellent, the thinly sliced washugyu beef was very tender and flavorful.  We also had an order of the seafood mix which had a great variety of seafood options which included salmon, clams, shrimp and scallops.  The seasonal special was a duck breast which was very good but be sure not to cook the duck too long, the water can boil quick and the duck can get over cooked.  It comes crusted on the skin side but the rest of the duck is rare until they turn on the electric burner on.  The broth is came with was very good, wasn't too salty.  It also came with a small dish of cold soba noodles which compliment the salt form the broth and duck very nicely.  My favorite was the kimchee pork belly, the pork belly was cut very thin and had great flavor and tenderness.  The kimchee wasn't overpowering and added a nice flavor and seasoning to the vegetables and meat.  The most interesting item that came with the pork belly was the mochi.  It comes in a separate dish and it really hard but once its cooked in the broth, it becomes very chewy.  All the dishes come with vegetables by the way.  

BE SURE TO SAVE ROOM AT THE END...when you're finished eating all the meat and vegetables, they use the leftover broth, pour some cooked rice to create this awesome porridge.  They take out whatever left over ingredients in the broth (if you are too full to eat them), pour the cooked rice in the broth, let it come to a boil until it thickens a little bit.  Then they pour a raw egg, seaweed and green onions as it all comes together to create a very flavorful porridge, a nice way to end a meal on.  If it's too salty for you, they can add more rice or water to balance it out for you.  If you're too full to eat the porridge, you can also take it home and it will taste just as good the following day.  Great way to make use of all the leftover food and ingredients when most shabu places tend to waste a lot of leftover food and some even charge when there is an all you can eat option. Since you get this porridge at the end, the meals don't come with rice.  You will have to order it on the side but I was fine without it.  

Staff was extremely friendly and helpful, they were very prompt on refilling my teacup.  Decor was very nice but this is a very small place.  I think they could use a better ventilation system, the windows got all foggy and it was a little steamy inside. It is on the pricier side of Shabu/Hot Pot places, but the menu is different and more unique in my opinion.  I also feel the quality is top notch and above the rest of the shabu places I've been to.  This has become one of my favorite places to eat shabu/hot pot and I'm positive I'll be back soon.

kurobuta pork.review:
Steam billows throughout the dining room, fogging up the floor-to-ceiling glass windows, as expectant diners line up out the door. Nabe is clean, trendy, and offers up high-quality Japanese hot pot. The service is attentive and the broths delicious. Arriving early on a Friday evening, my group was seated right away, but by the time we left, the place was packed and people were waiting out the door!

I tried the seafood yosenabe, which came with tons of seafood--shrimp, salmon, scallops, clams, and harusame (cellophane) noodles and tons of veggies like napa cabbage, mushrooms, pumpkin, and spinach. I also had the shabu shabu pot with a spicy miso broth and thin slices of tender Kurobuta pork, udon, and more veggies--both of these were fantastic, and though the portion sizes weren't huge, I found them to be just enough, and the quality of the ingredients was great! Each diner also had a little bowl of dipping sauce for the meats, which was the perfect complement. My only complaint was that the broths tended to be a little on the salty side (which is not too atypical). After the meal is done, you select one of the broths, and the server uses it to make a complementary rice porridge with egg and dressed with scallions on top--delicious!

Overall, Nabe was a fantastic Japanese hot pot restaurant--though the prices are by no means cheap, I'd definitely recommend giving this place a try. Come early or make a reservation to avoid the waits!

Ambiance could be better... There's a loooooooooooong communal table in the middle and a few tables on the side. LUCKILY my bestie and I got our own table to the side. I would've hated to catch up in between a bunch of strangers. They use the space to the fullest extent... like there's barely any room for the waiters to move around AND it's a fucking sauna in there. It's so funny cuz the glass windows literally steam up and you can't see anything outside. Ok on the important part... the food.

You order a set of broth and meat and choose regular or large. The sets come with the items listed plus assorted veggies, noodles, and rice. You can also add veggies and more meat for an additional fee. I thought that the sets provided more than enough. For a party of 2, order these two sets to share... perfect combination!

+ Sukiyaki (wagyu beef and shirataki in warishita broth) - I liked their sukiyaki. Sometimes it can be TOO sweet or salty, but theirs is just right. Wagyu beef is super on point... really great quality. I highly recommend this set.

+ Shabu shabu (wagyu beef/kurobuta pork and udon in radition konbu, miso, or spicy miso) - get this with wagyu beef and SPICY MISO. I've had spicy miso at other locations and this one is by far the best spicy miso shabu I've ever had. I HIGHLY recommend. Again the wagyu beef is great and I don't think I'd ever stray from beef with shabu. 

+ porridge - What's different about Nabe that I really enjoyed was the porridge they make for you at the end of your meal. They simply ask you to choose a broth, add rice and condiments, and voila... delicious. 

Ask for their ponzu and goma sauce because I don't think they don't serve it automatically with your set. AND be sure to ask for garlic, green onions, daikon, and chili oil/powder (if you like spice) to add to each sauce. 

Nabe is missing one important ingredient - hot drops to add to the sauce. Every shabu spot in SoCal has this and it is a key component. LUCKILY we brought our own so the lack of it didn't kill our experience lol. Nabe, I suggest looking into it. 

I'm hoping they expand in the near future. This spot has so much potential.

excerpts: I ordered the regular sized ($19) shabu shabu with kurobuta pork with spicy miso broth.
The order came with napa cabbage, spinach, pumpkin, shiitake mushrooms, tofu, udon, shimeji mushrooms, carrots, and a plate of kurobuta pork.
kurobuta pork.author: Victoria H.
kurobuta pork.review:
My friend & I came to Nabe to try their shabu shabu. I ordered the regular sized ($19) shabu shabu with kurobuta pork with spicy miso broth. The order came with napa cabbage, spinach, pumpkin, shiitake mushrooms, tofu, udon, shimeji mushrooms, carrots, and a plate of kurobuta pork. The only difference between the regular and large size shabu is the amount of meat that is provided. 

The shabu shabu itself was average. I have had much better shabu elsewhere. However, after our meal, we were offered to have porridge with the leftover spicy miso broth and it was amazing. The waitress put in two bowls of rice into the leftover broth, turned the heat up, let it cook for a couple minutes, and slowly started taking some of the broth out so it wouldn't be soupy. She also added a scrambled egg, green onions and seaweed. My friend & I were pleasantly surprised at how amazingly delicious this was. However, I would most likely not return to Nabe for shabu. I'd return to try the sukiyaki and to have the porridge, but that's it.

excerpts: Anyway, I ordered the Sukiyaki with beef and my date for the evening ordered the Spicy Miso broth with Kurobuta Pork.
kurobuta pork.author: Yi Z.
kurobuta pork.review:
Checked out Nabe with my Babe (oh, never mind, I realized that doesn't rhyme and I don't think my friend likes it when I make advances on her).

It was Saturday night and we were hungry. I wasn't in the mood to go to an ultra trendy restaurant in the Mission or wherever they are these days. Who has the time to wait in line for 2 hours? Nabe seemed like great comfort food for a cool SF evening. 

We were able to score free street parking easily and were seated right away. We thought that the free filtered water was awesome and it was brought out in pretty frosted glass bottles (I know, it's a random observation).

Anyway, I ordered the Sukiyaki with beef and my date for the evening ordered the Spicy Miso broth with Kurobuta Pork. The meat was of high quality and the portion size for the veggies was generous for a Japanese shabu shabu place. My side of the pot took quite some time to heat up since all of the veggies had already been dumped into the broth. I think the Spicy Miso broth was better tasting the Sukiyaki broth. I really enjoyed the rice porridge that was made using the leftover Spicy Miso broth at the end. That was probably the best part of the entire meal.

I also really enjoyed eavesdropping on the people behind us who were on a first date. The girl giggled so much and the guy seemed to be having a good time. I wonder if they are going on a second date.

excerpts: On the SHABU SHABU side, we went with the Spicy Miso broth over their traditional Kombu and opted for the Kurobuta Pork over getting more beef.
Between its more savory flavor and slight kick, I thought the Spicy Miso was the better of the two we had.
Can't argue with the Kurobuta Pork either!
kurobuta pork.author: Mike L.
kurobuta pork.review:
Considering where it is (9th Ave), how long they've been open (it's been a while), the food (it's pretty good), and the fact that it's shabu (shabu!), I'm really surprised Nabe only has 109 reviews.  I mean, TPumps probably had that many after two weeks and they aren't nearly as good!  Granted, there's a slight difference in what they serve, but still!

Unlike other shabu joints, Nabe doesn't offer an AYCE option (which might be why they get less traffic).  However, the menu does offer several appetizers and Nabemono sets, which each include a plate of meat and vegetables (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#jAuLiyN-WUPGbLsAKTkbbA).  To start our meal, the three of us shared an order of the KUROBUTA GYOZA ($7).  The filling was pretty tasty and I liked the accompanying chili sauce, but I thought the skin could have used a harder crust (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#S79V2u3V_0n3JhZSB02q6A).

For our dinner set, we decided to share a large 50/50 pot ($24) of Sukiyaki and Shabu Shabu (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#MhOerOo7cXe4vkZrU31rww).  The SUKIYAKI side came with a Warishita broth and a plate of Wagyu Beef.  Although it was a little light and sweeter than what I would normally go for, it balanced out the rest of the meal pretty well.  Not mind blowing, but solid.

On the SHABU SHABU side, we went with the Spicy Miso broth over their traditional Kombu and opted for the Kurobuta Pork over getting more beef.  Between its more savory flavor and slight kick, I thought the Spicy Miso was the better of the two we had.  Can't argue with the Kurobuta Pork either!  So good (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#J3qUCdFHz-k2gbf5qREluw).

To cap off the meal, we were served Nabe's signature Zosui rice soup (I don't know of any other place in SF that does it).  Utilizing the remainder of our Spicy Miso broth, our server mixed in an egg, rice, green onions, and nori to create a delicious jook-like soup.  Although it was a little salty, it was delicious!  Almost made us wish we had left more of the meat and veggies in the pot (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/nabe-san-francisco-3?select=IrM7BJW5wN_xU4PtKKmbBg#Xy2B_bzJWTb2zn2AVA2bLw).

Despite the fact they won't replace Shabu House as my favorite spot for shabu in SF (or anywhere), Nabe is more than a sufficient alternative to mix things up a bit.  Not I hope Nabe doesn't get TOO busy in the future...

excerpts: The kurobuta pork and the sukiyaki were the standout items.
While we had four pots total, I did not relish that we were only allowed to make rice porridge using our choice of one of the broths.
kurobuta pork.author: David C.
