The meat and broth was delicious, but navigating the dishes around made me feel like I was playing tetris again.  The kurobuta pork and the sukiyaki were the standout items.  While we had four pots total, I did not relish that we were only allowed to make rice porridge using our choice of one of the broths.

excerpts: *Kimchi & Kurobuta Pork Belly:
Pork Belly with Kimchi Miso Broth
kurobuta pork.author: Cherylynn N.
kurobuta pork.review:
4.5 STARS

The Winter Blues.

For 60 hours, I didn't leave the house much less leave my bed (too bad it wasn't one of those "marathon" sessions). I don't/can't sleep so all I did was watch awesomely terrible Lifetime movies and eat Tyson buffalo wings and Kimchi ramen bowls.

Nothing was going to get me to leave the house. Nothing.

That was until I heard there was a new shabu joint that opened in The Sets.

*Furiously grabs baby wipes and sprays dry shampoo all over*

Hey, don't judge. 

My friends and I came to Nabe on Friday night with reservations. Thankfully, we made reservations because it was packed.

F O O D
Nabe offers Nabemono shabu set meals with additional a la carte meat and seafood options. No AYCE is available. All ingredients are organic and locally sourced. No MSG is used in any of the broths.

Each shabu set is paired with a specific broth that will best complement the type of meat. 

*Sukiyaki: Washugyu Beef with Warishita Broth
*Kinaka Nabe: Assorted Japanese Mushrooms in Miso Broth
*Kimchi & Kurobuta Pork Belly: Pork Belly with Kimchi Miso Broth
*Shabu Shabu with Traditional Konbu or Spicy Miso Broth
*Seafood Yosenabe: Shrimp, Salmon, Scallops, and Asari Clams in Dashi Broth

You have a choice of Regular ($18 for 8oz) or Large ($22 for 12oz); more for the seafood option. A veggie platter with udon noodles is included with each set.

Our group's Nabemono Sukiyaki & Shabu Shabu Sets: http://bit.ly/UEmCVg

My pick was the traditional konbu which is clear broth with seaweed (http://bit.ly/UEmQvI). There's not much flavoring to it but it allows you to enjoy the natural beefiness of the well-marbled washugyu beef (http://bit.ly/UEmZz3). The accompanying sesame paste with bonito and ponzu sauce were deliciously mouth-watering and full of umami flavors (http://bit.ly/UEn7yK).

However, when I got a taste of Mr. NSS' Warishita broth (Sukiyaki set), I was in shabu heaven (http://bit.ly/UEndGE). The delicious broth imparted a savory sweetness into the beef that was addicting that I abandoned my own pot. I loved the accompanying raw egg that added a layer of creaminess.

Saving the best for last is the Zosui. After your broth has been well-seasoned from the meat swishing, they add, rice, egg, nori and green onions to your broth to make a Japanese porridge (http://bit.ly/UEnh9o). The Zosui using the Warishita broth was so comforting and oh so good.

S E R V I C E
Friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable. Wendy, our waitress always had a smile on her face and did a good job explaining the Nabemono shabu concept to us thoroughly since it was new to us. I appreciated that they asked for feedback at the end of our meal. Always a good sign from new business owner(s). 

Service was a tad slow and it took awhile to get our broth pots but it was opening week and all.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
The swankiest shabu place in the city with minimalist black walls lined with wooden sake dispensers (http://bit.ly/UEnqcX). My only gripe is the place is small and tight (formerly Good Earth Cuisine) with just 2 communal tables and 3 small tables.

P A R K I N G
Good luck. Your best bet finding street parking is 2 blocks down on Lincoln near GG park.

With soul warmed and my tummy filled (ok, busting out from my spanx), I was glad I finally left the house to shabu my winter blues away!

excerpts: My PDC family ordered 2 regular sets: the SUKIYAKI (Washugyu beef with a sweet Warishita broth) and the SHABU SHABU (Washugyu beef or Kurobuta pork with either traditional konbu or spicy miso broth).

Our order came with 3 plates, one for each of the meats (15 slices of thinly sliced, beautifully marbled beef: http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZwBukC0KhMXJKbmaNfKPFw/l.jpg, forgot to take a picture of the pork, oops) and another for the combined vegetables and udon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oENOdFCIcUrOqzm1cSXdgg/l.jpg).
Since the sukiyaki set came with Washugyu beef, we opted for the Kurobota pork in spicy miso broth, per my big's recommendation.
When our pot came to our table, the vegetables were already swimming in it (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9Zp7qpP_MynVcMIw3wA0TQ/l.jpg).
This gave the scallions, mushrooms, tofu, cabbage, carrots, chrysanthemum leaves, and these spotted, slightly-crunchy, translucent noodles more time to cook.
Both the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU sets were fantastic, although I have a preference for the sukiyaki's broth and raw egg dip.
I liked both the beef and the pork, and the beef is exceptionally marbled.
And don't forget the Zosui rice porridge at the end!
kurobuta pork.author: Adele F.
kurobuta pork.review:
2 regular nabemono shabu sets shared among 3 people is more than enough, mostly due to the Zosui rice that they add to your broth after your hot-potting is done. It's like two meals in one!

A new hotpot restaurant in Inner Sunset that opened only 3 weeks ago? Hot damn! Cherylynn's review is so thorough that I don't need to bother with all the details. I just want to note that the nabemono sets include meat/seafood, noodles, and assorted vegetables paired with a broth. Your meal ends with a Zosui rice soup using the flavored broth from the cooking. Pricing is $18 per person for a regular portion, $22 per person for a large portion.

They also have a seasonal nabemono winter set called Kamonanban, which includes duck breast and Tokyo negi with Dashi broth, regular $23 and large $28.

Our group of 9 entered the restaurant around 5:30 PM without a reservation, and we were lucky to nab the long communal table in the back. The restaurant can only seat 32, so I would definitely recommend a reservation during normal dining hours. Service is good, with multiple waitresses running around checking on things, refilling water, and asking if the group is ready for the Zosui rice. However, the entire endeavor is a bit time-consuming given the ingredient preparation, table stove heating, and rice porridge finale. Our group was there for TWO HOURS. Crazy.

My PDC family ordered 2 regular sets: the SUKIYAKI (Washugyu beef with a sweet Warishita broth) and the SHABU SHABU (Washugyu beef or Kurobuta pork with either traditional konbu or spicy miso broth). Our order came with 3 plates, one for each of the meats (15 slices of thinly sliced, beautifully marbled beef: http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZwBukC0KhMXJKbmaNfKPFw/l.jpg, forgot to take a picture of the pork, oops) and another for the combined vegetables and udon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oENOdFCIcUrOqzm1cSXdgg/l.jpg). The vegetable/udon plate came with chopped cabbage, baby spinach leaves, a few slices of squash, two slabs of tofu, enoki mushrooms, a quartered shiitake mushroom, a few carrot pieces in cute shapes, and udon noodles. To be honest, I wish they gave more vegetables because spinach severely shrinks :(

Since the sukiyaki set came with Washugyu beef, we opted for the Kurobota pork in spicy miso broth, per my big's recommendation. When our pot came to our table, the vegetables were already swimming in it (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9Zp7qpP_MynVcMIw3wA0TQ/l.jpg). This gave the scallions, mushrooms, tofu, cabbage, carrots, chrysanthemum leaves, and these spotted, slightly-crunchy, translucent noodles more time to cook. We added the meats on par with our consumption; I enjoyed the beef and pork equally :)

Regarding the broths, I definitely preferred the sukiyaki's Warishita. The sweetened soy base adds subtle undertones to the hot pot ingredients, although the spicy miso adds that kick most people enjoy with their meat. The sukiyaki also comes with a raw egg that you crack into a bowl and dip your meat and vegetables in. So strange! I loved the added creaminess hehe. Screw Salmonella.

After all is eaten, a waitress scoops out some of your broth and adds in some rice to make this delicious porridge chock full of hot pot flavor. You can choose to split your rice between the two broths or have it half-half. We asked for half-half, and she let the rice sit for 5 or so minutes before returning to stir in the beaten egg, nori, and green onions. I definitely would vouch for the Warishita broth over the spicy miso broth because at the end of the stewing, the savoriness of the boiled ingredients blends harmoniously with the innate sweetness of the broth.

Max 4-way credit card split, and make sure to let them know before the ring things up. Also, they have one bathroom hidden behind a curtain. It has a weird sliding door...

All in all, I would recommend 2 regular nabemono sets to be shared among 3 people. Both the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU sets were fantastic, although I have a preference for the sukiyaki's broth and raw egg dip. I liked both the beef and the pork, and the beef is exceptionally marbled. And don't forget the Zosui rice porridge at the end! You're getting a real bang for your buck here ;)

Also, shout-out to the best family out there!

excerpts:
Ordered:
- Kurobuta pork & wagyu beef sets (large for both)
- sets came with veggies as well
- Soup bases:
kurobuta pork.author: Denise K.
kurobuta pork.review:
I came here with my boyfriend and the food was very tasty.

Ordered:
- Kurobuta pork & wagyu beef sets (large for both) - sets came with veggies as well
- Soup bases: Sukiyaki & spicy miso

Overall, the food was good and the meat quality was very tasty as well. Both kinds of meat had just the right amount of marbling (meat vs. fat), so when you cooked it in the broth, it wasn't too dry and not too fatty. 

Unique element:
After you've devoured your meat, veggies, and noodles, they make this rice porridge for you with the broth of your choice. We chose to do it with our spicy miso broth. The server came to the table and combined the following with the broth:
- egg
- rice
- green onions
- seaweed

This porridge was very hearty and a great way to end your meal. My boyfriend and I were already really full, but couldn't get enough of this.

The only downside about this place is that it gets super steamy and it'll make the restaurant pretty warm inside, so don't wear anything that'll make you hot easily.

Service:
They were very attentive and this alone would encourage me to come back to this restaurant again.

excerpts: I got the Kimchi soup with Kurobuta Pork - so so good.
Really flavorful broth and the pork was really good quality.
kurobuta pork.author: Steph S.
kurobuta pork.review:
YUM. I've recently taken a liking to Japanese Hot Pot/Shabu Shabu and this place is really really good!  So happy it's nearby. 

They have some AWESOME flavors for different broths or soups as well as a huge variety of veggies to add.  I got the Kimchi soup with Kurobuta Pork - so so good. Really flavorful broth and the pork was really good quality. They also do a cool rice soup at the end with the leftover broth if you want something else after you're done ... if you have room. 

Overall, I loved this place. Small, steamy, but super yummy if you're craving soup on a cold day :)

excerpts: and I got the kimchi hot pot with kurobuta pork belly and mochi.
We also got a side of rice (one split between the two of us), harusame noodles, tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and duck (the side order of duck which was $16 isn't listed on the menu).
They also have the sesame dipping sauce, which we also asked for as well as it isn't automatically given to you.
The ponzu sauce was more tart than other places I've been too
but I thought it was great.
I really liked the flavors of both broths and the pork and the beef portions were pretty decently sized.
kurobuta pork.author: Jennifer J.
kurobuta pork.review:
Came here recently with my dad since we've been trying to try out all the hot pot places in the city. After looking through the pictures of the place on Yelp, we decided to make a reservation which turned out to be a good idea because right when we got to the place there was already a table waiting for us. The staff were very friendly and nice and answered all our questions regarding the menu.

The food was really good in my opinion. My dad got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef with miso (not spicy) broth and I got the kimchi hot pot with kurobuta pork belly and mochi. We also got a side of rice (one split between the two of us), harusame noodles, tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and duck (the side order of duck which was $16 isn't listed on the menu). They also have the sesame dipping sauce, which we also asked for as well as it isn't automatically given to you. The ponzu sauce was more tart than other places I've been too but I thought it was great. I really liked the flavors of both broths and the pork and the beef portions were pretty decently sized. Though neither of us thought the side order of duck was worth it, it was an interesting try. 

The best part of the meal for me was the zosui rice soup. They take rice, a beaten egg, and green onions and throw it into your broth that you cooked all your food in (in this case we had a choice between miso and kimchi, and we chose miso). They serve it in your individual bowls and top it with nori strips. I didn't really know what to expect but it ended up being very flavorful (even though it was the miso broth and not the kimchi broth) and I ate the whole bowl even though I was pretty full from the main meal. When you get the soup it is BLAZING HOT so take your time eating it... and don't worry if you don't finish everything in the pot! They'll give you the rest in a take-out container.

The atmosphere of the place is what's bringing down the rating to 4 stars. It's a small place and everyone is having hot pot, so of course it was hot and a bit stuffy. When we walked in my dad mentioned that his glasses fogged up, and maybe it's better right when they open, but I thought it smelled kind of sweaty. It was great that we made a reservation because we had a table for two in the corner of the restaurant (I'm not a fan of sharing my space and sitting next to strangers).

Their bathroom is pretty nice inside. The door is a sliding door which even though I thought was pretty cool, was pretty embarrassing when I was standing outside the bathroom door for longer than 15 seconds trying to figure to whether there was someone in there or not.

Overall our meals ended up being pretty pricey (no thanks to the side of duck) but I'd come back again.

excerpts: We got the Kimchi broth with kurobuta pork, large side of beef, garlic soy edamame, and extra mushrooms.
Everything was very good and fresh!
kurobuta pork.author: Thatcher H.
kurobuta pork.review:
I'm so happy my friend recommended this place to me! 

If you are craving shabu but want to be more adventurous ... then this is the place to go! Nabe is a small and modern. We came here on a Sunday night and didn't have to wait! We were greeted and seated immediately. Our waitress was very helpful. She explained the menu gave us some suggestions. 

After we ordered, our food came out pretty quickly. Our waitress explained what each dish was.

We got the Kimchi broth with kurobuta pork, large side of beef, garlic soy edamame, and extra mushrooms. Everything was very good and fresh! The broth had just the right amount of spiciness. 

After we finished, our waitress came to make the zosui (japanese rice porridge) with our leftover broth. They can take out your chunks of vegetables and meat or leave them in. We chose to leave them in. You can tell them how thick you want it! They add egg and other different ingredients such as, green onions. You have the option to choose from the selection they have! You would think that it would be awkward with your waitress stirring for 5 minutes at your table but it wasn't. Our waitress was friendly and nice! 

Overall, I had a great experience here. This has become one of my favorite shabu places in the city! 

I want to come back to try their different broths!

excerpts: My go to sets are the Kamonanban (duck) and the Shabu Shabu (w/ the Wagyu beef or the Kurobuta pork belly).
But you really can't go wrong with any of them!
kurobuta pork.author: My L.
kurobuta pork.review:
Oh Nabe...how I love all your wonderful nabemono combinations! My go to sets are the Kamonanban (duck) and the Shabu Shabu (w/ the Wagyu beef or the Kurobuta pork belly). But you really can't go wrong with any of them! All the meats and veggies are great quality and really fresh! 

Another must is the Kurobuta Sausage starter. Great texture, nice bite of the casing and just super savory yumminess. Beware as you take your first bite as I've some across come squirters! *giggles*

And the Zosui rice finisher is a thoughtful way to end your meal. It's crazy comfort food and a wonderful way to not waste the delicious broth!

Lastly, the staff and owner round out all the reasons why this is one of favorite restaurants in SF. Courteous and attentive, while not being overbearing. 

I love introducing my friends to Nabe when they are craving shabu and are looking for something different from the usual. And everyone always walks out loving it as well!

Love you Nabe! I feel a shabu craving coming on so I will be seeing you guys soon!

excerpts: Kimchi kurobuta pork belly with kimchi miso broth - if you like a spicy kick in your soup, go for it!
pork belly is thin-sliced, easy to cook and very tender!
Sukiyaki with wagyu beef and warishita broth
- it's a much lighter and sweeter soup with a variety of vegetables.
kurobuta pork.author: Mindy C.
kurobuta pork.review:
Oh how I love shabu...

My love for shabu is unconditional. I want it all day everyday, rain or shine, day or night... No, seriously!
Nabe is not the usual shabu shabu places you can find a dozen in the richmond district. Nabe offers the authentic nabemono shabu sets that's carefully chosen and prepared based on the soup base and the flavor of the meat.

Appetizer
Edamame with sea salt and garlic sauce - get your appetite going!
Gyoza - pan-fried dumplings with ponzu sauce
Kurobuta sausages with mustard aioli - sweet and delicious! 

Kimchi kurobuta pork belly with kimchi miso broth - if you like a spicy kick in your soup, go for it! pork belly is thin-sliced, easy to cook and very tender!
Sukiyaki with wagyu beef and warishita broth - it's a much lighter and sweeter soup with a variety of vegetables. Absolutely refreshing! 

Keep in mind, they don't offer AYCE but a set of nabe or shabu shabu is more than enough for my tummy, and trust me, I have a big appetite for a girl! (And I'm not ashamed of it!)

Don't order rice with your shabu set because at the end of your meal you will regret it! After you are finished with your meat and vegetable set, Nabe offers the zosui - they put a bowl of rice, an raw egg, nori, green onions into the flavorful soup to make rice porridge. I'm a person who loves to drink a bowl of the soup which contains all the nutrition and flavor from the vegetables and meat. I typically love to cook my udon in the soup and have that as the last bite of my shabu shabu. But after I discovered zosui, I could care less about the udon! I absolutely love zosui! The raw egg makes the soup a little creamier for the taste and you get a bowl of heaven(for me at least)! That is my favorite part of the meal! 

Never disappoint! Ok, I'm hungry now thinking about the wagyu beef, the pork belly and the zosui! Maybe I'll have that for dinner tonight! 

The service at Nabe is great! The waitresses there are attentive and friendly. :) Thanks Nabe!
Parking is tough - street parking or you can try the parking lot right across the street. It is Irving st, just be patient. Make a reservation, it'll definitely be easier!

Enjoy! xoxo

excerpts: It comes with your choice of wagyu beef or Kurobuta pork, udon, and an assortment of veggies, all nicely cut and of good quality.
My only gripes would be that you have to ask for rice instead of it being given automatically, and that they charge for shungiku.
kurobuta pork.author: Elaine W.
kurobuta pork.review:
Nabe is aptly named, as it lives up to its name in serving high quality Japanese style hotpot. It is very very cosy and a good place for a laidback dinner with a couple of friends. I wouldn't recommend coming with more than a group of four because this place is tiny. We waited about 40 minutes and there were only one or two groups ahead of us.

All of us ordered the shabu shabu; it comes with your choice of spicy miso, regular miso, or kombu broth. I opted for the kombu; they give a good amount of kombu whereas other places I've been will only give a tiny square to flavor the broth. The shabu shabu is $14 for lunch and $20 for dinner. It comes with your choice of wagyu beef or Kurobuta pork, udon, and an assortment of veggies, all nicely cut and of good quality. My only gripes would be that you have to ask for rice instead of it being given automatically, and that they charge for shungiku. I think for an authentic shabu shabu joint, at least a couple leaves of shungiku should be automatic. Anyways, the meat was pretty high quality, tender, and cooks very quickly. The ponzu sauce was really delicious, the sesame sauce just so-so. I like the bottled goma-shabu I can buy at the supermarket better to be honest. However, the rice finisher at the end is really a nice touch and a perfect end to the meal. The 33 oz Asahi is a perfect pairing with all of this too.

All in all I had a very good meal. I took one star off because of the above issues, and because of the lack of waiting area; the entrance door pushes inwards so it's easy to hit people who are waiting indoors. Also, the ventilation is really poor so it's just really stuffy and humid in the restaurant. However, I would definitely come back for some quality shabu shabu.

Nabe, Inner Sunset's new Japanese hot-pot restaurant opened on Friday 12/21/12. Nabe is a nabemono hot-pot restaurant with a clean modern decor. They have surely drawn a crowd with their wonderful choices of broth and high quality organic, locally sourced produce.

While Nabe is a bit small on size (32 seats), it's big on "high quality" flavors. It's a must try!

Food Ordered:

- Sukiyaki - Washugyu beef with Warishita broth
- Kimchi + Kurobuta Pork Belly - Berkshire pork belly with Kimchi Aka Miso broth
* Traditional Nabe pairings, includes meat/seafood, broth, accompanied by noodles and assorted vegetables, finished with Zosui rice soup. [Reg 18., Lrg 22]

Both of the broth's were amazing! The Warishita broth had a nice sweet savory taste, while the Miso broth had a spicy kick that was just right (medium). The Washugyu beef and Kurobuta Pork belly were tasty and even came with their own dipping sauce! Be sure to save room for the Zosui rice soup at the end; it comes with an egg, seaweed, green onions, and your choose of which soup to put it in. My wife and I chose to put it in our Warishita broth which we thought came out perfect.

Quick Tips:

- For parties of 6 or more, call in for reservations.

The Good: Savory flavored soups, delicious food, and Zosui rice soup!

The Bad: Waiting 1 hour on a Friday night while watching everyone sitting at the tables eating and salivating away.

kurobuta pork.review:
Meaning to try them ever since I saw them under construction, I finally had a chance to drop by two months ago, sharing a split pot of their kurobuta pork belly with kimchi broth, and kamonanban (duck breast with dashi broth) with a friend [ Photo: http://instagram.com/p/YhLxG9Qfrq/ ].

Nabe is a bit unlike the other hotpot places around the city, neither serving up AYCE hotpot, nor individual portions accompanied by too many side vegetables. Instead, most of what you're going to have is already in the pot, with the exception of the mochi and rice sides. And, after you're done with your meats, rather than noodles, you can have them use one of the remaining broths to make zosui (rice porridge/congee).

Okay food overall, with nothing standing out in particular. And their zosui, unfortunately, is unbearably salty, unlike other places I've been to that offer this. Your choice of broth will certainly have something to do with this, but my recommendation is to have the zosui made, and then packed to go so you can dilute it back at home with more rice and water/plain stock. Can't let that food go to waste, after all! But, while Nabe is not a bad choice, I personally will probably stick with some of the other hotpot options around the city.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Semi-accessible, from what I recall. The seats up near the entrance are somewhat accessible, but the walkways to the back are narrow enough when there aren't customers that it's near impossible when there ARE customers.

Bathroom - I didn't check them out, but given the above issue with narrow walkways, you'd have a hard time getting to them, even if they were accessible.

I came here two times as the first time was for lunch and little did I know that they do not offer the post-shabu porridge(Zosui Finisher) during lunch and only for dinner.

Both times, we ordered the same, half kimchi broth w/kurobuta pork and Shabu Shabu with Wagyu Beef, both of which were excellent. The kimchi broth already comes with all the veggies within the broth whereas the Shabu Shabu provided you a platter of veggies for you to cook at your own pace. We also ordered a side of clams in case the food was not enough.

The portions were just right for 2 people and I enjoyed being able to try two different broths and two different styles of cooking but ultimately, we enjoyed the kimchi broth the most so when it came time for the Zosui Finisher, we chose the kimchi broth.

I wish all shabu places in the city provided a Zosui Finisher as it is the ultimate way to have a flavorful porridge in case you were still hungry. I will definitely be back here for more especially with their cool decor of empty customer sake bottles hung all over the walls.

Food Highlight: Zosui Finisher with the KimChi Broth

P.S. - The bathroom is hidden behind curtains in the middle of the room along the wall so make sure to ask before walking towards/into the kitchen lol

Some of my favorite broths include

Don't put them in the pot for too long, or else it becomes a blob that is so mushy you won't be able to pick it up with any of the provided utensils. 
- Shabu Shabu with Wagyu beef in spicy miso broth - my bf and I love anything spicy. So we had to do a spicy option with something beefy. This was the perfect combination of the two. This one is always our go-to broth.
- Seafood Yosenabe - Seafood lover's pick. Not my favorite since I'd probably choose the above two over seafood, but not a bad choice - especially if you love seafood! 

You can pick additional items to add onto your original broth, so don't feel too limited on a certain choice just because it includes something you like. My advice? Pick your favorite broth, then add the items you like!

This place can get a little pricy since it's more expensive than your traditional hotpot, but trust me.. you'll never leave Nabe still feeling hungry.

kurobuta pork.review:
I ate here once with a group of friends, and it was one of the best dinners I have ever eaten. The food here is absolutely amazing.

My friend and I had the sukiyaki and kimchi kurobuta pork belly sets (both in regular), and it was enough to feed 2.5 people (I say .5 because my friend was eating from the sukiyaki/kimchi kurobuta set and our other friends' set which was shabu shabu and seafood). It was extremely filling and tasted amazing. Both sukiyaki and kimchi broths were full of flavor and plentiful in assorted veggies (the mushrooms in the sukiyaki broth absorbed all the flavors in the broth which made it even tastier). The ponzu dipping sauce for the beef made the beef taste even better. At the end of the meal, the servers make a rice porridge from the broth of your choice (we chose the shabu  shabu broth which was a miso broth). I usually don't like rice porridge but this was super delicious porridge, probably because the miso broth was so flavorful.

I most definitely recommend this place and will be coming back soon. So worth every penny.

4.5 STARS

The Winter Blues.

For 60 hours, I didn't leave the house much less leave my bed (too bad it wasn't one of those "marathon" sessions). I don't/can't sleep so all I did was watch awesomely terrible Lifetime movies and eat Tyson buffalo wings and Kimchi ramen bowls.

Nothing was going to get me to leave the house. Nothing.

That was until I heard there was a new shabu joint that opened in The Sets.

*Furiously grabs baby wipes and sprays dry shampoo all over*

Hey, don't judge. 

My friends and I came to Nabe on Friday night with reservations. Thankfully, we made reservations because it was packed.

F O O D
Nabe offers Nabemono shabu set meals with additional a la carte meat and seafood options. No AYCE is available. All ingredients are organic and locally sourced. No MSG is used in any of the broths.

Each shabu set is paired with a specific broth that will best complement the type of meat. 

*Sukiyaki: Washugyu Beef with Warishita Broth
*Kinaka Nabe: Assorted Japanese Mushrooms in Miso Broth
*Kimchi & Kurobuta Pork Belly: Pork Belly with Kimchi Miso Broth
*Shabu Shabu with Traditional Konbu or Spicy Miso Broth
*Seafood Yosenabe: Shrimp, Salmon, Scallops, and Asari Clams in Dashi Broth

You have a choice of Regular ($18 for 8oz) or Large ($22 for 12oz); more for the seafood option. A veggie platter with udon noodles is included with each set.

Our group's Nabemono Sukiyaki & Shabu Shabu Sets: http://bit.ly/UEmCVg

My pick was the traditional konbu which is clear broth with seaweed (http://bit.ly/UEmQvI). There's not much flavoring to it but it allows you to enjoy the natural beefiness of the well-marbled washugyu beef (http://bit.ly/UEmZz3). The accompanying sesame paste with bonito and ponzu sauce were deliciously mouth-watering and full of umami flavors (http://bit.ly/UEn7yK).

However, when I got a taste of Mr. NSS' Warishita broth (Sukiyaki set), I was in shabu heaven (http://bit.ly/UEndGE). The delicious broth imparted a savory sweetness into the beef that was addicting that I abandoned my own pot. I loved the accompanying raw egg that added a layer of creaminess.

Saving the best for last is the Zosui. After your broth has been well-seasoned from the meat swishing, they add, rice, egg, nori and green onions to your broth to make a Japanese porridge (http://bit.ly/UEnh9o). The Zosui using the Warishita broth was so comforting and oh so good.

S E R V I C E
Friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable. Wendy, our waitress always had a smile on her face and did a good job explaining the Nabemono shabu concept to us thoroughly since it was new to us. I appreciated that they asked for feedback at the end of our meal. Always a good sign from new business owner(s). 

Service was a tad slow and it took awhile to get our broth pots but it was opening week and all.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
The swankiest shabu place in the city with minimalist black walls lined with wooden sake dispensers (http://bit.ly/UEnqcX). My only gripe is the place is small and tight (formerly Good Earth Cuisine) with just 2 communal tables and 3 small tables.

P A R K I N G
Good luck. Your best bet finding street parking is 2 blocks down on Lincoln near GG park.

With soul warmed and my tummy filled (ok, busting out from my spanx), I was glad I finally left the house to shabu my winter blues away!

kurobuta pork belly.review:
Came here recently with my dad since we've been trying to try out all the hot pot places in the city. After looking through the pictures of the place on Yelp, we decided to make a reservation which turned out to be a good idea because right when we got to the place there was already a table waiting for us. The staff were very friendly and nice and answered all our questions regarding the menu.

The food was really good in my opinion. My dad got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef with miso (not spicy) broth and I got the kimchi hot pot with kurobuta pork belly and mochi. We also got a side of rice (one split between the two of us), harusame noodles, tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and duck (the side order of duck which was $16 isn't listed on the menu). They also have the sesame dipping sauce, which we also asked for as well as it isn't automatically given to you. The ponzu sauce was more tart than other places I've been too but I thought it was great. I really liked the flavors of both broths and the pork and the beef portions were pretty decently sized. Though neither of us thought the side order of duck was worth it, it was an interesting try. 

The best part of the meal for me was the zosui rice soup. They take rice, a beaten egg, and green onions and throw it into your broth that you cooked all your food in (in this case we had a choice between miso and kimchi, and we chose miso). They serve it in your individual bowls and top it with nori strips. I didn't really know what to expect but it ended up being very flavorful (even though it was the miso broth and not the kimchi broth) and I ate the whole bowl even though I was pretty full from the main meal. When you get the soup it is BLAZING HOT so take your time eating it... and don't worry if you don't finish everything in the pot! They'll give you the rest in a take-out container.

The atmosphere of the place is what's bringing down the rating to 4 stars. It's a small place and everyone is having hot pot, so of course it was hot and a bit stuffy. When we walked in my dad mentioned that his glasses fogged up, and maybe it's better right when they open, but I thought it smelled kind of sweaty. It was great that we made a reservation because we had a table for two in the corner of the restaurant (I'm not a fan of sharing my space and sitting next to strangers).

Their bathroom is pretty nice inside. The door is a sliding door which even though I thought was pretty cool, was pretty embarrassing when I was standing outside the bathroom door for longer than 15 seconds trying to figure to whether there was someone in there or not.

Overall our meals ended up being pretty pricey (no thanks to the side of duck) but I'd come back again.

excerpts: My go to sets are the Kamonanban (duck) and the Shabu Shabu (w/ the Wagyu beef or the Kurobuta pork belly).
But you really can't go wrong with any of them!
kurobuta pork belly.author: My L.
kurobuta pork belly.review:
Oh Nabe...how I love all your wonderful nabemono combinations! My go to sets are the Kamonanban (duck) and the Shabu Shabu (w/ the Wagyu beef or the Kurobuta pork belly). But you really can't go wrong with any of them! All the meats and veggies are great quality and really fresh! 

Another must is the Kurobuta Sausage starter. Great texture, nice bite of the casing and just super savory yumminess. Beware as you take your first bite as I've some across come squirters! *giggles*

And the Zosui rice finisher is a thoughtful way to end your meal. It's crazy comfort food and a wonderful way to not waste the delicious broth!

Lastly, the staff and owner round out all the reasons why this is one of favorite restaurants in SF. Courteous and attentive, while not being overbearing. 

I love introducing my friends to Nabe when they are craving shabu and are looking for something different from the usual. And everyone always walks out loving it as well!

Love you Nabe! I feel a shabu craving coming on so I will be seeing you guys soon!

Sukiyaki with wagyu beef and warishita broth

kurobuta pork belly.author: Mindy C.
kurobuta pork belly.review:
Oh how I love shabu...

My love for shabu is unconditional. I want it all day everyday, rain or shine, day or night... No, seriously!
Nabe is not the usual shabu shabu places you can find a dozen in the richmond district. Nabe offers the authentic nabemono shabu sets that's carefully chosen and prepared based on the soup base and the flavor of the meat.

Appetizer
Edamame with sea salt and garlic sauce - get your appetite going!
Gyoza - pan-fried dumplings with ponzu sauce
Kurobuta sausages with mustard aioli - sweet and delicious! 

Kimchi kurobuta pork belly with kimchi miso broth - if you like a spicy kick in your soup, go for it! pork belly is thin-sliced, easy to cook and very tender!
Sukiyaki with wagyu beef and warishita broth - it's a much lighter and sweeter soup with a variety of vegetables. Absolutely refreshing! 

Keep in mind, they don't offer AYCE but a set of nabe or shabu shabu is more than enough for my tummy, and trust me, I have a big appetite for a girl! (And I'm not ashamed of it!)

Don't order rice with your shabu set because at the end of your meal you will regret it! After you are finished with your meat and vegetable set, Nabe offers the zosui - they put a bowl of rice, an raw egg, nori, green onions into the flavorful soup to make rice porridge. I'm a person who loves to drink a bowl of the soup which contains all the nutrition and flavor from the vegetables and meat. I typically love to cook my udon in the soup and have that as the last bite of my shabu shabu. But after I discovered zosui, I could care less about the udon! I absolutely love zosui! The raw egg makes the soup a little creamier for the taste and you get a bowl of heaven(for me at least)! That is my favorite part of the meal! 

Never disappoint! Ok, I'm hungry now thinking about the wagyu beef, the pork belly and the zosui! Maybe I'll have that for dinner tonight! 

The service at Nabe is great! The waitresses there are attentive and friendly. :) Thanks Nabe!
Parking is tough - street parking or you can try the parking lot right across the street. It is Irving st, just be patient. Make a reservation, it'll definitely be easier!

Enjoy! xoxo

kurobuta pork belly.review:
Meaning to try them ever since I saw them under construction, I finally had a chance to drop by two months ago, sharing a split pot of their kurobuta pork belly with kimchi broth, and kamonanban (duck breast with dashi broth) with a friend [ Photo: http://instagram.com/p/YhLxG9Qfrq/ ].

Nabe is a bit unlike the other hotpot places around the city, neither serving up AYCE hotpot, nor individual portions accompanied by too many side vegetables. Instead, most of what you're going to have is already in the pot, with the exception of the mochi and rice sides. And, after you're done with your meats, rather than noodles, you can have them use one of the remaining broths to make zosui (rice porridge/congee).

Okay food overall, with nothing standing out in particular. And their zosui, unfortunately, is unbearably salty, unlike other places I've been to that offer this. Your choice of broth will certainly have something to do with this, but my recommendation is to have the zosui made, and then packed to go so you can dilute it back at home with more rice and water/plain stock. Can't let that food go to waste, after all! But, while Nabe is not a bad choice, I personally will probably stick with some of the other hotpot options around the city.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Semi-accessible, from what I recall. The seats up near the entrance are somewhat accessible, but the walkways to the back are narrow enough when there aren't customers that it's near impossible when there ARE customers.

Bathroom - I didn't check them out, but given the above issue with narrow walkways, you'd have a hard time getting to them, even if they were accessible.

kurobuta pork belly.review:
I've always brought different people here for dinner and they always ask me "When's the next time we're going to Nabe? It's so good!" 

I guess the thing that sets it apart is the end course where they take your leftover broth, put rice, and then add other ingredients to make it into a delicious porridge. So if you plan to come here anytime soon and it's your first time, remember to not get super full from the shabu shabu itself!

Some of my favorite broths include
- Kimchi + Kurobuta Pork Belly - I love how the kimchi spice isn't overpowering all the other flavors in the pot. Plus, I also love the included mochis. Don't put them in the pot for too long, or else it becomes a blob that is so mushy you won't be able to pick it up with any of the provided utensils. 
- Shabu Shabu with Wagyu beef in spicy miso broth - my bf and I love anything spicy. So we had to do a spicy option with something beefy. This was the perfect combination of the two. This one is always our go-to broth.
- Seafood Yosenabe - Seafood lover's pick. Not my favorite since I'd probably choose the above two over seafood, but not a bad choice - especially if you love seafood! 

You can pick additional items to add onto your original broth, so don't feel too limited on a certain choice just because it includes something you like. My advice? Pick your favorite broth, then add the items you like!

This place can get a little pricy since it's more expensive than your traditional hotpot, but trust me.. you'll never leave Nabe still feeling hungry.

kurobuta pork belly.author: J L.
kurobuta pork belly.review:
I ate here once with a group of friends, and it was one of the best dinners I have ever eaten. The food here is absolutely amazing.

My friend and I had the sukiyaki and kimchi kurobuta pork belly sets (both in regular), and it was enough to feed 2.5 people (I say .5 because my friend was eating from the sukiyaki/kimchi kurobuta set and our other friends' set which was shabu shabu and seafood). It was extremely filling and tasted amazing. Both sukiyaki and kimchi broths were full of flavor and plentiful in assorted veggies (the mushrooms in the sukiyaki broth absorbed all the flavors in the broth which made it even tastier). The ponzu dipping sauce for the beef made the beef taste even better. At the end of the meal, the servers make a rice porridge from the broth of your choice (we chose the shabu  shabu broth which was a miso broth). I usually don't like rice porridge but this was super delicious porridge, probably because the miso broth was so flavorful.

I most definitely recommend this place and will be coming back soon. So worth every penny.

kurobuta pork belly.review:
Although I am no expert in nabemono, I thought that this new Inner Sunset restaurant that opened the day before we tried it (12/21/12) was very good indeed.
Starting with the look of the restaurant, the modern Japanese decor is elegantly done, with wooden sake dispensing containers lining one wall, and a wood grid ceiling. The floor to ceiling wall faces 9th Avenue, so you can watch the neighborhood pass by.
For a nabemono neophyte like myself, the menu needs some explanation, but the wait staff were very friendly and patient about explaining how best to cook the various meats in the broths, and what dipping sauces or raw egg go with which item. Of the food we tried the Kimchi and kurobuta pork belly, sukiyaki and the seafood yosenabe were my favorites. After you eaten your fill by cooking the meat and vegetables in the broth, the waitstaff will then ask which broth you would like to have rice, green onions, egg and seaweed cooked in (you can pick more than one of your broths); this is a delicious way to end the nabemono.
The food was excellent, fresh and healthy. And the prices were reasonable; this is a great addition to the neighborhood restaurant scene.

shiitake mushroom.author: Mito I.
shiitake mushroom.review:
Quick Summary:
- Not All-You-Can-Eat
- After ordering a nabe style, extras are ordered Al La Carte Style
- Not enough for a glutton, even after ordering two large nabes. 
- If you're a glutton, enter with 50% full (drink coffee before entering) and you will leave moderately full
- Recommend to set up a reservation. I did it online.

The only reason, and it was a large reason for my case, why I decided to lower the star from 5 to 4 is the portions. 

First off, the food was very delicious. We ordered two large nabe styles: shabu shabu (ordered the beef) and the kinoko (mushroom and vegetables). The shabu shabu came with a plate of vegetables (carrot, tofu, spinach, enoki mushrooms, shiitake mushroom, daikon radish, udon, etc.). On the other hand, most of the stated vegetables were already placed in the kinoko nabe (the ramen came as a separate plate), so there was fewer preparations for that dish. 
I ordered the konbu dashi for the shabu shabu because I wanted to try the shabu shabu that focuses on the meat's flavor. Also, we ordered the kinoko dish, and that is already made in a miso broth, so it was great to try two different soups. In the end, we selected the rice porridge to be made in the kinoko broth. I do have to add, the miso broth was lacking the dashi taste (lacking konbu, katsuo bushi, or shiitake). 

At first glance, I can tell, I can easily eat one of these large nabe and one regular nabe portion all by myself, if I were to arrive at the restaurant hungry with a 90% or higher empty stomach. Even my other family members could have eaten at least one large nabe on their own.

We cleared the dishes and ate the rice porridge - and I have arrived drinking 1 1/2 cups of coffee an hour or so earlier - and I was 75% full. 

I do also recommend setting up a reservation. It takes at least 2 hours for a guest to eat, minus the conversational chatter time duration, so if all seats are full, you might have to wait an hour or longer.

shiitake mushroom.review:
Shabu shabu makes the world a better place. Especially if you are sick and it is cold outside. 

SETTING
-Nabe is in a busy part of Inner Sunset - right between Irving and Judah on 9th Ave.
-Glass doors and walls so you can look right into the restaurant, unless it's around dinner when the inside is so hot that the glass gets fogged up! 
-They have a few tables for parties of 4 or smaller, and then a long table that stretches in the middle of the restaurant for pairs or larger groups. 
-If it's a full house they do have a wait list you can put your name on. You can wait inside or wander about outside and they'll give you a call. 
-Service gets a little bit slow when things get crowded.

SHABU SHABU
-We always go for the half pot Spicy Miso Broth (Shabu Shabu order) and half pot Warishita broth (Sukiyaki order)
-Meat platters come in two sizes: Regular or Large. The prices vary depending on which type of meat. For this outing we ended up ordering a large Sukiyaki wagyu beef order and a regular Shabu Shabu kurabuta pork plate.
-Each order comes with a plate of assorted vegetables and other condiments: tofu, cabbage, enoki mushroom, carrot, udon noodles, shiitake mushroom, kabocha squash, etc. 
-TIP: After you finish your shabu shabu meal, there is actually a FINISHER! The waiter will bring out rice and use your leftover broth to make a rice soup. The spicy miso broth rice soup finisher is amazing. They add an egg, green onions, and a little bit of seaweed. It takes about 10 minutes to prepare if your broth is still hot. 

PROS/TIPS
-Complimentary rice soup finisher after your Shabu Shabu meal! It always hits the spot if you're still a little hungry after your Shabu Shabu!
-Ask for iced water when you get in - most people ask for tea but after you get your Shabu Shabu... you'll want cold water.
-Keep your broth hot after you're done with your Shabu Shabu and you're ready for the finisher - otherwise it'll take extra time to reheat the broth and make the finisher. Since it's time intensive you could end up waiting for awhile. 

Overall delicious :) happy happy shabu shabu!

shiitake mushroom.author: Adele F.
shiitake mushroom.review:
2 regular nabemono shabu sets shared among 3 people is more than enough, mostly due to the Zosui rice that they add to your broth after your hot-potting is done. It's like two meals in one!

A new hotpot restaurant in Inner Sunset that opened only 3 weeks ago? Hot damn! Cherylynn's review is so thorough that I don't need to bother with all the details. I just want to note that the nabemono sets include meat/seafood, noodles, and assorted vegetables paired with a broth. Your meal ends with a Zosui rice soup using the flavored broth from the cooking. Pricing is $18 per person for a regular portion, $22 per person for a large portion.

They also have a seasonal nabemono winter set called Kamonanban, which includes duck breast and Tokyo negi with Dashi broth, regular $23 and large $28.

Our group of 9 entered the restaurant around 5:30 PM without a reservation, and we were lucky to nab the long communal table in the back. The restaurant can only seat 32, so I would definitely recommend a reservation during normal dining hours. Service is good, with multiple waitresses running around checking on things, refilling water, and asking if the group is ready for the Zosui rice. However, the entire endeavor is a bit time-consuming given the ingredient preparation, table stove heating, and rice porridge finale. Our group was there for TWO HOURS. Crazy.

My PDC family ordered 2 regular sets: the SUKIYAKI (Washugyu beef with a sweet Warishita broth) and the SHABU SHABU (Washugyu beef or Kurobuta pork with either traditional konbu or spicy miso broth). Our order came with 3 plates, one for each of the meats (15 slices of thinly sliced, beautifully marbled beef: http://s3-media4.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/ZwBukC0KhMXJKbmaNfKPFw/l.jpg, forgot to take a picture of the pork, oops) and another for the combined vegetables and udon (http://s3-media2.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oENOdFCIcUrOqzm1cSXdgg/l.jpg). The vegetable/udon plate came with chopped cabbage, baby spinach leaves, a few slices of squash, two slabs of tofu, enoki mushrooms, a quartered shiitake mushroom, a few carrot pieces in cute shapes, and udon noodles. To be honest, I wish they gave more vegetables because spinach severely shrinks :(

Since the sukiyaki set came with Washugyu beef, we opted for the Kurobota pork in spicy miso broth, per my big's recommendation. When our pot came to our table, the vegetables were already swimming in it (http://s3-media1.ak.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/9Zp7qpP_MynVcMIw3wA0TQ/l.jpg). This gave the scallions, mushrooms, tofu, cabbage, carrots, chrysanthemum leaves, and these spotted, slightly-crunchy, translucent noodles more time to cook. We added the meats on par with our consumption; I enjoyed the beef and pork equally :)

Regarding the broths, I definitely preferred the sukiyaki's Warishita. The sweetened soy base adds subtle undertones to the hot pot ingredients, although the spicy miso adds that kick most people enjoy with their meat. The sukiyaki also comes with a raw egg that you crack into a bowl and dip your meat and vegetables in. So strange! I loved the added creaminess hehe. Screw Salmonella.

After all is eaten, a waitress scoops out some of your broth and adds in some rice to make this delicious porridge chock full of hot pot flavor. You can choose to split your rice between the two broths or have it half-half. We asked for half-half, and she let the rice sit for 5 or so minutes before returning to stir in the beaten egg, nori, and green onions. I definitely would vouch for the Warishita broth over the spicy miso broth because at the end of the stewing, the savoriness of the boiled ingredients blends harmoniously with the innate sweetness of the broth.

Max 4-way credit card split, and make sure to let them know before the ring things up. Also, they have one bathroom hidden behind a curtain. It has a weird sliding door...

All in all, I would recommend 2 regular nabemono sets to be shared among 3 people. Both the SUKIYAKI and SHABU SHABU sets were fantastic, although I have a preference for the sukiyaki's broth and raw egg dip. I liked both the beef and the pork, and the beef is exceptionally marbled. And don't forget the Zosui rice porridge at the end! You're getting a real bang for your buck here ;)

Also, shout-out to the best family out there!

kabocha squash.author: Linz C.
kabocha squash.review:
My boyfriend and I were craving shabu but with not very many shabu places opened for lunch yelp led us to Nabe.  I had heard a lot of good things about this place and always wanted to try it for their "after meal" where at the end they add rice and egg into your shabu broth and you get a rice porridge.  

We came about an hour before they closed and there was still quite a few people there.  My boyfriend got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef and spicy miso and I got the sukiyaki with wagyu beef.  Out of the two I personally liked the sukiyaki better. The broth itself was sweet and tasted amazing after dipping your beef in it and then the raw egg they give you. Portion wise they could have been more generous but I understand since it's lunch time their portions are probably smaller than a dinner plate.  We both finished our meat in no time at all and had to order an additional plate of meat because we were still hungry. The meat was good, soft and not frozen like many other places, and I loved the vegetable assortment, especially the variety if mushrooms and kabocha squash!

When we were all done the waitress have us the bill and I was thinking... "We don't get the rice and egg add ins?" So my boyfriend asked our waitress and she told us it was only during dinner that they do that.   Seeing the disappointment on my face the waitress was sooo kind and said she could bring us a bowl of rice and I could make it myself since my meal already came with a raw egg.  She ended up making the whole thing for us, adding the rice, taking out excess soup to make the rice to soup ratio even, stirring in the raw egg, and she went above and beyond and brought us the green onion and seaweed garnishes to put on top.  The customer service that we experienced was AMAZING and our waitress was really sweet.  And I'm glad we got to try the rice porridge because it was delicious!! 

I wouldn't mind coming back again but I prefer AYCE when doing hot pot or shabu.

kabocha squash.author: Priscilla W.
kabocha squash.review:
Nabe is the new, popular Japanese hot pot restaurant in the Inner Sunset. They have an inadequate ventilation system, so the front windows are usually covered with steam; it's no surprise if you overlook this restaurant while walking along 9th Avenue. However, the restaurant's name, displayed cleverly with a bold, blue neon lighting against the black exterior, is easily seen across the street, up to half a block away. It's like your calling to come in on a cold day for some yummy Japanese-style comfort food.

We tried Nabe a few Saturdays ago for an early dinner around 6PM. As newbies, the menu was a little confusing at first. But our server, Nhu, was very helpful explaining how everything worked. Basically, the nabemono sets are portioned per person. They come with the meat, noodles, and vegetables in the broth, all already in a large pot. That pot is brought to your table stove to cook. However, there is one shabu shabu set (beef or pork for choice of meat), which is the only nabemono set that doesn't have the ingredients already in the pot. In other words, you cook it yourself at the table.

We shared the beef and pork shabu shabu and opted for one regular miso broth and one spicy miso broth (traditional kombu (kelp) in water was the other option for shabu shabu broth). I definitely preferred the beef over the pork. Both meats were very fresh and delicious, but the beef was flavorful on its own that sauce wasn't necessary. Vegetables were fresh and abundant. You're given a generous helping of spinach, cabbage, shiitake and enoki mushrooms, carrots, tofu and kabocha squash. The miso broth was very mild, and the spicy miso definitely had some heat.

I love the idea of using leftover broth for rice porridge, so you're not wasting the broth. The waitress comes over to make it for you. That Saturday night we went, there were only three waitresses in the restaurant, so I give our server credit for doing so much, shuffling back and forth to other tables but still tending to ours. The broth is usually concentrated after your meal, so you can ask for them to dilute it. The rice porridge is a perfect compliment at the end of our meal, keeping us warm before we leave the restaurant and endure the cold night.

Nabe is a relatively small restaurant. There's two long communal tables and three smaller 4-person tables. Not a lot of walking room either. Without a reservation, come in by or before 6PM on weekends to guarantee no lines.
