portion isn't big but isn't small either. hungry? you might need to spend a lot here. 
A/C system just alright. Why I get smelled after shabu? 
limited dipping sauce choices

I love the meat here. nice marbled, delicious, fresh so I do 100% enjoy whole experience. 
the best sukiyaki shabu in SF for sure. 
want some sweet savory dinner shabu? I will come here for sure~

excerpts: I loved to watch it being made at our own table, and to finish it all off with the chewy and crunchy mochi cake was awesome!
mochi.author: Claire C.
mochi.review:
Absolutely loved this place. The experience here is so relaxing, it feels like a spa.

The atmosphere is kind of dark and modern. I noticed their music selection here is very feelsy. This is definitely the place where you want to take your best friend or someone close and talk about the good and the bad. It's a very cozy rainy day vibe.

The food itself was amazing. We ordered the ishikari nabe, and it was honestly my favorite. The broth is super buttery and has such a subtle but beautiful flavor to it. I found myself just drinking the broth because it was soooo good. We also ordered the shabu shabu with spicy miso, which was super flavorful and moderately spicy. We loved the wagyu beef! Also, the zosui at the end was perfect. I loved to watch it being made at our own table, and to finish it all off with the chewy and crunchy mochi cake was awesome! The meal was super satisfying.

They have great drinks also! If sake is your thing, there's plenty of that. I opted for the choya plum wine, which was super sweet with just a hint of tartness. We also ordered a pot of the genmaicha tea, which was smoky and savory. I loved both! Honestly, the meal wouldnt have been complete without some wine and hot tea.

excerpts: We also like to get an add on of mochi, even though its $4 for 6 tiny pieces...I LOVE MOCHI, and mochi wrapped in wagyu beef is so so good (also a couple of times they gave us 7 pieces, twas magical)!!!
At the end they make a yummy zosui (rice porridge) with your leftover broth, and mmm it is so good,
both my bf and I love porridge, so we are always happy for it at the end.
Once they accidentally burned it, but we got extra for the inconvenience, which was very nice of the staff.
On days where we are too full, we bring it home and eat it for lunch the next day, and mm it taste just as good!
For dessert, we have only tried the butter mochi with ice cream, which is definitely worth it in my opinion.
mochi.author: Nina W.
mochi.review:
Been wanting to come to Nabe for a while after my bf moved to inner sunset since a friend said it's her fave restaurant. I think Nabe is so yummy, kinda pricey, but every time I come I leave happy. 

My bf and I have now been here multiple times, and we usually always make a reservation an hour or two in advance just incase they're busy, thus we've never had to wait more than about 5 minutes. Every time we come we get the large beef wagyu shabushabu since it already comes with udon, and I'm an udon LOVER! We have tried both the miso and spicy miso, and enjoy both, but as people who like da spice, we usually go for spicy miso =). We also like to get an add on of mochi, even though its $4 for 6 tiny pieces...I LOVE MOCHI, and mochi wrapped in wagyu beef is so so good (also a couple of times they gave us 7 pieces, twas magical)!!! At the end they make a yummy zosui (rice porridge) with your leftover broth, and mmm it is so good, both my bf and I love porridge, so we are always happy for it at the end. Once they accidentally burned it, but we got extra for the inconvenience, which was very nice of the staff. On days where we are too full, we bring it home and eat it for lunch the next day, and mm it taste just as good! For dessert, we have only tried the butter mochi with ice cream, which is definitely worth it in my opinion. 

I definitely recommend Nabe, and maybe someday we will venture out and try out something besides our usual shabu shabu. Also just a warning, they don't have very good ventilation, so it gets quite warm inside.

excerpts: Must try Sesame ice cream and the crispy mochi cake!
I will just go there for the desert.
mochi.author: Ying L.
mochi.review: Not too bad not too dope! The porridge in the end is the hightligt! Must try Sesame ice cream and the crispy mochi cake! I will just go there for the desert.

excerpts: I think we ordered a beef and a pork thing and added some noodles and mochi, but I don't remember exactly because it wasn't all too memorable.
The redemption factor was the yummy rice broth at the end that everyone raves about.
mochi.author: Edna C.
mochi.review:
Floor-to-ceiling glass windows.
Pinterest-worthy wall decor of sake in wooden case dispensers.
Water served in pink and blue frosted sake bottles.
Sleek modern furniture.
Wooden utensils.
The classiness of not smelling like kBBQ.
Enter Nabe, Inner Sunset's suave shabu shabu place.

It's a cool ambiance with a general bouge feel, but overall I found it lacking flavor and more pricey for what it's worth. Yes it's locally sourced organic etc., which unfortunately doesn't translate to tasty. The broths were mediocre, and the portions were tiny (meat was sliced *paper-thin*!) I think we ordered a beef and a pork thing and added some noodles and mochi, but I don't remember exactly because it wasn't all too memorable. The redemption factor was the yummy rice broth at the end that everyone raves about. Overall though, $20 later, we were all still hungry :(

I think Nabe would be the best for a girl's night out (or maybe a date to impress a girl who really like ambiancey places). The food is nothing mind-blowing, but you feel so SF eating overpriced organic shabu and sitting in a pretty restaurant with a crowd outside waiting for your table.

excerpts: The mochi cake with ice cream is simple but very satisfying.
Definitely try it, especially if you've never tried mochi cake before!
mochi.author: Stephany L.
mochi.review:
Nabe is definitely more expensive than AYCE chinese hot pot, but I think much like KBBQ, what you lose in quantity you gain in quality for about the same price. I think considering that I'm not a very big eater anyway, it ends up working out about the same for me. 

Both times I've been here, I've split the large Kamonanban with my boyfriend. The first time we came here, it was fairly late and I remember the presentation of the hot pot was beautiful! The second time we were here it was around normal dinner hours and they were obviously much busier, and the presentation wasn't as visually stunning. Luckily though both times tasted just as great. I really like how flavorful and rich their broth is. I always die a little on the inside when they scoop out the excess when making the final porridge at the end...haha! Anyway the Kamonanban is extremely satisfying. It won't leave you totally stuffed, which is kind of a nice thing because then you can get dessert! The mochi cake with ice cream is simple but very satisfying. Definitely try it, especially if you've never tried mochi cake before!

excerpts: Not to mention their special desserts, that no restaurants can imitate- green tea cheescake and the homemade mochi cake(served hot with ice cream, which is a must try).
Also, the staffs are really really sweet, I love them all
mochi.author: Kerry P.
mochi.review:
I would've to say that Nabe is the only Shabu Shabu restaurant that makes me want to come back over over and over again, I can have their hot pot 3 days in a row i would say, not only Nabe has the best authentic Japanese hot pot taste to me, but it also very creative in the way they use the left over broth to make rice porridge in no time (isn't it sound great!!). Not to mention their special desserts, that no restaurants can imitate- green tea cheescake and the homemade mochi cake(served hot with ice cream, which is a must try). 
Also, the staffs are really really sweet, I love them all

excerpts: The matcha cheesecake was great, but the Mochi dessert was simply outstanding!!
mochi.author: lovetoeat a.
mochi.review:
Modern decor, excellent combo of meats and broths, excellent service. 
So hard to find parking in this neighborhood!! But once we made it to the restaurant, we were rewarded with a great shabu dinner!! 
There are so many choices: wagyu beef, kurobota pork, seafood, duck... a wide selection of side items. 
This place does not offer tonkotsu broth, but a dashi broth, milder, cleaner tasting broth. The meat quality is outstanding! 
The 2 desserts that we had were so good I am tempted to come back just for the desserts alone. The matcha cheesecake was great, but the Mochi dessert was simply outstanding!!

excerpts: My BF and I got the miso and Kim chi soups with veggies, mochi, pork belly and wagyu beef.
It all tasted great!
Afterwards you get to choose one soup to make into porridge for free.
Also very yummy!
It just sucks that you only get to choose one soup to make porridge with.
We were with a group of four and we still only get one soup to make porridge.
mochi.author: Elaine L.
mochi.review:
I made a reservation the morning of without any hassle. I'm glad I did because it was pretty packed when I came. 

My BF and I got the miso and Kim chi soups with veggies, mochi, pork belly and wagyu beef. It all tasted great! Afterwards you get to choose one soup to make into porridge for free. Also very yummy! It just sucks that you only get to choose one soup to make porridge with. We were with a group of four and we still only get one soup to make porridge. Boo.

Space wise, the restaurant is very narrow and pretty cramped so I wouldn't recommend big groups and I def recommend making a reservation. 

Tip: wear short sleeves because the poor ventilation made the hot pot experience even...hotter! The windows were so steamed up it reminded me of the scene from the titanic !

excerpts: Their special is the butter mochi, which is made in house.
I could definitely tell they were proud of it because they asked us what we thought of it.
It was really delicious.
Imagine a warm mochi that melts in your mouth.
It is served with ice cream of your choice.
The GF loves black sesame, and it paired great with the mochi.
mochi.author: Victor L.
mochi.review:
The GF and I came here on a Monday night.  I have passed by here before and seen it being very busy.  It was pretty late when we got here, which explains why there were only four other tables occupied.  We looked at the menu and decided to get the Sukiyaki and the Kinoko nabe.  The Sukiyaki comes with everything u would expect from shabu shabu, but with thinly sliced marbled pieces of beef.  They also supply you with an egg for dipping the meat in to make it more silky.  The Kinoko nabe comes with mushrooms and ramen.  Both broths were very flavorful.  I liked the Sukiyaki a little better though because it is more traditional.  

The vegetables and other ingredients are already placed in the pot.  This has its pros and cons.  For example, stuff that you do not like is automatically cooking inside the pot.  Although, one does not really have to worry about overcooking tofu or mushrooms, the vegetables may get soggy in this manner.  Pros are that you can get whatever you want at once because they will have all cooked at the same time!  

After you are done eating, they prepare a type of rice soup.  They ask you what type of broth you want the rice soup to be made in.  Then, they bring out green onions, egg, seaweed, and of course rice.  They add the rice into the broth.  Then they slowly drain the broth until the rice is clearly visible under the broth.  After that, the egg and green onions are stirred into the equation.  Then, this creation is put into bowls and topped with seaweed.  This was definitely my favorite part of the meal.  Dinner and a show?  Awesome.  

We were so full after the meal.  However, we had to make room for dessert.  Their special is the butter mochi, which is made in house.  I could definitely tell they were proud of it because they asked us what we thought of it.  It was really delicious.  Imagine a warm mochi that melts in your mouth.  It is served with ice cream of your choice.  The GF loves black sesame, and it paired great with the mochi.  NomZ.  

Service A 
Food A
Environment A (ventilation was very good)

excerpts: The most important thing to know for Nabe is TO GET THE MOCHI BUTTER CAKE DESSERT.
They make the Mochi Cake in house, so this is the only place to taste this delightful dessert.
It's served with a scoop of ice cream.
Just imagine biting into a warm-buttery-chewy piece of cake with a sudden sensation of sweet-chilly ice cream sliding down your taste buds.
mochi.author: Ringo M.
mochi.review:
Nabe has several very nice, attentive, and knowledgable waitresses. Because the waitresses were so informative and helpful, our food actually came with a healthy side of knowledge. And of course, KNOWLEDGE IS POWER!

Did you know......

1) Nabe, short for Nabemono, is not exactly the same as Shabu. In Nabemono, heaps of food are already filled into the hotpot broth. In contrast, ShabuShabu comes out with only broth, and food is filled into it afterwards. If you're eating at Nabe, choosing any broth options other than 'Shabu' will get you a beautiful hot pot broth with a variety of ingredients already inside. (Don't worry, both options come with thinly slice marbled meat on the side!)

2) The meal is finished with Zosui, which is similar to a porridge, or a Japanese Risotto. A waitress comes over to your table with a plate of rice, egg, seaweed, and scallion and then proceeds to cook the rice in the leftover broth. Apparently, the rice absorbs the leftover nutrients from the veggies in the broth, thus making the Zosui a nutritious finish to the meal. My mom pointed out that there is probably a lot of fat and sodium in the broth, but she also agreed that it makes the Zosui absolutely delicious.

3) The most important thing to know for Nabe is TO GET THE MOCHI BUTTER CAKE DESSERT. They make the Mochi Cake in house, so this is the only place to taste this delightful dessert. It's served with a scoop of ice cream. Just imagine biting into a warm-buttery-chewy piece of cake with a sudden sensation of sweet-chilly ice cream sliding down your taste buds. gettttttit

My mom and my sister gave strong compliments to the stellar service. I agree, the waitstaff was top notch. Next time I'm here, I will try the Sake, because they have an impressive collection lined up on their walls. Maybe I'll learn a little something about Sake too and of course, KNOWLEDGE IS POWER.

excerpts: Instead we just ordered this mochi cake with ice cream.
The waitress suggest that we order the roasted black sesame ice cream.
It was good to try
but I wouldn't say that I crave their ice cream or shabu.
I suggest trying this shabu place as the decor and utensils are fun, and it could be a nice fun first date, but I don't think this is my go to.
The mochi cake was not very tasty, there was definitely a lack of sugar and butter.
It needs to be softer, more moist, and definitely sweeter.
mochi.author: Amy Y.
mochi.review: I came to this location with my boyfriend as we were craving some shabu shabu. Luckily there was parking right outside the restaurant and it was a minute away from the location. When we walked into the location it was very stuffy and there were a few tables occupied. There were three servers that were very friendly and helpful. We looked at the menu and ordered a set which included Wagyu beef. We added a couple of additional items as we were sharing these the set together. We got the spicy miso soup- I suggest ordering the regular miso soup instead of the spicy as you can always add spicy and not the other way around. The set comes with a vegetable plate that includes some udon, mushroom, spinach, squash etc. The service was okay, when we got there, the employees were eating their dinner too. They failed to tell us it was last call time, so we ended up not being able to order anything. Instead we just ordered this mochi cake with ice cream. The waitress suggest that we order the roasted black sesame ice cream. It was good to try but I wouldn't say that I crave their ice cream or shabu. I suggest trying this shabu place as the decor and utensils are fun, and it could be a nice fun first date, but I don't think this is my go to. The mochi cake was not very tasty, there was definitely a lack of sugar and butter. It needs to be softer, more moist, and definitely sweeter.

excerpts: I also tried their mochi cake for dessert and it was divine.
I haven't found any kind of mochi bread since visiting SoCal!
Overall, it was shareable and worth the price.
The decor is modern and pleasant but the space is small and fills up quickly!
mochi.author: Leanna C.
mochi.review: The broth and sauce were very flavorful! I came here in a party of 4 around 6PM and had to wait almost 20 minutes. Tip: If you have more than 2 people, make a reservation or call ahead. They are really big on that. They have a huge selection of sake--watch out if you're a lightweight like me! We got a large shabu shabu and the platter of beef was huge! Its not AYCE but a fixed menu. I also tried their mochi cake for dessert and it was divine. I haven't found any kind of mochi bread since visiting SoCal! Overall, it was shareable and worth the price. The decor is modern and pleasant but the space is small and fills up quickly!

excerpts: For dessert their most popular seems to be the mochi cake which is what it sounds like, a blend of mochi into a piece of cake.
You can choose your own ice cream on the side.
mochi.author: Catherine C.
mochi.review:
A friend brought me here for my birthday, and I've been back twice since then. The sukiyaki is my favorite and I would highly recommend their yam noodles. Their veggies are fresh and the meat looks relatively lean, and even though their portions don't look huge it's a lot of food. 

At the end of the hot pot there's a rice finisher that's really interesting. It involves slightly more than just dumping a bowl of rice into the left over soup. They let the rice simmer down into a porridge and then add some toppings. A little too salty with a sukiyaki base but it's better with shabu shabu. For dessert their most popular seems to be the mochi cake which is what it sounds like, a blend of mochi into a piece of cake. You can choose your own ice cream on the side. I've tried the green tea and black sesame and both were really good. 

Only downside to Nabe is that the service is a little slow. It was fine when we came for an early dinner but after 7pm it seems to fill up and it's difficult to catch the servers' attention. When you do have their attention though, you have their full attention and they are very pleasant. 

Overall Nabe is awesome for a cold SF day-- the food is really great and absolutely worth a try. Will definitely be back!

excerpts: I substituted the noodles for, mochi (rice cakes).
The added mochi reminded me of the Japanese New Year, where this would be commonplace for the Japanese.
mochi.author: Jeanie L.
mochi.review:
I now look at Shabu dining with a whole different perspective!  I absolutely loved our first time experience here.  

The dining space is small with a simple, clean decor; sake bottles adorn one big wall of the restaurant.  The wait time could be long due to limited seating.  I would recommend making reservations in advance or at least calling ahead to be put on the wait list.

I ordered a Nabemono Set:  Sukiyaki.  This set contained Wagyu beef sliced thinly, assorted vegetables and shirataki noodles in a Warishita broth.  I substituted the noodles for, mochi (rice cakes).  The added mochi reminded me of the Japanese New Year, where this would be commonplace for the Japanese.  The broth had a sweet soy sauce flavor; it was delicious!

Accompanying my meal was a glass of cold sake, Konteki, "Tears of Dawn":  sweet rice & banana.  Instead of being an anticipated sweet sake, it was more in the lines of a Margarita, where it was salty.  As I drank it along with my meal and as the alcohol slowly took effect, it no longer tasted so salty.  

The big surprise of the evening was what they call the "final course", the zosui.  With the remaining broth in your hot pot, your waitress will add a bowl of rice, a raw egg, nori and green onions.  Stirring it all up results in a delicious porridge-like dish.  Too bad I was absolutely satiated, or else I would've enjoyed the zosui a little more; that ended up being the Togo dish.

I enjoyed both my meal and the new experience here.  This is my new Shabu-go-to spot!

excerpts: I typically order an extra side of mochi and mushrooms!
mochi.author: Kristen C.
mochi.review:
My new go to spot for Japanese Shabu! No only are the ingredients fresh, but there are enough options without the menu being too overwhelming. That's definitely a plus IMO! And if you want to add items, you can customize it to include exactly what you want. I typically order an extra side of mochi and mushrooms! 

The best part is at the end of the meal when they make the rice porridge with your left over soup. Unfortunately you can only choose one soup broth to make it with, but it's damn good. Trust. 

Prices are fairly reasonable. The first time I ate here, I thought it was a bit on the smaller side for a regular, but I was fooled because I found myself beyond full at the end.

It does get crowded especially on a cold SF day, so be prepared for a wait or make a ressie ahead of time. 

TIP: If you still have room after the meal, Eazy Breezy is just up the street. It's a win/win!

excerpts: and I got the kimchi hot pot with kurobuta pork belly and mochi.
We also got a side of rice (one split between the two of us), harusame noodles, tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and duck (the side order of duck which was $16 isn't listed on the menu).
They also have the sesame dipping sauce, which we also asked for as well as it isn't automatically given to you.
The ponzu sauce was more tart than other places I've been too
but I thought it was great.
I really liked the flavors of both broths and the pork and the beef portions were pretty decently sized.
mochi.author: Jennifer J.
mochi.review:
Came here recently with my dad since we've been trying to try out all the hot pot places in the city. After looking through the pictures of the place on Yelp, we decided to make a reservation which turned out to be a good idea because right when we got to the place there was already a table waiting for us. The staff were very friendly and nice and answered all our questions regarding the menu.

The food was really good in my opinion. My dad got the shabu shabu with wagyu beef with miso (not spicy) broth and I got the kimchi hot pot with kurobuta pork belly and mochi. We also got a side of rice (one split between the two of us), harusame noodles, tofu, shiitake mushrooms, and duck (the side order of duck which was $16 isn't listed on the menu). They also have the sesame dipping sauce, which we also asked for as well as it isn't automatically given to you. The ponzu sauce was more tart than other places I've been too but I thought it was great. I really liked the flavors of both broths and the pork and the beef portions were pretty decently sized. Though neither of us thought the side order of duck was worth it, it was an interesting try. 

The best part of the meal for me was the zosui rice soup. They take rice, a beaten egg, and green onions and throw it into your broth that you cooked all your food in (in this case we had a choice between miso and kimchi, and we chose miso). They serve it in your individual bowls and top it with nori strips. I didn't really know what to expect but it ended up being very flavorful (even though it was the miso broth and not the kimchi broth) and I ate the whole bowl even though I was pretty full from the main meal. When you get the soup it is BLAZING HOT so take your time eating it... and don't worry if you don't finish everything in the pot! They'll give you the rest in a take-out container.

The atmosphere of the place is what's bringing down the rating to 4 stars. It's a small place and everyone is having hot pot, so of course it was hot and a bit stuffy. When we walked in my dad mentioned that his glasses fogged up, and maybe it's better right when they open, but I thought it smelled kind of sweaty. It was great that we made a reservation because we had a table for two in the corner of the restaurant (I'm not a fan of sharing my space and sitting next to strangers).

Their bathroom is pretty nice inside. The door is a sliding door which even though I thought was pretty cool, was pretty embarrassing when I was standing outside the bathroom door for longer than 15 seconds trying to figure to whether there was someone in there or not.

Overall our meals ended up being pretty pricey (no thanks to the side of duck) but I'd come back again.

excerpts:
I usually switch out the mochi for udon noodles)

SERVICE:
Friendly and prompt staff.
mochi.author: J C.
mochi.review:
Love this little gem in the city! I've been here several times and the food & service never disappoints.

FOOD:
Favorites: 1. Wagyu beef + spicy miso broth and 2. pork belly + kimchi broth. Meats are always high quality and they provide a well-sized portion of veggies/additions to your meal. I normally share a large dinner order with another person, which I find to be the perfect amount of food. At the end of your meal, they give you the option of a rice finisher (a "porridge" made with your broth, rice, eggs, scallions, and seaweed). Super yummy - get this! It will definitely fill you up if you aren't full already.

Tip: you can mix and match your meat and broth combos and switch out certain items (ex. I usually switch out the mochi for udon noodles)

SERVICE:
Friendly and prompt staff. All positive experiences thus far!

excerpts: I also dig their in-house green tea mochi cake.
It's not too sweet and perfect to share with your date, friend or anyone else
you came with... :)))
mochi.author: Content O.
mochi.review:
Ate here while vacationing in the Bay Area with my big brother last Fall of 2014.  It was in the month of September, to be exact!  This is a good place to go for Shabu Shabu.  It's small, modern and semi-classy.  The meat was tasty, produce was fresh & seafood broth was good.  What I loved most about this place is the free Japanese-style rice porridge service they provide.  They use the broth that's left in the hot pot to: mix one bowl of steamed white rice, seafood and a raw egg.  It's yummy & one of the highlights of the hot pot experience...

I also dig their in-house green tea mochi cake.  It's not too sweet and perfect to share with your date, friend or anyone else you came with... :)))

excerpts: Instead, most of what you're going to have is already in the pot, with the exception of the mochi and rice sides.
mochi.author: Johnny W.
mochi.review:
Meaning to try them ever since I saw them under construction, I finally had a chance to drop by two months ago, sharing a split pot of their kurobuta pork belly with kimchi broth, and kamonanban (duck breast with dashi broth) with a friend [ Photo: http://instagram.com/p/YhLxG9Qfrq/ ].

Nabe is a bit unlike the other hotpot places around the city, neither serving up AYCE hotpot, nor individual portions accompanied by too many side vegetables. Instead, most of what you're going to have is already in the pot, with the exception of the mochi and rice sides. And, after you're done with your meats, rather than noodles, you can have them use one of the remaining broths to make zosui (rice porridge/congee).

Okay food overall, with nothing standing out in particular. And their zosui, unfortunately, is unbearably salty, unlike other places I've been to that offer this. Your choice of broth will certainly have something to do with this, but my recommendation is to have the zosui made, and then packed to go so you can dilute it back at home with more rice and water/plain stock. Can't let that food go to waste, after all! But, while Nabe is not a bad choice, I personally will probably stick with some of the other hotpot options around the city.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Semi-accessible, from what I recall. The seats up near the entrance are somewhat accessible, but the walkways to the back are narrow enough when there aren't customers that it's near impossible when there ARE customers.

Bathroom - I didn't check them out, but given the above issue with narrow walkways, you'd have a hard time getting to them, even if they were accessible.

excerpts: They had Mochi which had perfect consistency when boiled.
The beef was also perfectly sliced.
And one of the best parts, at the end instead of wasting the leftover broth, the servers make a complementary porridge.
mochi.author: Fernilla S.
mochi.review: My friend and I ordered the Nabe with seared duck and it did not disappoint. One of the better shabu places in SF. They had Mochi which had perfect consistency when boiled. The beef was also perfectly sliced. And one of the best parts, at the end instead of wasting the leftover broth, the servers make a complementary porridge.

excerpts: Best part about the kimchi set was that it came with little mochi cubes instead of noodles!!
mochi.author: Krisna T.
mochi.review:
The bae and I decided to check this place out after yelping a few hotpot/shabu spots in the sunset. I suggested that we try some place new--and so we both agreed on Nabe. 

When we arrived, we were greeted by one of the servers and he allowed us to choose our table since the restaurant wasn't too packed. After being seated, another server came by and kindly explained the menu thoroughly to us. Apparently, the restaurant serves nabemonos(aka nabe) and not your basic shabu. On their menu, there was a list of different nabe sets and our server explained that all sets but the shabu shabu set(yes, it's still an option here!) come with a pot of broth that already contains most of the paired items inside of the pot--whereas for the shabu shabu set, the meat, noodles, and veggies are all given separately. I wanted shabu at the start because I wanted to cook my own food yakno, so we ordered the shabu shabu set with beef and miso broth and the kimchi with pork belly set. Now let's break it down:

Food-Super yummy! The shabu shabu set was like other shabu I've had--but still good. The kimchi set was my fav *o* The bae also agreed that the kimchi was also his fav, hehe. The level of spiciness of the broth was perfect. I love eating spicy food even though I can't handle it well LOL, but it was still bearable. Pork belly of course was good, obvi. Best part about the kimchi set was that it came with little mochi cubes instead of noodles!! When we cooked it in the broth, it became squishy and just amazingggg. 

Best part of the meal had to be the rice finisher. When we were done eating, our server asked if we were ready for the rice finisher and I was like "Okay!", but then bae and I looked at each other like huh?? She came back with rice, egg, seaweed and green onions and explained to us that the rice finisher(zosui?) is served at the end of each meal. We chose to have it prepared in the kimchi broth and omg, it was so good. It is basically rice soup/porridge/jook/chao/whatever you wanna call it--but better. You can say that we both left with with a food baby.


Environment- The restaurant layout is really cute and compact. Not many tables and the aisles were quite small, but still walkable. Everything looks clean and simple. Although the restaurant was sort of empty when we got there, by the end of our meal, the restaurant was SUPER packed and it got pretty humid inside of the restaurant. 



Service-EXCELLENT! Although there were only 2 servers and there was a full house, both were very attentive and were super friendly. Our cups of tea were never empty and they checked up on us here and there.



Overall, I'd say my first visit to Nabe was enjoyable and will most def return!

excerpts: Plus side orders of udon, kabocha and mochi.
Melt in your mouth wagyu beef and kurobota pork shoulder sliced paper thin to cook in rich broth with noodles, assorted mushrooms, radish and cabbage.
Don't forget to save room for the rice porridge, made tableside in the leftover broth with egg, scallions and nori.
I wanted to take it home and eat it for breakfast.
So full, so sated!
mochi.author: Emily L.
mochi.review: Hot pot heaven! Had two large sukiyaki for a table of 4 (it was more than enough)- one with kimchi and one with duck and leeks. Plus side orders of udon, kabocha and mochi. Melt in your mouth wagyu beef and kurobota pork shoulder sliced paper thin to cook in rich broth with noodles, assorted mushrooms, radish and cabbage. Don't forget to save room for the rice porridge, made tableside in the leftover broth with egg, scallions and nori. I wanted to take it home and eat it for breakfast. So full, so sated!

excerpts: When our pot came the kimchi broth already had all the ingredients in the pot, with a large plate of pork on the side and mochi.
mochi.author: Jenny Y.
mochi.review:
Call in before you get there so they can put your party on the wait list!
I called in about 20-30 minutes before I got there and a waitress called me back when we were up and our table was free.
We eventually found parking in the lot across the street but that area in general is just a pain in the ass to deal with.
We arrived with the windows all fogged up and were seated shortly after.
Waitresses are very nice and attentive and let you take your time to order and will gladly explain what everything is.

Nabe's hot pot is a bit different from all the other hot pot/shabu places that you go to and that's what caught my taste buds attention.
You order a set which comes with the listed ingredients/soup flavor.
My boyfriend decided to split half half so we could try more things and went with the large beef shabu shabu with spicy miso soup and another half of the pork belly with kimchi broth.
When our pot came the kimchi broth already had all the ingredients in the pot, with a large plate of pork on the side and mochi.
With the shabu shabu you add everything into the soup yourself.
I liked the kimchi broth, the soup was very flavorful and I loved how it was filled with a lot of vegetables. The marbling on the beef for the shabu was also very nice, the meat was tender.
Their sesame sauce is also good, it's more on the watery side which I like.

We were too full to try the zosui rice at the end but will be back.
Sucks that they run out of Sprite. Who runs out of Sprite?!

excerpts: Interesting starch options - sweet potato noodles, mochi (MOCHI?! seriously).
mochi.author: Christina W.
mochi.review:
ZOSUI???! What the best idea ever! This ending dish that the waitress makes for you with your leftover broth is ten million times better than making udon!! I keep thinking about this rich risotto-like bowl of rice. They basically cook down the remaining broth with rice (we used the spicy miso) until it's thickened and starchy, then briefly mix a beaten egg, then add green onions and top with seaweed. Rich, fresh, flavorful... I could go on for days.

The set combos of soup base, meat, and fixings are unique. Meat options of pork belly (sliced super thin so they cook up very delicately soft and tender), duck, wagyu beef. Interesting starch options - sweet potato noodles, mochi (MOCHI?! seriously). 

This time I had the kimchi broth (it's not overly sour/tangy/fermented but still strong enough so I didn't drink the broth with each bite of food as I normally do - it imparts plenty of flavor to the food while cooking), and my bf had the spicy miso. Both solid, and I would recommend.

I honestly want to come back here to try all their flavor combinations. Very good first experience on unique food, flavor, and service. I may bump this up to 5 stars after trying a few more items.

excerpts: If you have room for dessert at this point they have a delicious housemade mochi cake with green tea that I highly recommend.
mochi.author: Kate M.
mochi.review:
I adore this place. I'm normally more of a hot pot (Chinese style) fan than shabu shabu (Japanese) as the options for broth and everything that goes into it is far more varied in hot pot, but Nabe is something special.

It is a little on the pricey side but the quality of meat, noodles, and vegetables are all high quality. I've tried most of the broth and my favorite would have to be the spicy miso. Konbu is a little bland while the kimchi one is a little sour for my tastes. I always get the medium spicy miso broth for size and order extra meat and noodles if there are more people. The udon noodles are fresh and delicious while the pork has just the right amount of marbling.

If it hasn't been raved about already, the best part of the meal is the zosui rice, aka THE FINISHER. I can never go back to other shabu places as most places do not do the zosui. After you've finished your meal and the broth is wonderfully flavored with the meat and vegetable, they take a little bit of rice and egg and let it simmer to a wonderful jook, congee, rice soup, whatever you would like to call it. Top it off with scallions and nori and it is a PERFECT cup of the most flavorful rice soup/stew you could possibly taste. I love it so much that I wish they would just sell this part. 

If you have room for dessert at this point they have a delicious housemade mochi cake with green tea that I highly recommend.

The wait during weekdays is minimal to none but on the weekends I would recommend calling ahead to be seated. The service is great, they're attentive and make the rice soup on the spot for you.

excerpts: The other choice of dessert is butter mochi which is also very good.
mochi.author: Janey H.
mochi.review:
I've been to this place twice & can say that it's very good. The portions are good sizes, the prices are reasonable, & the service is very good. All the servers I've interacted with there knows everything about every dish which is excellent. Every one is very friendly & polite which everyone looks for in servers at a restaurant.
The food comes out promptly so there is never a long wait for anything. I've had the kimchee nabe, sukiyaki, & I've tried the duck. All three of those are very flavorful & tasty. I've also ordered the garlic soy edamame, which I would definitely recommend trying. 
For those green tea lovers, the green tea cheesecake is amazing here. Its not super thick cheesecake so it's easy to eat & you can taste the green tea flavor, mmm. The other choice of dessert is butter mochi which is also very good. 
 If I ever have a shabu shabu craving, I would come here.

excerpts: This one also came with mochi, which I have never had in broth, so that was pretty good.
mochi.author: Samantha L.
mochi.review:
Nabe is the newest restaurant to open up in the Inner Sunset, so of course my friends and I wanted to try it out.  We came in for an earlier dinner, around 5:45 p.m. and the place was empty, so we were seated immediately.  The waitress gave us the menus and our group of five decided to share a few items.  At first it was a bit confusing trying to figure out how much food to order, but it all worked out in the end.  Anyway, about the food.  The regular orders are $19 and large orders are $24.  Special items, like the duck, are $24 for a regular size and $29 for the large.

-Shabu (spicy miso): this was probably my favorite of the broths.  It was a nice amount of spice for me, but some others found it to be a little spicy.  
-Shabu (traditional): pretty average/good.
-Kimchi and pork belly: I have never actually had kimchi in broth, so this was a new experience for me.  It tasted pretty good.  Just make sure you like kimchi.
-Duck breast and dashi broth: this broth tasted pretty similar to the traditional shabu broth.  I enjoyed the duck breast and there were probably about 8-10 pieces.  This one also came with mochi, which I have never had in broth, so that was pretty good.

We didn't realize before, but after the meal, they make a rice porridge with the leftover broth.  You get to pick which broth you want and it's a nice way to fill up, if you haven't already.  They mix in rice, egg and green onions.  The whole thing is pretty good, though we were stuffed already.  Make sure that you try the broth out before they cook it down further- because it can get really salty.  We didn't and the whole thing was kind of a salty mess.

The whole dining experience lasted for about 1.5 hours.  The staff was pretty helpful overall, though at times they were hard to track down for utensils, water or tea refills.  Also, the staff did seem pretty new/inexperienced, so I'll cut them a break.  I have a feeling that this could go up to 4 stars if they work on training the staff a little better.    

Note: this is a place that will have you smelling like the food when you leave.

excerpts:
the miso that came with the pork was very spicy, the sukiyaki that came with the waygu was very sweet)
- The butter mochi and the red been ice cream are bland and not reccomended
mochi.author: Claudio B.
mochi.review:
Overall we had an enjoyable shabu shabu experience, one of the best of his kind in San Francisco. We will likely come back for more.

Pros:
- Very good slices of Waygu beef and Kurobuta pork belly
- Good green tea cheesecake and black bean ice cream
- Attentive and friendly service 
- Good sake selection
- Unique touch with the rice porridge cooked at the table at the end of the meal (dinner only)
- Strong ventilation system which we wish other shabu shabu and hot pot restaurants had in place

Cons:
- Despite the strong ventilation, our clothes ended up smelling after the meal
- A few details missing: no chopstick holder, no place to put my cracked egg, paper napkins (simple cloth would fit better with the decor)
- The broths are quite intense (perhaps too much so: the miso that came with the pork was very spicy, the sukiyaki that came with the waygu was very sweet)
- The butter mochi and the red been ice cream are bland and not reccomended

excerpts: One huge plus is the mochi which is the best thing with hotpot.
The cost is mid-range but for someone young as me, I wouldn't be able to have this too often.
Even so, I brought company and they all loved it
and I definitely think it's a nice place to bring a couple friends.
Not too many though because the restaurant is really awkwardly long and small.
Love that the window's get all steamy though, adds to the mood.
The place also needs to be open for longer hours.
mochi.author: Valerie Z.
mochi.review: I chose the kimchi hotpot which comes with pork belly and it was satisfying though I wish they gave more meat even if there was less extra stuff in the stock itself. One huge plus is the mochi which is the best thing with hotpot. The cost is mid-range but for someone young as me, I wouldn't be able to have this too often. Even so, I brought company and they all loved it and I definitely think it's a nice place to bring a couple friends. Not too many though because the restaurant is really awkwardly long and small. Love that the window's get all steamy though, adds to the mood. The place also needs to be open for longer hours.

excerpts: i realized halfway through my meal that i didn't get my savory mochi.
the server quickly grabbed it for me and apologized for forgetting.
i forgot to mention that earlier, they brought me pork belly instead of shoulder.
two small mistakes, but i understand they were really busy.
mochi.author: Ashleigh R.
mochi.review:
i'm a huge fan of soupy foods. pho, ramen, shabu, thai noodle soup, cioppino. i loves it all. no surprise that i was very interested in this new-ish hot pot place. 

i typically go to shabu shabu, which is a type of hot pot (i learned recently). we had to wait an hour and a half on a chilly, super foggy sunday evening. the staff was sweet though, and called us when our table was ready. 

our server gave us a nice breakdown of the menu, explaining that some items come with everything in the broth, only vegetables in the broth and meat on the side, or everything on the side. very helpful. 

for appetizers, we got the edamame as well as the korobuta sausage with mustard aioli. the edamame was yummy, and had a slightly smoky flavor that we liked. the sausage was delicious and the mustard aioli was a perfect creamy complement to the saltiness of the pork. 

for entrees, my roommate got sukiyaki and i got the kimchi + korobuta pork shoulder. the pork belly would have been a nice option, but i didn't feel like having such a fatty meat that night. our food came quickly, which is good because we were huuungry! i liked the sukiyaki broth much better than mine. the flavor was perfect and complex. also, the raw egg used as a dipping sauce after the meat was cooked, really kicks it up a notch. the kimchi broth wasn't salty enough for me, but after i cooked my pork slices, i dipped them in the accompanying ponzu sauce, which was delicious. ponzu saved the day. i also felt that the meat portion for the regular size was a bit small, considering the price. hmph.

i realized halfway through my meal that i didn't get my savory mochi. the server quickly grabbed it for me and apologized for forgetting. i forgot to mention that earlier, they brought me pork belly instead of shoulder. two small mistakes, but i understand they were really busy. didn't let that ruin my experience.

the end of the meal was, of course, finished off my preparing the rice porridge with the leftover broth. they actually ran out of rice, so he used udon noodles with the sukiyaki broth. heavennnn. by the time we finished, they had prepared more rice, and he made us the proper porridge out of the kimchi broth, too. i liked the kimchi broth a lot more after it had boiled down and became more salty. oh well. 

all in all, i had a great time and yummy food. nabe won't be my regular go-to, as the price point is a bit higher than my usual spot, but i'll be back for that sukiyaki broth!

excerpts: Duck- broth tasted like sukiyaki, came with soba noodles and mochi chunks.
mochi.author: Whitney W.
mochi.review:
Went here around 5:30pm on a Monday and it was not busy at all. By the time we finished around 7 there is still plenty of seats available. 

The menu can be slightly confusing so ask the waitress how it works if it's your first time there. Basically you can choose 2 broth in one pot (you pay for each broth; ex. if you have one pot with 2 broth you pay for the 2 broths separately) and you can choose size large or small. The size refers to the amount of meat they give you rather than the pot size.  Since the store is relatively new, most of the staff seem to still be in training so our ordering process was kind of chaotic because we had some difficulty figuring out how to order and the pricing. 

We had 5 girls sharing 4 broths (2 pots, each pot with 2 kinds of broth) and it was a good amount. We each ended up paying $22 dollars (including tax/tip).  We tried the seasonal duck, spicy miso shabu shabu, kimchi/pork belly, and the Sukiyaki. 

1. Spicy Miso- a little spicier than I'd like, came with udon noodles and veggies/meat.Broth is very flavorful.
 
2. Duck- broth tasted like sukiyaki, came with soba noodles and mochi chunks. The duck is very soft and tasty even after boiling for 20 minutes.

3. Kimchi/pork belly: not too spicy or salty, pork belly meat was really good and thinly sliced

4. Sukiyaki- sweat/salty broth, goes well with beef and has jelly noodles in it. 

Quality of the meats are pretty good. Overall broth are pretty heavily flavored.

In the end the staff will add rice/egg, green onion and roasted seaweed to one broth per pot of your choice. They make a congee out of the left over broth. If they ask you how the broth taste, ask them to dilute your broth if you feel like it was on the salty side. We did not know this so we told them broth tasted fine and our congee turned out to be super salty and inedible with the sukiyaki broth. The congee with the kimchi broth was delicious however.

I think there are definitely room for improvement, but given the quality of the food and considering the fact that they just opened, I think they can (and hopefully will)  get better with time.

excerpts: The only thing I was disappointed with was the dessert, all these reviews said how good the mochi and sesame ice cream is, and I just was not impressed what-so-ever.
But regardless, I will be coming back here for sure!
Try it out!
mochi.author: Nikita K.
mochi.review: This is my second time trying shabu (first time at Shabu Shabu on Geary) and this place was also very good, but pretty different. Nabe looks super modern and cool, and has great service. I got the Beef plate and it was big and the spicy miso broth was delicious. I liked that at Shabu House they gave some like kimchi and stuff on the side, but they didn't give anything other than the meat and vegetables here. But the food was fresh and fantastic. The best part, which I have never seen before, is the rice porridge they made at the end ( rice, spicy miso broth, raw egg, and onion); it was so good and creamy, something very new to me. The only thing I was disappointed with was the dessert, all these reviews said how good the mochi and sesame ice cream is, and I just was not impressed what-so-ever. But regardless, I will be coming back here for sure! Try it out!

excerpts: The most interesting item that came with the pork belly was the mochi.
It comes in a separate dish and it really hard but
once its cooked in the broth, it becomes very chewy.
mochi.author: Darren W.
mochi.review:
Nabe has a very small menu, but they focus on high quality ingredients.  They do shabu a bit different here, they call it Nabemono but its practically the same thing.  Most shabu restaurants I've been to usually bring out the soup and the uncooked ingredients on a plate.  At Nabe they already put everything in the pot, with the flavored broth.  They do have one dish, called Shabu, where you do put the ingredients in yourself.  The food was excellent, the thinly sliced washugyu beef was very tender and flavorful.  We also had an order of the seafood mix which had a great variety of seafood options which included salmon, clams, shrimp and scallops.  The seasonal special was a duck breast which was very good but be sure not to cook the duck too long, the water can boil quick and the duck can get over cooked.  It comes crusted on the skin side but the rest of the duck is rare until they turn on the electric burner on.  The broth is came with was very good, wasn't too salty.  It also came with a small dish of cold soba noodles which compliment the salt form the broth and duck very nicely.  My favorite was the kimchee pork belly, the pork belly was cut very thin and had great flavor and tenderness.  The kimchee wasn't overpowering and added a nice flavor and seasoning to the vegetables and meat.  The most interesting item that came with the pork belly was the mochi.  It comes in a separate dish and it really hard but once its cooked in the broth, it becomes very chewy.  All the dishes come with vegetables by the way.  

BE SURE TO SAVE ROOM AT THE END...when you're finished eating all the meat and vegetables, they use the leftover broth, pour some cooked rice to create this awesome porridge.  They take out whatever left over ingredients in the broth (if you are too full to eat them), pour the cooked rice in the broth, let it come to a boil until it thickens a little bit.  Then they pour a raw egg, seaweed and green onions as it all comes together to create a very flavorful porridge, a nice way to end a meal on.  If it's too salty for you, they can add more rice or water to balance it out for you.  If you're too full to eat the porridge, you can also take it home and it will taste just as good the following day.  Great way to make use of all the leftover food and ingredients when most shabu places tend to waste a lot of leftover food and some even charge when there is an all you can eat option. Since you get this porridge at the end, the meals don't come with rice.  You will have to order it on the side but I was fine without it.  

Staff was extremely friendly and helpful, they were very prompt on refilling my teacup.  Decor was very nice but this is a very small place.  I think they could use a better ventilation system, the windows got all foggy and it was a little steamy inside. It is on the pricier side of Shabu/Hot Pot places, but the menu is different and more unique in my opinion.  I also feel the quality is top notch and above the rest of the shabu places I've been to.  This has become one of my favorite places to eat shabu/hot pot and I'm positive I'll be back soon.

excerpts: But I would recommend replacing the mochi with ramen.
mochi.author: George L.
mochi.review: This is now one of my favorite restaurants in SF. I love the Kimchi with Pork Belly.  It's simply delicious.  But I would recommend replacing the mochi with ramen. :)

excerpts: The new panna cotta is super creamy and their mochi cake which is served warm with ice cream is delicious.
I usually get the duck breast and my BF gets the spicy miso shabu.
I think it's one of the best combos ever.
Best part is, they take rsvp despite party size!
Super plus.
Give nabe a try, you won't regret it!
mochi.author: Anna Z.
mochi.review: This is a long overdue review. When I first tried this place, I was immediately impressed with their beef quality. If you shabu a lot like me, you'll remember that other places have beef that seemed to fall apart when cooked or turned into a weird gray color. But nabe beef is amazing. It's tender, juicy, and never falls apart even after over cooking. I was hooked with their shabu shabu set but it was their duck set that was life changing. This stuff is like crack. The skin is seared nicely and the breast is cut into perfect slices. It's cooked in a dashi broth (savory soy based) and it simply taste like heaven. And when things can possibly get better, they make you a rice porridge with your left over broth that'll blow your mind all over again. Save room for desert though! The new panna cotta is super creamy and their mochi cake which is served warm with ice cream is delicious. I usually get the duck breast and my BF gets the spicy miso shabu. I think it's one of the best combos ever. Best part is, they take rsvp despite party size! Super plus. Give nabe a try, you won't regret it!

excerpts: This was my first visit and we had the classic beef shabu shabu, wonderful DUCK(yep, there's duck) with shitake mushrooms, and kim chee pork belly (with mochi)!
Everything just melts in your mouth!
I have cut out beef and pork from my diet and eating more greens, but this meal was my one-time pass card!
There are a ton of veggies too!
All the dishes come packed with good protein, fresh healthy greens, and then you finish with OMG...rice porridge!
Who does that?
This place does!
I did not have the sake yet...
but I'm sure it's a must as well.
Delish!
I'm coming back and trying the rest of the items on the menu.
mochi.author: Diane N.
mochi.review: A MUST GO and TRY!  Oh my goodness...a friend gave this place a thumbs up on Sat and several of us immediately went! Great service from the hardworking ladies and also just amazing spices and flavors! This was my first visit and we had the classic beef shabu shabu, wonderful DUCK(yep, there's duck) with shitake mushrooms, and kim chee pork belly (with mochi)! Everything just melts in your mouth! I have cut out beef and pork from my diet and eating more greens, but this meal was my one-time pass card!  There are a ton of veggies too!  All the dishes come packed with good protein, fresh healthy greens, and then you finish with OMG...rice porridge!  Who does that?  This place does!  I did not have the sake yet...but I'm sure it's a must as well.  Delish! I'm coming back and trying the rest of the items on the menu.
